Ida J Wolcott 48, b. NY, 3 children
Carolyn Wolcott 52, b. NY
George P Wolcott 19, b. NY
Charles J Wolcott 18, b. NY
Magie Mason 38, b. NY, servant
(9) Franklin Anson Wolcott (George Paul Wolcott8, Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 APR 1853 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 15 MAY 1884 .
(9) Elizabeth Georgiana Wolcott (George Paul Wolcott8, Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 JUN 1856 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 1937 .
(8) Elvira Antoinette Wolcott (Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 SEP 1820 Bloomfield, Ontario Co., New York, d. 24 SEP 1865 .
m. 26 JUN 1860 Edward Jackson Jenks , b. 3 MAR 1817 ,, Massachusetts, d. .
(8) Oliver Epaphras Wolcott (Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAR 1827 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 21 OCT 1829 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
(8) Georgianna Melvina Wolcott (Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JUN 1834 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 15 SEP 1835 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
(8) Julia M. Wolcott (Epaphras Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1838 , d. 11 MAY 1865 .
NotesJulia is placed here because she was buried in the pot owned by Epaphras' sons. She may be an in-law.

The funeral of the late Mrs. P.B. VIELE took place yesterday afternoon from the family residence, No. 139 North Union street. The services were conducted by Rev. Dr. RIGGS, assisted by Rev. Mr. BARSTOW. The deceased
was the daughter of the late Carlos and Billings DUTTON and is survived by
her husband, P.B. VIELE, secretary and treasurer of the East Side Savings
Bank, two sons, George B. CHASE of Cleveland and Benjamin B. CHASE, secretary
of the Title and Guarantee Company of this city, also two sisters, Mrs.
Abby G. HOWLAND of Perry, N.Y., and Mrs. Churchill H. CUTTING of Brooklyn.
m. Platt B. Viele , b. 1829 ,, New York, d. .
(7) James Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 MAY 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1866 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesJAMES settled at Rome, Oneida Co., New York, where all his children were born. He had a sawmill at Rome. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, and died there in the home of his son, Ebenezer. James was a Presbyterian.
m. 13 NOV 1814 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, Lovisa Emily Gould , b. 15 JUL 1792 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. ABT 1854 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York.
9 children: Ebenezer Gould, Norman, William, Anson Gould, Chauncey Smith, Francis Story, Charles Darwin, Beulah Ann, James Henry.
(8) Ebenezer Gould Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 SEP 1815 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 30 DEC 1885 Wolcottville, LaGrange Co., Indiana.
NotesEBENEZER was at Belvedere, Illinois, in 1850, with wife Maria L. 29, and daughter, Ella, 2. He was a produce dealer at Oswego, New York, in 1859. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, recorded as Edgar G. Woolcott, with Maria L., Charles, Ellen M., and his father, James Wolcott. He was also at Chicago in 1870, recorded as Edward G., with wife Mary L., and daughter Ella. He and 5 other men together purchased 400 acres of land in Michigan in 1870. In 1880, E. G. Wolcott was a produce merchant at Chicago, Illinois.
m. 17 AUG 1843 Maria Louise Brown , b. MAY 1820 Caledonia, Monroe Co., New York, d. 29 NOV 1905 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
3 children: Ella, Charles Theron, Ebenezer Gould.
(9) Ella Wolcott (Ebenezer Gould Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1848 ,, Wisconsin, d. .
(9) Charles Theron Wolcott (Ebenezer Gould Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 AUG 1851 Belvidere, Boone Co., Illinois, d. 3 JAN 1861 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
(9) Ebenezer Gould Wolcott (Ebenezer Gould Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JAN 1856 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 25 JUN 1860 .
(8) Norman Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 SEP 1817 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. .
(8) William Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 SEP 1817 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 30 SEP 1817 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
(8) Anson Gould Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 OCT 1819 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 10 JAN 1907 Wolcott, White Co., Indiana.
NotesANSON began teaching school in Ontario County, New York, at the age of 15. When he was 21 he went to Claibourne Parish, Louisiana, and studied law with Judge Peets. He was admitted to the New York bar at Buffalo, New York, in 1842, and to the Supreme Court in 1852. He was a lawyer, farmer, and grain merchant. He purchased 2,000 acres of land from the Holland Land Co. in Royalton Township, Niagra Co., New York, and settled on it in 1847. He dug a well and built a steam sawmil, He employed a large number of men in cutting and processing lumber, and built a boarding house for them to live in. He was living at Lockport, New York, in 1850. Lockport is adjascent to Royalton. In 1851 he deeded his land to four trustees who divided the land into small plots. He came to Indiana as an attorney for a railroad company, and purchased several square miles of land where the railroad would be located. The town of Wolcottsville was laid out in 1861, next to the Toledo, Logansport, and Burlington Railroad, later part of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It was named in his honor. On an errand to Washington, D.C. in 1861, he heard of the Confederate attack on the Union Army at Bull Run and hastened to the battle area to assist in the fight, receiving a minor wound. He and his brother, Ebenezer, settled in Princeton Township, White Co., Indiana, in 1858, and laid out a town that became Wolcott, Indiana, in 1861. Here Anson built a large 14 room home in 1864, later occupied by his son, Eben. The home is still standing at 500 N. Range St., and is listed on the National Registry of Historical Places. He had a large farm called Wolcott Farm. In 1956 it was given by his grandson, Roger Wolcot, to Princeton Township. It is now the home of the Anson Wolcott Historical Society, who began restoring it in 1974. In 1868 Anson was elected as a Republican to the Indiana State Senate, where he was Chairman of the Finance Committee. He was reelected in 1871, and was Chairman of the Finance Committee . In 1872, his trustees in New York sold lots to seventy five families from Prussia, who drew lots for the land. Anson moved his sawmill from Wolcottsville, New York, to Erie Co., New York, at that time. In 1876 he was nominated for Governor on the Greenback Party ticket., but in later years returned to the Republican party. In 1880 he was an attorney, living in a boarding house at Logansport, Indiana. He later resided in Denver, Colorado, where he owned considerable mining property.
m. 12 JUL 1848 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, Elizabeth Walbridge , b. 2 APR 1823 Geneva, Ontario Co., New York, d. 26 APR 1909 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
1 children: Henry Walbridge.
(9) Henry Walbridge Wolcott (Anson Gould Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 SEP 1849 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. Blackstone, Nottoway Co., Virginia.
NotesHENRY W. Wolcott was an agent for the T., W. & W. Railroad at Logansport, Indiana, in 1874. He was a laborer at Fremont, Sandusky Co., Ohio, in 1880: Henry W. Walcott 30 born NY, laborer. Helen 27 born Scotland, Helen 4, Hugh 2, son 1 month, all born Scotland, Jane McTyre 60, Ranson Wolcott, brother, 16, born Ohio.
(8) Anson Gould Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 OCT 1819 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 10 JAN 1907 Wolcott, White Co., Indiana.
NotesANSON began teaching school in Ontario County, New York, at the age of 15. When he was 21 he went to Claibourne Parish, Louisiana, and studied law with Judge Peets. He was admitted to the New York bar at Buffalo, New York, in 1842, and to the Supreme Court in 1852. He was a lawyer, farmer, and grain merchant. He purchased 2,000 acres of land from the Holland Land Co. in Royalton Township, Niagra Co., New York, and settled on it in 1847. He dug a well and built a steam sawmil, He employed a large number of men in cutting and processing lumber, and built a boarding house for them to live in. He was living at Lockport, New York, in 1850. Lockport is adjascent to Royalton. In 1851 he deeded his land to four trustees who divided the land into small plots. He came to Indiana as an attorney for a railroad company, and purchased several square miles of land where the railroad would be located. The town of Wolcottsville was laid out in 1861, next to the Toledo, Logansport, and Burlington Railroad, later part of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It was named in his honor. On an errand to Washington, D.C. in 1861, he heard of the Confederate attack on the Union Army at Bull Run and hastened to the battle area to assist in the fight, receiving a minor wound. He and his brother, Ebenezer, settled in Princeton Township, White Co., Indiana, in 1858, and laid out a town that became Wolcott, Indiana, in 1861. Here Anson built a large 14 room home in 1864, later occupied by his son, Eben. The home is still standing at 500 N. Range St., and is listed on the National Registry of Historical Places. He had a large farm called Wolcott Farm. In 1956 it was given by his grandson, Roger Wolcot, to Princeton Township. It is now the home of the Anson Wolcott Historical Society, who began restoring it in 1974. In 1868 Anson was elected as a Republican to the Indiana State Senate, where he was Chairman of the Finance Committee. He was reelected in 1871, and was Chairman of the Finance Committee . In 1872, his trustees in New York sold lots to seventy five families from Prussia, who drew lots for the land. Anson moved his sawmill from Wolcottsville, New York, to Erie Co., New York, at that time. In 1876 he was nominated for Governor on the Greenback Party ticket., but in later years returned to the Republican party. In 1880 he was an attorney, living in a boarding house at Logansport, Indiana. He later resided in Denver, Colorado, where he owned considerable mining property.
m. 11 FEB 1863 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, Georgiana De Ismisquero Sayne , b. Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 4 AUG 1877 Wolcott, White Co., Indiana.
1 children: Eben Henry.
(9) Eben Henry Wolcott (Anson Gould Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 MAY 1866 Wolcott, White Co., Indiana, d. 21 AUG 1941 Indianapolis, Marion Co., Indiana.
NotesEBEN graduated from Wabash College in 1886. He was in the grain business, and later involved in the Western Motor Co. of Logansport, manufacturer of the Reutenber Motor. He was President of the State Savings and Trust Co. at Indianapolis, and later Chairman of the Board of that bank. He was a member of the State Board of Tax Comissioners, State Bank Comissioner under 3 different Governors, President of the Standard Investments and Security Co. of Indianapolis, and was a Trustee of Wabash College beginning in 1906. He was a grain dealer at Princeton Township, White Co., Indiana, in 1900, where his wife as called Ellen. Eben was elected a state senator for White, Newton, and Jasper Counties in 1900. He was considered an eloquent speaker. He resided at Logansport, Indiana, in 1908, Marion, Indiana, in 1909, and at Indianapolis in 1914-25. In 1916 he left his job as State Assessor for Indiana to become President of the State Savings and Trust Co. of Indianapolis. He was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1908, chairman of the Historical Committee and speaker at the Wolcott reunion in 1909, president of the 1910 reunion, President of the Wolcott Society 1910-1911, and 1916-1917, vice-president for Indiana 1909-17, and spoke at several of the reunions. For 23 years he was the executive director of the Indianapolis Volunteers of America.
(8) Chauncey Smith Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 NOV 1821 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 28 DEC 1890 Portland, Ionia Co., Michigan.
NotesCHAUNCEY was a farmer at Lockport, New York, in 1850 with wife Sarah M. and daughter Sarah M. Wolcott. He later worked in sales and manufacturing. For the last 22 years of his life he was in the shoe business and the grocery business at Portland, Michigan.
m. 24 SEP 1849 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, Sarah M. Wakeman , b. 3 JUL 1828 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 16 JUL 1850 .
1 children: Sarah M..
(9) Sarah M. Wolcott (Chauncey Smith Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1850 ,, New York, d. .
(8) Chauncey Smith Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 NOV 1821 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 28 DEC 1890 Portland, Ionia Co., Michigan.
NotesCHAUNCEY was a farmer at Lockport, New York, in 1850 with wife Sarah M. and daughter Sarah M. Wolcott. He later worked in sales and manufacturing. For the last 22 years of his life he was in the shoe business and the grocery business at Portland, Michigan.
m. 1850 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, Adaline Brockway , b. 20 JUN 1830 ,, New York, d. 20 AUG 1898 Portland, Ionia Co., Michigan.
1 children: Florence I..

NotesCHARLES drowned.
(8) Beulah Ann Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 AUG 1827 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 17 NOV 1891 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania.

3 children: Frances Emily, Celia Wright, Mary.
(9) Frances Emily Fletcher (Beulah Ann Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 NOV 1850 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 12 NOV 1902 .
(9) Celia Wright Fletcher (Beulah Ann Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 DEC 1857 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 20 JAN 1927 Trenton, Mercer Co., New Jersey.
NotesCELIA was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914 residing at Erie, Pennsylvania.
(9) Mary Fletcher (Beulah Ann Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 NOV 1859 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 5 DEC 1881 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania.
(8) James Henry Wolcott (James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAR 1831 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 24 NOV 1895 La Grange, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesJAMES was a broker. He helped his father run a sawmill in Rome, New York, and then moved to New York City where he had a wholesale dry goods business. He then moved to Galena, Illinois and operated a meat packing business. In 1858 he moved to Chicago and had a meat packing business at the Chicago Stock Yard. He lived at Pepin, Wisconsin, where he was in 1860, with wife Kate and daughter, Beulah L. Wolcott. He was at Chicago in 1870 with Kate R., Beulah L., James G., Katie W. and Ebenezer G. He helped organize the Chicago Board of Trade. He moved from Galena, Illinois, to LaGrange, Illinois, about 1880, where he built a home at Maple and Madison Aves.
m. 27 OCT 1857 Galena, Jo Daviess Co., Illinois, Kathryn "Kate" Reinwald , b. 19 OCT 1834 Baltimore, Baltimore Co., Maryland, d. 15 OCT 1926 LaGrange, DuPage Co., Illinois.
4 children: Beulah Louise, James Griffith "Jim", Kathryn Wilimina "Kate", Ebenezer Gould "Eben".
(9) Beulah Louise Wolcott (James Henry Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 MAR 1859 Galena, Jo Daviess Co., Illinois, d. 29 MAY 1938 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesBEULAH was a member of the Wolcott Society 1911-15, and member of the Executive Committee in 1915. She was the 16th President of the Society of Descendants of Henry Wolcott, 1926-27. She lived at Chicago 1911-38.
(9) James Griffith "Jim" Wolcott (James Henry Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 MAR 1861 Galena, Jo Daviess Co., Illinois, d. 18 DEC 1926 LaGrange, DuPage Co., Illinois.
NotesJAMES moved to LaGrange with his parents in 1879, and began working for the post office. He then worked in the County Clerk's Office for over 30 years. In 1892, he was elected tax assessor for Lyons Township, serving for 34 years. For the last 16 years of his life, he worked in the Tax Redemption Department. He became county comissioner in 1921. He was active in many civic organizations, including the Masons, Woodsmen, Elks. He was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914, and Chairman of the Executive Committee in 1915.
(9) Kathryn Wilimina "Kate" Wolcott (James Henry Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 OCT 1863 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesKATHRYN was a member of the Wolcott Society 1911-15 and she or her husband was a member of the Society executive committee in 1915. She lived at Chicago 1911-26, and re-registered as member #105 in 1925.
(9) Ebenezer Gould "Eben" Wolcott (James Henry Wolcott8, James Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 FEB 1866 Galena, Jo Daviess Co., Illinois, d. 10 JAN 1905 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesEBEN lived at Chicago in 1926.
(7) Norman Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 APR 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 OCT 1852 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky.
NotesNORMAN came to Bloomfield, New York, to help his brother, Anson, operate a silkworm business. He moved to Warren County, Ohio, about 1819. Norman, his wife and infant son, and the Henry family, left there on a flatboat, en route to New Orleans. Coming down the Ohio River they encountered a lot of ice, so they spent the winter of 1820 camped at the mouth of the Green River. The Henry family continued down the river, but left their son, James, with the Wolcotts. James later married Norman's daughter. In the spring, Norman, continued up the Green River and settled at a place on the Green River, 6 miles north of South Carrollton, Kentucky. This became known as Wolcott's Landing. There he built a grist mill. He operated the mill until he got his arm crushed in the mill machinery. He later died of the injury.

1850 Ohio, Ohio Co. KY:Norman Walcott 56 Massachusetts, miller
Mary A Walcott F 54 North Carolina
Oliver H Walcott M 22 New York, Distiller
Nancy J Walcott F 19 New York
Isabella Cole F 65 North Carolina
next to James Walcott,29, b. OH, distiller
Louisa Walcott, 15
m. 1 FEB 1820 , Warren Co., Ohio, Mary Ann Mac Gregor , b. 1797 Aberdeen,, Scotland, d. 24 OCT 1862 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky.
5 children: James MacGregor, Christina, Anson, Oliver Hector, Nancy Jane,
(8) James MacGregor Wolcott (Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 NOV 1820 , Warren Co., Ohio, d. 24 AUG 1896 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
NotesJAMES operated his father's mill at Wolcott's Landing. Later he was Captain of a Green River steamer, called "The Enterprise", on which he built a saw mill. He traveled the Green River sawing lumber for landowners who lived along the river. During the Civil War, he organized and was Capt. of the home militia. He built a grist mill at South Carrolton, Kentucky. In 1880 he was a Miller and Engineer at South Carrollton.
m. 10 JAN 1850 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky, Louisa Jane "Jennie" Bullock , b. 25 AUG 1832 ,, Kentucky, d. 22 APR 1875 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
5 children: Hortense Amelia, George Alfred, Louisa Jane, Charles Edgar, James Franklin.
(9) Hortense Amelia Wolcott (James MacGregor Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1850 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 2 FEB 1922 Marion, Marion Co., Indiana.
(9) George Alfred Wolcott (James MacGregor Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JAN 1853 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 5 FEB 1901 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
NotesGEORGE and his wife were living with Susan Strother, age 63, at South Carrollton in 1880. Susan was probably his wife's aunt or stepmother. His middle name is also given as Albert. In 1900 he was a wholesale merchant at South Carrollton with 3 children.
(9) Louisa Jane Wolcott (James MacGregor Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 MAR 1855 , Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky, d. 28 OCT 1931 Big Clifty, Grayson Co., Kentucky.
(9) Charles Edgar Wolcott (James MacGregor Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 AUG 1857 , Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky, d. 29 AUG 1932 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
NotesCHARLES was a partner with his brothers in the familyflour milling and shipping business at South Carrollton. He managed the mill while they ran the steamboat. The mill was built in 1887, and was the first roller mill in Muhlenberg County. It operated for 50 years. He was a miller at South Carrollton in 1900.

1920 Muhlenburg Co. KY:
Charles E Wolcott M 62y
Spouse Mollie Wolcott F 50y
(9) James Franklin Wolcott (James MacGregor Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 APR 1859 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky, d. 6 DEC 1950 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
NotesJAMES and two of his brothers owned a steam boat with a saw mill on it called "The Lumberman". They cut 2 1/2 million feet of lumber for the government, which was used in making concrete forms for the locks at Glenmore, Kentucky. They also owned and operated a flour mill at South Carrollton, Kentucky, begun in 1887, and operated by the Wolcotts for 50 years. In 1895 the brothers built the steamship "Three Brothers", 100 feet long, one of the largest boats on the Green River. They had a saw mill on the boat, which they later removed and used the boat only for carrying freight. They then operated the boat as part of a wholesale grocery business, delivering food to stores all along the Green River. George was the Captain, and James the engineer. After George's death in 1900, James studied for his captain's license and later became captain. James sold the boat sold the boat, and devoted their attention to the flour milling business, which James managed until 1933. James was President of the Citizens Bank at South Carrollton.

1920 Muhlenberg Co. KY:
James F Wolcott M 60y
Spouse Betty Wolcott F 60y
Child Rena Wolcott F 23y
Timothy H Brown M 46y
Ilene Brown F 17y
Sarah Brown F 11y
(8) Christina Wolcott (Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 NOV 1822 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 27 NOV 1886 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
m. 2 APR 1846 James Henry , b. 1822 ,, Ohio, d. 2 MAR 1867 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky.
6 children: J. S., W.C., Albert M., Mary E., Samuel N., Mattie.
(9) J. S. Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAR 1848 South Carrollton, Muhlenberg Co., Kentucky, d. 1911 Marion,, Kentucky.
NotesJ. W. graduated from Bethel College in 1869, and then moved to Evansville, Indiana, where he learned the stone cutting trade. He was ordained a minister in the United Baptist Church in 1870, and was clerk of the Ohio River Baptist Association for 28 years. He preached all over Western Kentucky. He had a stone business at Madisonville, Kentucky from about 1872 to 1882, and then moved to Marion, Kentucky, where he opened a stone and marble business in 1881. In 1896 he sold the business to his brothers, S. N. and Albert, who ran it until 1905, when they sold it to J. W.s sons.
(9) W.C. Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Albert M. Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Mary E. Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Samuel N. Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Mattie Henry (Christina Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Anson Wolcott (Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 FEB 1825 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 8 JUL 1826 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky.
(8) Oliver Hector Wolcott (Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 JAN 1828 Wolcott's Landing, Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. APR 1863 .
Notes1850 Ohio KY:


Oliver Walcot was a farmer, age 33, born New Jersey, at Point Pleasant, Ohio Co., Kentucky, in 1860, with Sarah 30, Christina 7, Augustus 6, Alva 5, Millard F. 3, and Marinda 1, all born in Kentucky. Oliver served in the Union Army during the Civil War. He was severely wounded at the Battle of Shilow. A crucial part of this battle took place in a peach orchard where the trees were in bloom. As the battle raged, petals fell like snow. It was here that Oliver was wounded. He received a disability discharge at Pittsburg Landing 7 April 1862, and never fully recovered from his wounds. The gun carried in the war by Oliver, and a bowie knife belonging to him, were owned by his niece, Rena Wolcott Crabtree.
m. 1851 Sarah Ellen "Sally" Dexter , b. 1830 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 1862 , Ohio Co., Kentucky.
6 children: Christina Isabelle, William Augustus "Gus", Alva Arista, Millard Winfield, Mary Ellen, Robert Vaughn.
(9) Christina Isabelle Wolcott (Oliver Hector Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. NOV 1852 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. FEB 1875 .
NotesCHRISTEN's name is Catherine on a record transcription of marriages at Ohio Co., Kentucky.
(9) William Augustus "Gus" Wolcott (Oliver Hector Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1854 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 1899 .
NotesWilliam was wounded during the Civil War. He learned the stonecutting trade at Madisonville, Kentucky. He and his brothers, Alva and Robert, established a stonecutting business at McKinney, Texas, called "W. W. Wolcott and Bros., Monuments, Tablets and Headstones".
(9) Alva Arista Wolcott (Oliver Hector Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 AUG 1855 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. 14 MAY 1929 Wetherford, Parker Co., Texas.
NotesALVA was a stonecutter. In 1883, his father-in-law, J. B. Pond, deeded him land at McKinney, Texas. After the death of his brother, William, in 1899, he took over the management of their stone cutting business, specializing in tombstones, at McKinney.

Alva Walcott was at Smith Co., Texas, in 1920, with his son, Joe M. Wolcott.
(9) Millard Winfield Wolcott (Oliver Hector Wolcott8, Norman Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Epaphras Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1857 , Ohio Co., Kentucky, d. .

NotesROBERT was a stone cutter and worked with his brothers at McKinney, Texas. He then moved to Helen, Montana. In 1930 he was at San Augustine, Texas.

NotesHORACE was a printer and newspaper worker. He worked for the Chicago Evening Post, and in the advertising departments of the New York Times and The Annalist in New York City. (5) Parmenio Wolcott (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 APR 1746 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 JAN 1812 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
NotesPARMENIO moved to Rome, New York, shortly after his marriage. He had a farm there. However, he appears on the 1790 census at East Windsor, with a family of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 3 females. Information about his family is found in an 1825 Bible, apparently recorded by his daughter, Mary Wolcott Stone.
m. 1767 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Mary Ballard , b. 11 OCT 1750 Lancaster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 2 MAR 1833 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
8 children: Alfred, Parmenio, Prudence, , Josiah, Mary "Polly", Prudence, Lydia.
(6) Alfred Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 APR 1769 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 20 NOV 1835 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED came to the Western Reserve, which later became Ohio, in 1796. He had been hired as a surveyor by John Young, the founder of Youngstown. He also surveyed the towns of Canfield and Bristol, for which the Connecticut Land Co. gave him 350 acres of land as payment. He erected the first building in Bristol Township. His marriage to Mary Gilson in 1800 was the first marriage in the county, but the ceremony was actually performed in Pennsylvania as there was no minister in Mahoning County. Mary must have died soon after their marriage, for by 1806 he had bought half of Boston Township in Portage County, and had gone there to clear the ground for his farm, and to build a log house for his new bride, Margaret Craig Wolcott. Alfred was a taxpayer in Portage Co. in 1808. This part of Portage County later became Summit County. Alfred was elected Justice of the Peace in the first election, and also serving as a fence-viewer. His old record book containing all cases that came to him as Justice was in the possession of his great-grandson, Oliver Wolcott, of Copley, Ohio. The Wolcott's daughter Malinda was the first white child born in Boston Township. In 1816 a log schoolhouse was built in the Wolcott neighborhood, and Alfred Wolcott was the first schoolmaster. It is said that there was a tiny school near his home in which he taught as early as 1812. Alfred served in Capt. Rial McArthur's Co. from August to October 1812, during the War of 1812. His will left his land, about 119 acres, to his wife, Margaret, with the exception of a half acre left as a burial ground for the township of Boston, now called the Fairview Cemetery, established in 1890.
m. 1800 Mary Gilson , b. , d. .
1 children: Lydia.
(7) Lydia Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1804 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 JUN 1834 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesLYDIA died of Tuberculosis, age 32.
m. 23 FEB 1823 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, George Leach , b. 1798 Goshen, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 31 JUL 1853 .
5 children: Clarissa, Eliza, Lydia, Luman George, George.
(8) Clarissa Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
m. Allen Ingersoll , b. , d. .
(8) Clarissa Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
m. S. Gaylord , b. , d. .
(8) Eliza Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
(8) Lydia Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
m. Conrad Schoch , b. , d. .
1 children: Maud.
(9) Maud Schoch (Lydia Leach8, Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1867 , d. FEB 1948 .
(8) Luman George Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1829 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 31 JAN 1832 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) George Leach (Lydia Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. JUN 1833 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 31 JUL 1833 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(6) Alfred Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 APR 1769 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 20 NOV 1835 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED came to the Western Reserve, which later became Ohio, in 1796. He had been hired as a surveyor by John Young, the founder of Youngstown. He also surveyed the towns of Canfield and Bristol, for which the Connecticut Land Co. gave him 350 acres of land as payment. He erected the first building in Bristol Township. His marriage to Mary Gilson in 1800 was the first marriage in the county, but the ceremony was actually performed in Pennsylvania as there was no minister in Mahoning County. Mary must have died soon after their marriage, for by 1806 he had bought half of Boston Township in Portage County, and had gone there to clear the ground for his farm, and to build a log house for his new bride, Margaret Craig Wolcott. Alfred was a taxpayer in Portage Co. in 1808. This part of Portage County later became Summit County. Alfred was elected Justice of the Peace in the first election, and also serving as a fence-viewer. His old record book containing all cases that came to him as Justice was in the possession of his great-grandson, Oliver Wolcott, of Copley, Ohio. The Wolcott's daughter Malinda was the first white child born in Boston Township. In 1816 a log schoolhouse was built in the Wolcott neighborhood, and Alfred Wolcott was the first schoolmaster. It is said that there was a tiny school near his home in which he taught as early as 1812. Alfred served in Capt. Rial McArthur's Co. from August to October 1812, during the War of 1812. His will left his land, about 119 acres, to his wife, Margaret, with the exception of a half acre left as a burial ground for the township of Boston, now called the Fairview Cemetery, established in 1890.
m. 27 MAY 1806 Youngstown, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Margaret Craig , b. 1785 Wheeling, Ohio Co., West Virginia, d. 28 FEB 1863 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
8 children: Malinda, Edytha, Parmenio, Alfred, Josiah, Darius, Mary, Simon Perkins.
(7) Malinda Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 APR 1807 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1878 .

m. 10 JAN 1828 , Portage Co., Ohio, Zebulon Stow , b. 8 APR 1802 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 28 SEP 1871 Cascade, Kent Co., Michigan.

(8) Russel J. Stow (Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 AUG 1837 , Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesRUSSELL was a table manufacturer at Grand Rapids, Michigan, in 1880, with wife Harriet, and daughter Ella.
m. 27 OCT 1864 Paris Township, Kent Co., Michigan, Harriet H. Henshaw , b. 1 OCT 1846 , Summit Co., Ohio, d. 31 MAY 1918 .
1 children: Ella A..
(9) Ella A. Stow (Russel J. Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1869 ,, Michigan, d. .
(8) Alfred Wolcott Stow (Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1838 , Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
m. 8 FEB 1862 Cascade, Kent Co., Michigan, Clara Augusta Beckley , b. 28 AUG 1841 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 18 MAR 1910 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
4 children: Lucy Sarah, Millie Miriam, Julia Augusta, Ralph Albert.
(9) Lucy Sarah Stow (Alfred Wolcott Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 NOV 1864 Cascade Township, Kent Co., Michigan, d. .
(9) Millie Miriam Stow (Alfred Wolcott Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 DEC 1869 Caledonia, Kent Co., Michigan, d. .
(9) Julia Augusta Stow (Alfred Wolcott Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 NOV 1877 Caledonia, Kent Co., Michigan, d. 3 APR 1974 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
(9) Ralph Albert Stow (Alfred Wolcott Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 MAR 1881 Caledonia, Kent Co., Michigan, d. .
(8) Lucy Abiah Stow (Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 DEC 1841 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 9 FEB 1904 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
m. 17 DEC 1863 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, William Bellamy , b. 11 AUG 1839 London,, England, d. 18 NOV 1905 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
6 children: Clara Alice, Ida Anna, George Albert, Wilber Everett, William A., Claude C..
(9) Clara Alice Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 SEP 1864 Cascade Township, Kent Co., Michigan, d. 27 APR 1904 .
(9) Ida Anna Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 OCT 1869 , d. .
(9) George Albert Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 SEP 1872 Cascade, Kent Co., Michigan, d. 8 JUL 1960 Chagrin Falls, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesGEORGE graduated from Hiram College and came to Cleveland in 1896. In that year he founded Hiram House, an experimental school and summer camp at Chagrin Falls, near Cleveland. During the first World War he was head of the War Dept's. Committee on Training Camp Activities, charged with establishing recreational facilities for the soldiers. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1926 as member #117, residing at Cleveland, Ohio, and was reccorded as member #84 in 1930, residing at Cleveland. He and Harry Bliis were the founders of the Henry Wolcott Foundation.

"Bellamy's immediate family had little money, and from the day George
left home, he found it necessary to earn his own living. He worked his way
through Hiram College in northeastern Ohio with various selling jobs and
graduated in 1896. The idea of founding a settlement, or neighborhood house in a congested area that would provide various social services to the community, was conceived by Bellamy while still in college. Two years before graduation, he
met Graham Taylor who had just founded the Chicago Commons settlement
and had written the Y.M.C.A. Handbook used by members of a club studying sociological questions at Hiram College. Later Bellamy was to creditTaylor with "the motivation of my life work."4 In the spring of 1896 this club voted to study the need for a social settlement in Cleveland. A quick trip to Cleveland convinced them that the need did in fact exist. In the summer Bellamy and two other members of the club moved to Cleveland to begin a settlement which they named Hiram House because the first
residents were graduates of Hiram College. Four others joined them to
make an initial group of seven residents, or social workers who lived in
the neighborhood they were trying to help. Bellamy's financial resources during the first few years were slender. To finance the fledgling project, he solicited contributions, but the largest amount given by anyone during the first year was $75.00. He rented a
small house which provided only enough space for a nursery and the clubs,
forcing him to find living space across the street. In the spring, the settlement was evicted from its first home because too many people were using
the house and causing too much wear on it, in the opinion of the landlord.
The rent had been paid, but Bellamy had fallen behind in paying salaries, including his own. In order to buy a badly needed suit, he had to take a temporary job collecting pledges for the Anti-Saloon League. By 1898, the settlement in its second location had expanded to includenine clubs, a nursery, and a kindergarten with sixty-five children enrolled.

Also, with incorporation in 1898, the house began to receive gifts from
prominent Cleveland philanthropists, led by Samuel Mather, and in 1899
ground was broken for its own building near Twenty-seventh and Orange.
Bellamy was then at last able to relax secure in the knowledge that Hiram
House was going to have a place where the settlement work could proceed.
To Bellamy and many of his contemporaries, the key to social problems
was the environment--improve the environment and social problems will
be alleviated, or so they thought. Specifically, Bellamy blamed congestion
in the slums for health problems, law-breaking, low morals, and truancy.
In response to these and other social problems, settlements offered facilities
and programs which were intended to be of a remedial nature. They also
supported the rehabilitative efforts of other charities and organizations,
and they became closely connected with the social gospel and progressivemovements. However, from the beginning of the first settlement in the world, Toynbee Hall founded by Samuel Barnett in London, the settlement approach differed from that of other organizations.

"Bellamy was forced to be practical about money matters and did not stay in the public
recreation department. Francis F. Prentiss, chairman of the Hiram House
board, had recognized his financial need. When Bellamy had been offered
the job of secretary of the Playground Association in 1910, Prentiss held
out the possibility of a salary increase and mentioned picking up the deficit
on Bellamy's farm if he would not leave the settlement.16 By the depression years Bellamy's salary reached $7500 plus "other benefits"--Samuel Mather and others also paid for the college education of his daughters. Even so, Bellamy probably made less money than if he had gone into business with his ability as a salesman and fund raiser."


"George Bellamy was a master at the art of fundraising. He once remarked to Francis F. Prentiss, "As a boy, our churchalways used to get me to sell tickets."31 By 1899, Bellamy had gone from selling church tickets to soliciting large sums of money from Samuel Mather and John D. Rockefeller. The list of contributors to Hiram House soon
read like a "Who's Who in Cleveland."
(9) Wilber Everett Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 SEP 1874 , d. 25 OCT 1881 .
(9) William A. Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 SEP 1874 , d. .
(9) Claude C. Bellamy (Lucy Abiah Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1880 , d. 30 OCT 1881 .

1 children: Bertha.
(9) Bertha Stow (L.C. Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 JUL 1875 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio, d. 1948 .
NotesBERTHA joined the Wolcott Society in 1946 as member #329, residing at Hanford, California.
(8) Laura Stow (Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 JAN 1849 Stowe, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 27 APR 1937 .
m. 16 APR 1868 Franklin Patterson , b. 5 DEC 1844 , d. .
1 children: Mattie.
(9) Mattie Patterson (Laura Stow8, Edytha Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 FEB 1871 Cascade, Kent Co., Michigan, d. .
NotesMATTIE joined the Wolcott Society in 1946 as member #336, residing at St. Petersburg, Florida.
(7) Parmenio Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 MAY 1810 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 JUL 1871 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesPARMENIO was a farmer. He was a town trustee of Norfolk, Ohio, from 1862 to 1871. In 1870 Parmenio was at Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, with Emeline and James M. Wolcott. He purchased a house and land in Summit Co., Ohio, from George Thompson in 1853. It was a stone farmhouse in the Greek Revival style and is now on the Ohio Historic Registry. Three generations of Wolcotts lived here, and operated a cheese factory on the property. It was owned by his son, James, who deeded it to Avis G. Wolcott in 1898. Avis sold it to Henry E. Bourne in 1913.
m. 10 JUN 1835 , Portage Co., Ohio, Emeline Tupper , b. 27 MAY 1815 Parishville, St. Lawrence Co., New York, d. 27 JUN 1894 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
6 children: Malinda, Alfred Newton, Phoebe Lorette, James Monroe, Daniel, Margaret Lucinda.
(8) Malinda Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 DEC 1838 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1907 .
m. 2 JUL 1857 , Summit Co., Ohio, Sylvester P. Ozmun , b. , d. .
3 children: James, Sylvester, Levina.

(8) Alfred Newton Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 MAY 1840 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. FEB 1893 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
Notes1870 Boston OH:
1870 Boston OH:
Alfred A Woolcott M 30y, farmer
Mary Woolcott F 26y

Hebert Woolcott M 4y

Alfred N. Wolcott, 40, born Connecticut, was a carpenter at Boston, Ohio, in 1880. With him was Nellie 35, Eloada 16, Herbert 13, Alice 9, Ara 6, and Arthur 6, all born Ohio.
m. 31 DEC 1863 ,, Ohio, Ella A. "Nellie" Wells , b. 1 JAN 1845 Bedford, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 25 MAR 1900 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
6 children: Elzada M., Herbert Rockwell "Bert", Alice Gertrude, Arthur Lee, Avis Lenore, Herman A..
(9) Elzada M. Wolcott (Alfred Newton Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 NOV 1864 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 21 FEB 1936 Macedonia, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesAfter Elzada's divorce, she worked in Cleveland as a housekeeper and a seamtress. Two quilts that she made are in the family of her great granddaughter, Barbara Tatham (1998).
(9) Herbert Rockwell "Bert" Wolcott (Alfred Newton Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 JUL 1866 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 MAY 1924 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesHERBERT, his wife, May E., and their son Alfred R. were living with his mother-in-law Sarah Phillips, at Bedford Township, Cuyahoga Co. Ohio, in 1900. Herbert Rockwell Wolcott homesteaded 320 acres of land at McKenzie Co., North Dakota, in 1919, and was a retired rancher when he died 1 May 1924 age 57 yrs., 8 mo., 11 d..
(9) Alice Gertrude Wolcott (Alfred Newton Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 APR 1871 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 30 JUN 1944 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(9) Arthur Lee Wolcott (Alfred Newton Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JUN 1874 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 9 JUN 1952 Ravenna, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesARTHUR was a farmer and raised rabbits.

2 children: Hettie E., Lottie.
(9) Hettie E. Gay (Phoebe Lorette Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 SEP 1867 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 OCT 1954 .
(9) Lottie Gay (Phoebe Lorette Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1875 ,, Ohio, d. .
(8) James Monroe Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 AUG 1845 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 AUG 1892 , Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES was a farmer in Summit Co., Ohio. He took over his father's farm. In 1880 he was a farmer at Northampton Township, Summit Co., Ohio, with wife Avis 27 and mother Emeline 65. His wife sold the farm in 1913 to the Presbyterian Church, who established a "fresh air camp", known as the Goodrich Social Settlement there.
m. 1880 Northfield-Macedonia Cemetery, Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, Avis Gertrude Phyle , b. 25 FEB 1852 Macedonia, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 2 APR 1931 Bedford, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
2 children: Henry Monroe, Lewis M..
(9) Henry Monroe Wolcott (James Monroe Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 MAR 1884 Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 26 MAR 1974 Bedford, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.

HENRY joined the Wolcott Society in 1941 as member 237, residing at Bedford, Ohio.
(9) Lewis M. Wolcott (James Monroe Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 DEC 1888 Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 22 FEB 1973 Twinsburg, Summit Co., Ohio.

Lewis M. Wolcott 45 was at Bedford Village, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, in 1930, with wife, Jessie L. 45, and son, Carroll M. 19, all born Ohio.
(8) Daniel Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1847 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .

m. 17 FEB 1880 , Summit Co., Ohio, Henry Jones , b. , d. .
2 children: Clarence, Lulu.
(9) Clarence Jones (Margaret Lucinda Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Lulu Jones (Margaret Lucinda Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(7) Alfred Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 JAN 1812 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 MAR 1892 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED and his 15 year old wife set up housekeeping in a log cabin on his father's farm at Boston Township, Ohio. The log cabin was replaced by a large farm house, and was expanded into a four hundred acre farm. Alfred served several terms in the Ohio legislature, and he saw to it that those of his children who wished it had a college education and professional training. In 1880 he was at Boston, Ohio, with Mary Ann, John, Anna A., Alfred, and Fremont Wolcott. His farm is now the Boston Mills Golf Course.
m. 18 APR 1831 Mary Ann Scoville , b. 1816 ,, Connecticut, d. 23 JUN 1882 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio.
11 children: Simon Perkins, Andrew Augustus, George Young, Andrew Augustus, Darius Young, Lucinda Marie, Thomas Darius, John Mead, Anna Augusta, Alfred E., Fremont Charles.
(8) Simon Perkins Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JAN 1837 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 6 APR 1901 Kent, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesSIMON graduated from Western Reserve College with an AM degree in 1862. He studied law at Hudson and Akron, Ohio, and was admitted to the bar in Summit County in 1864. He moved to Kent, Ohio, in 1867, where he was an attorney for the Atlantic & Great Western Railroad. In 1870 he was at Franklin, Portage Co., Ohio, with Mary, Nellie, and Jennie Wolcott. He was a personal friend of Presidents McKinley and Garfield. He was City Solicitor for Kent for two terms, a member of the school board for nine years, and a member of the Board of Examiners. For 9 years he was Deputy State Supervisor of Elections for Portage County. Simon was said to have been a great orator. He was elected Mayor of Kent in 1866, and was elected to the Ohio State Senate in 1881 as a Republican, and reelected in 1883. He built a house at 450 West Main St. in Kent, Ohio, in 1869.
m. 17 JUL 1866 Hudson, Summit Co., Ohio, Mary Helen Brewster , b. 29 DEC 1841 Hudson, Summit Co., Ohio, d. JAN 1910 Kent, Portage Co., Ohio.
3 children: Nellie Brewster, Jennie Brewster, Duncan Brewster.
(9) Nellie Brewster Wolcott (Simon Perkins Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1868 , d. 14 MAY 1955 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesNELLIE joined the Wolcott Society in 1943 as member #257, residing at Kent, Ohio.
(9) Jennie Brewster Wolcott (Simon Perkins Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 MAY 1870 , d. .
(9) Duncan Brewster Wolcott (Simon Perkins Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 MAY 1873 Kent, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 14 MAR 1930 Kent, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesDUNCAN graduated from Adelbert College in 1896, and from the law school of Western Reserve University in 1899 where he was a member of Beta Theta Pi fraternity. He was an attorney in Kent, Ohio, and was Prosecuting Attorney of Portage Co. for six years. He also had an insurance business. He moved to Kent, Ohio, in 1901. In 1906 he moved into the house his father had built on West Main St. Duncan served on the Kent Board of Education from 1918 to 1929, and was a vestryman of Christ Episcopal Church. He spoke at the 1909 Wolcott Reunion at Niagra Falls, was presiding officer at the 1914 reunion, and was President of The Society of Descendants of Henry Wolcott, 1915-1916 and 1921-1922.

1918 Draft Registration
Duncan Brewster Wolcott 45, b. 9 May 1873 White Kent, Portage, Ohio, Attorney at law, Kent OH, kin Mrs. Daisy L. Wolcott, Kent OH, tall , medium build, gray eyes, brown hair.
(8) Andrew Augustus Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 JAN 1839 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 DEC 1841 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) George Young Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 FEB 1841 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 27 FEB 1841 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) Andrew Augustus Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 FEB 1842 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 11 MAY 1862 Strasburg, Shenadoah Co., Virginia.
NotesANDREW enlisted in Co. D, 29th Ohio Inf. Regt. from Summit, Ohio. He also served in Co. H., 20th Ohio Infantry Regt. He died during the war at Strasburg, Virginia. His epitaph says he "died for his country."
(8) Darius Young Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 MAY 1845 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 12 AUG 1849 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) Lucinda Marie Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 JUL 1847 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 9 AUG 1849 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) Thomas Darius Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JUL 1850 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 11 AUG 1854 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(8) John Mead Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 APR 1853 Hudson, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1939 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJOHN learned to play the drum at age nine, and left home to join his brother, Andrew, who was in the army at Cleveland. His brother put him on the train and sent him home. He attended Western Reserve College, and at age 21 went to Grand Rapids, Michigan, to be a travelling salesman for a furniture manyfacturer. He and his wife lived with her parents at Grand Rapids in 1880. John moved to Washington, D.C., for his wife's health, and went to work for the Post Office, and later the Department of Commerse. He worked for the government for 25 years. He served in the U.S. Navy in both World War I and II. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1917, and was District of Columbia state vice president of the Wolcott Society.

1910 Washington DC

1920 Washington DC
m. 16 OCT 1878 Ada, Kent Co., Michigan, Rose Arabella Woodworth , b. 1855 Ada, Kent Co., Michigan, d. 1931 Washington, District of Columbia.
3 children: Nina, Neil Bernard, John Woodworth.
(9) Nina Wolcott (John Mead Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1880 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Neil Bernard Wolcott (John Mead Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 APR 1884 , Kent Co., Michigan, d. 19 JAN 1967 North Fort Myers, Lee Co., Florida.
NotesNEIL enlisted in the Naval Reserves in 1917, and turned over to the Navy the cruising yacht owned by him and his brother, John. He was given command of this boat, and did patrol duty at Norfolk, Virginia. In June 1917 he was sent to Annapolis, Maryland, for training, comissioned Ensign, and assigned to the USS Texas. He went to Europe Jan. 1918, was promoted to Lieutenant, and was signal officer, observation officer, and assistant navigation officer on the Texas, before the fleet returnd home. He was sent to London and France as naval attache, and then to Venice as communication officer, and then to Trieste. He was Vice President of Frederic P. Humphries. Inc., naval architects and yacht builders. Neil B. Wolcott and wife, Clara, were living at Red Bank, New Jersey, in 1938. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1947 as member #420, residing at Fairhaven, New Jersey.
(9) John Woodworth Wolcott (John Mead Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 FEB 1886 , d. 26 AUG 1954 .
Notes1918 Draft Registration:
John Woodworth Wolcott 32, b. 1 Feb 1886 clerk in cash room, Treasury Dept., Washington, District of Columbia, Mrs. Rose Wolcott, mother, Wash. DC, tall, slender, hazel eyes, light brown hair slightly bald..


JOHN was at Arlington, Virginia, in 1930, with Rosina V., Rose M., and Barbara S. Wolcott.
(8) Anna Augusta Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 FEB 1856 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
(8) Alfred E. Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAR 1858 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 MAR 1908 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED was a lawyer and a judge at Grand Rapids, Michigan. In 1888 he was a Circuit Court Commissioner. He was a two term Prosecuting Attorney from Kent Co., Michigan in 1892, and from 1900 to 1908 a Circuit Judge of 17th Judicial District of Michigan. He was the first Juvenile Court Judge in the State of Michigan. At the time of his death he was a judge of the Superior Court at Grand Rapids. He was prominent in securing indeterminate sentence laws and parole.

In 1900 he was a curcuit judge at Grand Rapids with Carrie B., Mabel L., and Hazel C. Wolcott.

He gave the principal speech at the third Wolcott reunion at Warren, Ohio, in 1907, and was elected the second President of the Society in that year.
m. 21 OCT 1885 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, Carrie B. Hauk , b. 17 JUN 1858 Suffield, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 10 NOV 1943 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio.
2 children: Mabel Louise, Hazel Katherine.
(9) Mabel Louise Wolcott (Alfred E. Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 JUL 1886 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesMABEL was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-20, residing at Grand Rapids, Michigan.
(9) Hazel Katherine Wolcott (Alfred E. Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 DEC 1889 Bluffton, Allen Co., Ohio, d. 5 APR 1983 .
NotesHAZEL lived in Los Angeles in 1920. She was carried on the roster of the Wolcott Society 1914-17, residing at Grand Rapids, Michigan.
(8) Fremont Charles Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 MAY 1863 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 10 AUG 1895 Canton, Stark Co., Ohio.
NotesFREMONT was a farmer in Summit Co., Ohio. He inherited the family homestead. He moved from Boston to Canton, Ohio in 1892. When he died in 1895, his family moved to Akron.

1910 Akron OH
Metta Walcott 44, b. OH
Lena F Wolcott 23, b. OH, stenographer
Olivar H Wolcott 21, b. OH, clerk, rubber factory
Kenneth W Wolcott 17, b. OH
Mary P Wolcott 15, b. OH
m. 25 NOV 1885 , Summit Co., Ohio, Metta E. "Mettie" Hand , b. 17 JAN 1866 Fairlawn, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 29 MAY 1936 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
4 children: Lena Florence, Oliver Hand, Kenneth Wight, Mary Pauline.
(9) Lena Florence Wolcott (Fremont Charles Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 AUG 1886 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Oliver Hand Wolcott (Fremont Charles Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 AUG 1888 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 4 DEC 1961 Copley, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesOLIVER was at Summit Co., Ohio, in 1820 with Annette and Fremont. He worked in the rubber industry for 27 years. He was office manager for the Miller Rubber Co., assistant manager of Goodyear Tires' distribution department, and distribution manager for Seiberlings Tires. He retiredin 1960. Oliver began collecting stamps when he was a child, and amasses an impressive collection. He later collected historic letters and documents as well. He owned hundreds of letters written from Civil War battlefields. His collection also contained letters written by President Garfield, one addressed to Simon Perkins Wolcott at Kent, Ohio. Oliver attended the 1914 Wolcott Society reunion with his mother in 1914. He was vice president of the Wolcott Society in 1936, and president in 1937.

1918 Draft Registration:
Oliver Hand Wolcott 28, b. 13 Aug 1888 Boston Twp. OH, lives Akron, Summit, Ohio, office manager, Miller Rubber Co., Akron, tall, medium build, grey eyes, dark hair
(9) Kenneth Wight Wolcott (Fremont Charles Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 AUG 1892 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 27 JUN 1959 Elizabeth, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesK. W. Wolcott of Akron, Ohio, attended the Wolcott Society reunion at Cleveland in 1914. Kenneth joined the Society in 1917, residing at Akron. He served with the 334th Field Hospital, 309th Sanitary Train, with the Army Expeditionary Force in France in 1918. He was an outstanding amateur golfer at Akron, Ohio. He was at Akron in 1930, with Doris, Cynthia, and Ellen Wolcott. He moved to Trenton, New Jersey, in 1930. He won the Trenton Country Club Championship 1931 to 1937, 1941, and 1943, and the Frank K. Fischer Cup in 1948-50, and 1954 . The Wolcott Memorial Golf Tournament was named in his honor. He rejoined the Wolcott Society in 1946 as member #321, residing at Trenton, New Jersey.
(9) Mary Pauline Wolcott (Fremont Charles Wolcott8, Alfred Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUN 1895 Boston, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
(7) Josiah Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 FEB 1814 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 MAR 1828 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio.
(7) Darius Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 DEC 1816 Boston Township, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 29 AUG 1894 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio.
NotesDARIUS and Sophia were at Thompson, Ohio, in 1870. He was appointed a Justice of the Peace at Thompson in 1873. He was a farmer at Thompson, Ohio, in 1880. Buried with him and his wife at Maple Grove Cemetery was Minnie Wolcott, possibly a daughter.
m. 30 APR 1841 , Lorain Co., Ohio, Sophia Simpson , b. 1819 ,, New York, d. 1 OCT 1890 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio.
2 children: Mary, Addie.
(8) Mary Wolcott (Darius Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1843 ,, Ohio, d. .
m. 14 AUG 1862 , Ashtabula Co., Ohio, Hiram Sanders , b. , d. .
(8) Addie Wolcott (Darius Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1849 ,, Ohio, d. 30 JAN 1924 .
m. 11 MAR 1869 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio, Rufus Hurlburt , b. 1845 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio, d. 10 JUN 1928 .
3 children: Hoyt W., Wade Oakley, John R..
(9) Hoyt W. Hurlburt (Addie Wolcott8, Darius Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 DEC 1870 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesHOYTH was at Thompson, Ohio, 1910-20.
(9) Wade Oakley Hurlbert (Addie Wolcott8, Darius Wolcott7, Alfred Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 OCT 1876 Thompson, Geauga Co., Ohio, d. 12 JAN 1959 .

(6) Parmenio Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 DEC 1770 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. ,, New York.
NotesPARMENIO Wolcott, Jr., of Cayuga County, served as ensign in Capt. Ellis' Co., New York militia, in 1810-1812. He was later a farmer at Yorkshire, Cattaraugus Co., New York. In 1840 he moved to Michigan, buying land in Washtenaw and Barry Counties, and living in Washtenaw County. He later returned to New York and resided with his son, Alfred.
m. 9 AUG 1798 Westmoreland, Oneida Co., New York, Anna "Annie" Fulkerson , b. 1779 Freehold, Monmouth Co., New Jersey, d. 24 JUL 1874 Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan.
8 children: Lydia, Laura, Littoria, Alfred, Henry "Harry", Parmenio, Samuel B., Clarinda Matilda.

m. DEC 1819 Nicholas Rowe , b. 8 NOV 1778 , Dutchess Co., New York, d. 11 OCT 1841 , Washtenaw Co., Michigan.

m. 29 NOV 1821 Worcester, Otsego Co., New York, Stephen Vanrensselaer Freeman , b. 25 APR 1801 Albany, Albany Co., New York, d. 10 MAR 1877 LaGrange, Lorain Co., Ohio.
10 children: Parmenio Vanrensselaer, Lydia Ann, Dorliska J., George E., Coroden W., Ellen M., Stephen E., Laura Seville, Susan Dorliska, Casius M..

(8) Susan Dorliska Freeman (Laura Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JAN 1844 , d. 4 MAR 1927 Lorain, Lorain Co., Ohio.
m. 16 SEP 1871 Alexander Porter , b. 16 MAR 1843 Lorain, Lorain Co., Ohio, d. 4 JAN 1919 .
(8) Casius M. Freeman (Laura Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 MAR 1847 , d. 25 DEC 1848 .
(7) Littoria Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 FEB 1804 ,, New York, d. .
m. 19 DEC 1829 Henry Allen , b. , d. .
(7) Alfred Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 JUN 1806 , Tompkins Co., New York, d. LaGrange, Lorain Co., Ohio.
NotesALFRED moved from Tompkins County, New York, to Erie County in 1840, where he had a hotel and a farm. He then had a hotel at Cattaraugus county, New York, for 10 years. He was a farmer at Prairieville, Michigan, in 1850. He was a farmer at Orangeville, Michigan, in 1860, with Mary and Anna, his mother. He was at Prairieville, Michigan in 1870 with Mary H. and Anne. He moved to join his son, William, at La Grange and in 1880 was farming at LaGrange, Ohio.
m. 20 MAR 1834 Mary Henrietta Ledoyt , b. 1834 ,, Connecticut, d. .
1 children: William Franklin.
(8) William Franklin Wolcott (Alfred Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JAN 1835 LaGrange, Lorain Co., Ohio, d. 9 APR 1922 LaGrange, Lorain Co., Ohio.
NotesWILLIAM came to Lorain Co., Ohio, at age 18 and settled at La Grange . About 1859 went to Michigan but didn't like it there and returned to Ohio. He was at Orangeville, Ohio, in 1860, with Melissa and Lewis. He enlisted 25 Aug. 1864 in Btry E, 1st Ohio Lt. Arty. Regt., discharged 10 July 1865. After the war he purchased a hotel which he ran for 10 years. He was at La Grange, Ohio, in 1870 with Melissa, Lewis, and Mary E. Woolcott. He was then a travelling salesman for lightning rods for 5 years. He was a laborer at La Grange, Ohio, in 1880. He was appointed justice of the Peace in 1888. He served as postmaster 1898-1908, and Mayor of LaGrange for 12 years, also city councilman and constable. W. F. Wolcott of LaGrange, Ohio, attended the 1909 Wolcott reunion at Niagara Falls, and was a member in 1914.

William F Wolcott
Birth Date: 15 Jan 1835
Spouse: Malissa Hastings
Marriage Date: 22 Feb 1857
Parents: Alfred and Mary Henrietta Ledoyt
Notes: Civil War Veteran

In the 1840s he and his brother, Samuel, settled in White Oak Twp. Ingham Co., Michigan. They were on the tax rolls there in 1844.

(7) Parmenio Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 JUL 1813 ,, New York, d. Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan.
NotesPARMENIO was a farmer. In the 1830's he and his brother, Henry, moved to Washtenaw Co., Michigan. In 1837 Parmenio Wolcott Jr. of Washtenaw Co., Michigan, bought 80 acres of federal land in Washtenaw Co.. In the 1840's he settled in Barry Co., Michigan. He was a farmer at Orangeville, Michigan, in 1850 with Azina and Alfred Woolcott. He was living in Michigan in 1863. In 1860 he was a farmer at Orangeville, Barry Co., Michigan, with Alzina L. and Jerome.
m. 15 JAN 1841 , Jackson Co., Michigan, Alzina L. Turner , b. 1816 ,, New York, d. .
1 children: Alfred Jerome "Jerome".

NotesALFRED was a physician.
m. 17 SEP 1868 , Mc Henry Co., Illinois, Anna W. Knapp , b. Bedford, Westchester Co., New York, d. .
2 children: Constance Mary, Jo.

(9) Jo Wolcott (Alfred Jerome "Jerome" Wolcott8, Parmenio Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. 1971 .
(7) Samuel B. Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUL 1815 ,, New York, d. 16 SEP 1870 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan.
NotesSAMUEL and his brother, Henry, were among the earliest settlers in White Oak Township, Ingham Co., Michigan. They were on a tax list there in 1844. He was a farmer at Sharon, Washtenaw Co. from 1850 to 1870. In 1860 he was with Marian, Frances, Marian, and Venning.
m. 24 FEB 1849 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan, Maria Ellen Matthews , b. 1829 ,, Michigan, d. ABT 1861 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan.
3 children: Frances, Florence, Venning Dodge,
