(9) Jennie Gillette (Florence Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1877 Tecumseh, Lenawee Co., Michigan, d. .
(8) Venning Dodge Wolcott (Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 SEP 1860 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan, d. 31 JUL 1929 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa.
NotesVENNING moved from Michigan to Iowa about 1880. He was at Ida, Iowa, in 1885, with Hattie and Fred Wolcott. He owned the Maple Grove Stock Farm. "His farm comprised 155 acres in the vicinity of Battle Creek, Iowa. His house was a story and a half with an L, and he had two barns. Mr. Wolcott made a specialty of fine horses and secured the best breeds of draft horses. His French Draft, "Captain", a black Percheron, weighed 1,850 pounds, and his French coach was a bay of good style and action." He is buried in the same cemetery with Mabel E. Wolcott 1873-1961, and


Birth: Sep. 16, 1860
Death: Jul. 31, 1929

Venning Dodge Wolcott was born in Sharon, Michigan, Sept. 16. 1860, to Samuel and Maria (Matthews) Wolcott, and died in Battle Creek, Iowa, on July 31, 1929, aged 68 years, 10 months, and 15 days.

On April 9, 1880, he came to Battle Creek and continued this residence here for the past 50 years with the exception of 2 years 1895-6 which he spent in Harrison County, Iowa. It was here that he was married to Mabel F. Lawrence of Magnolia, Iowa, on Dec. 2, 1896.

Mr. Wolcott had been ill many years with kidney trouble. Several years ago one kidney had to be removed, but relief was very temporary as his health had been poor ever since.

He was a member of Perserverance Lodge No. 446, A.F. and A.M. Benevolence Chaper No. 336, O.F.S. Sioux City Consistory Chaptr No 5, Scottish Rite Masons and Abu Bekr Temple of Masonic Order, and was faithful to his duties in order.

Mr. Wolcott owned a farm here which was later made into town lots and residences built and has helped make the town.

Funeral Services were held at the Presbyterian Church Friday, August 2, at 2:30 with Rev. Claude Fausnaugh officiating. Burial was in the Mt. Hope Cemetery, Battle Creek.

Survivors include his widow and 4 children, Fred C. of Audubon, Iowa; D. W. Eugene and Gary of Des Moines, Iowa; and Mrs. Lucille Modrell of Battle Creek, and a host of friends.

Burial:
Mount Hope Cemetery
Battle Creek
Ida County
Iowa, USA
m. 1879 , Ingham Co., Michigan, Harriet J. "Hattie" Teel , b. , d. .
4 children: Fred W., Fred Charlie, W. Eugene "Gene", Gene.
(9) Fred W. Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1879 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan, d. .
(9) Fred Charlie Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JAN 1883 , d. .
Notes1918 Draft Registration:
Fred Charley Wolcott 35, b. 21 Jan 1883 , Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa, farmer, wife Ossie Wolcott, medium height and build, blue eyes, dark hair.

1920 Maple IA
Fred C Wolcott 28, b. IA, farm labor
Ocia H Wolcott 25, b. IA
Leonard E Wolcott 3, b. IA
Hazel G Wolcott 1 6/12
(9) W. Eugene "Gene" Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 AUG 1881 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa, d. 3 SEP 1952 Council Bluffs, Pottawattamie Co., Iowa.
NotesEUGENE served at a 1st Lt. in World War I. He received his MD degree from the University of Iowa. In 1928 he established a medical practice in Des Moines. He retired from medical practice and did research at the University of Virginia. He organized a home for crippled children.
(9) Gene Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Venning Dodge Wolcott (Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 SEP 1860 Sharon, Washtenaw Co., Michigan, d. 31 JUL 1929 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa.
NotesVENNING moved from Michigan to Iowa about 1880. He was at Ida, Iowa, in 1885, with Hattie and Fred Wolcott. He owned the Maple Grove Stock Farm. "His farm comprised 155 acres in the vicinity of Battle Creek, Iowa. His house was a story and a half with an L, and he had two barns. Mr. Wolcott made a specialty of fine horses and secured the best breeds of draft horses. His French Draft, "Captain", a black Percheron, weighed 1,850 pounds, and his French coach was a bay of good style and action." He is buried in the same cemetery with Mabel E. Wolcott 1873-1961, and


Birth: Sep. 16, 1860
Death: Jul. 31, 1929

Venning Dodge Wolcott was born in Sharon, Michigan, Sept. 16. 1860, to Samuel and Maria (Matthews) Wolcott, and died in Battle Creek, Iowa, on July 31, 1929, aged 68 years, 10 months, and 15 days.

On April 9, 1880, he came to Battle Creek and continued this residence here for the past 50 years with the exception of 2 years 1895-6 which he spent in Harrison County, Iowa. It was here that he was married to Mabel F. Lawrence of Magnolia, Iowa, on Dec. 2, 1896.

Mr. Wolcott had been ill many years with kidney trouble. Several years ago one kidney had to be removed, but relief was very temporary as his health had been poor ever since.

He was a member of Perserverance Lodge No. 446, A.F. and A.M. Benevolence Chaper No. 336, O.F.S. Sioux City Consistory Chaptr No 5, Scottish Rite Masons and Abu Bekr Temple of Masonic Order, and was faithful to his duties in order.

Mr. Wolcott owned a farm here which was later made into town lots and residences built and has helped make the town.

Funeral Services were held at the Presbyterian Church Friday, August 2, at 2:30 with Rev. Claude Fausnaugh officiating. Burial was in the Mt. Hope Cemetery, Battle Creek.

Survivors include his widow and 4 children, Fred C. of Audubon, Iowa; D. W. Eugene and Gary of Des Moines, Iowa; and Mrs. Lucille Modrell of Battle Creek, and a host of friends.

Burial:
Mount Hope Cemetery
Battle Creek
Ida County
Iowa, USA
m. 2 DEC 1896 Magnolia, Harrison Co., Iowa, Mabel Emma Lawrence , b. 18 DEC 1873 Magnolia, Harrison Co., Iowa, d. 23 AUG 1961 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa.
2 children: Lucille June, Gary Venning.
(9) Lucille June Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JUN 1900 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa, d. 29 AUG 1964 Battle Creek, Ida Co., Iowa.
NotesLucille June (Wolcott) Modrell, daughter of W.D. and Mabel Lawrence Wolcott, was born at Battle Creek, Iowa, June 29, 1900, and passed away Aug. 27, 1964.

She graduated from Battle Creek High School in 1918, was a student at Morningside College, and became a rural school teacher.

She married John Samuel Modrell Feb. 14, 1923. They had 2 children, Delores and John Modrell, Jr.

Preceding her in death was one son, as an infant in 1931.
(9) Gary Venning Wolcott (Venning Dodge Wolcott8, Samuel B. Wolcott7, Parmenio Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUL 1902 ,, Iowa, d. 20 OCT 1994 Onawa, Monona Co., Iowa.
NotesGARY was at Des Moines, Iowa, in 1930.

(6) Josiah Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 APR 1776 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 27 AUG 1797 Rome, Oneida Co., New York.
(6) Mary "Polly" Wolcott (Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 OCT 1778 Rome, Oneida Co., New York, d. 27 JAN 1856 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
m. 17 DEC 1802 Nathan Stone , b. 14 OCT 1780 Brimfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 APR 1851 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
8 children: Hadassah, Melissa, Josiah Wolcott, Hadassah, Almira, Alphonso, Emily A., Vernon Thompson.
(7) Hadassah Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 SEP 1803 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 25 NOV 1806 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(7) Melissa Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 DEC 1805 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 5 JUL 1883 .
m. APR 1835 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, David Corey , b. 14 MAY 1798 , d. 16 AUG 1874 .
3 children: David Brainerd, Benjamin, Nathan Stone.
(8) David Brainerd Corey (Melissa Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 SEP 1837 , d. 9 JAN 1877 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesDavid B. Corey was a partner of Augustus H. Bennett until he died an untimely death in 1877.
m. Frances M. Benedict , b. 17 JUN 1844 , d. 11 MAY 1917 .
(8) Benjamin Corey (Melissa Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 SEP 1839 , d. 8 MAR 1843 .
(8) Nathan Stone Corey (Melissa Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 MAR 1845 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 29 MAY 1885 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(7) Josiah Wolcott Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 OCT 1807 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 10 MAY 1877 Glen Haven, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesJOSIAH was a wagon maker, foundry worker and furnace maker. His obituary says his early years spent on his father's farm east of Homer. He learned wagon manufacturing from Mr. David Coye. Then he removed to Phelps, Ontario Co. where he resided 2 or 3 years. Immediately after his marriage in 1835, he returned to Homer and went into business with Mr. Coye and lived on Pine St. In 1838 removed to Moravia where he stayed until spring of 1853, when he returned to Homer and went into the foundry business with his brother Alphonso until 1872. He joined the Homer Congregational church in 1856. In 1873 he built a house on Main St. He was trustee of the First Religious Society of Homer.
m. FEB 1835 ,, New York, Elizabeth Ringer , b. 1816 , Ontario Co., New York, d. 21 JAN 1857 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(7) Josiah Wolcott Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 OCT 1807 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 10 MAY 1877 Glen Haven, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesJOSIAH was a wagon maker, foundry worker and furnace maker. His obituary says his early years spent on his father's farm east of Homer. He learned wagon manufacturing from Mr. David Coye. Then he removed to Phelps, Ontario Co. where he resided 2 or 3 years. Immediately after his marriage in 1835, he returned to Homer and went into business with Mr. Coye and lived on Pine St. In 1838 removed to Moravia where he stayed until spring of 1853, when he returned to Homer and went into the foundry business with his brother Alphonso until 1872. He joined the Homer Congregational church in 1856. In 1873 he built a house on Main St. He was trustee of the First Religious Society of Homer.
m. 2 FEB 1859 Marie Antoninette Whitney , b. 1824 , d. 28 AUG 1907 Syracuse, Onondaga Co., New York.
1 children: Mary Elizabeth.

NotesHadassah was a school teacher in Dist. No. 10. She never married.
(7) Almira Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 MAR 1815 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 3 NOV 1879 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesALMIRA and her brothers, Josiah and Vernon, were charter member of the Congregational Church at Homer in 185.
m. 5 APR 1837 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, Lorenzo Bennett , b. 19 MAR 1812 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 9 JUL 1891 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
4 children: Cleora Melissa, Augustus Henry, Mary Hadassah, Edward Lorenzo.
(8) Cleora Melissa Bennett (Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 APR 1838 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 2 DEC 1906 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesCleora Melissa Bennett was a graduate of Homer Academy in 1857. She belonged to the Congregational Church. She and her husband had no children of their own but many of her nieces and cousins used to stay with them, especially during summer vacations. She was "Aunt Coe" to the family.
m. 22 MAY 1862 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, Porter C. Kingsbury , b. 8 JUL 1833 , d. 17 MAR 1910 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(8) Augustus Henry Bennett (Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 APR 1840 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 25 MAY 1904 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesAUGUSTUS was a merchant and President of the Homer Bank. He was Treasurer of the Homer Village, and a member of the school board there.
m. 27 JUN 1866 Albany, Albany Co., New York, Emma Gertrude Pratt , b. 20 SEP 1843 Pratts Hollow, Madison Co., New York, d. 5 JUN 1911 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
5 children: Adeline Castle, Lester Pratt, Edward Lorenzo, Frederick Vernon, Ralph Stone.
(9) Adeline Castle Bennett (Augustus Henry Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 DEC 1867 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 10 MAY 1942 San Diego, San Diego Co., California.
(9) Lester Pratt Bennett (Augustus Henry Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 JAN 1870 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 9 JUN 1930 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(9) Edward Lorenzo Bennett (Augustus Henry Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 JAN 1872 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 25 AUG 1872 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
(9) Frederick Vernon Bennett (Augustus Henry Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 MAY 1873 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 1 NOV 1952 West Palm Beach, Palm Beach Co., Florida.
NotesThe Bennett family moved to Minnesota to run the Eckenberg Company. The company made Teko Pancake Flour and malted milk and was later sold to Borden Company. Fred was in Palm Beach on vacation when he was involved in a fatal accident.
(9) Ralph Stone Bennett (Augustus Henry Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 OCT 1880 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 15 SEP 1956 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.

(9) Benjamin Robert Johnson (Mary Hadassah Bennett8, Almira Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 DEC 1874 Albany, Albany Co., New York, d. 9 MAY 1952 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesBenjamin was a Patent lawyer in Washington, DC and never married.

NotesAlphonso, for many years operated the Stone foundry on South Main Street, inconjunction with his sons, C.C. & L.A. Stone.

m. 27 JUN 1887 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, Anna Staats , b. ABT 1860 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 3 JAN 1927 .
(8) Eliott L. Stone (Alphonso Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1857 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 18 MAY 1933 Auburn, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesElliott was a lawyer. He resided in Syracuse, New York for 20 years after leaving Homer, New York. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1915, residing at Syracuse.
(8) Florence Stone (Alphonso Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1859 ,, New York, d. 1859 ,, New York.
(8) Frank Eugene Stone (Alphonso Stone7, Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ,, New York, d. 20 SEP 1933 Skaneateles, Cayuga Co., New York.
NotesFRANK was a lawyer at Skaneateles. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1915 residing at Skaneateles.
(7) Emily A. Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1824 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 2 AUG 1903 .
(7) Vernon Thompson Stone (Mary "Polly" Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 FEB 1824 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 12 DEC 1900 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
NotesVernon Thompson Stone was born on the farm east of Homervillage on Feb 6, 1824. He was educated at Cortland Academy and spent his entire live in Homer with the exception of two years spent in Hamilton, Canada and two years in Aurora, Illionis. He was married July 20, 1847 to Miss Emily Eliott. He was engaged in the mercantile business for some years with George J.J. Barber and C.O. Newton and also in the manufacture of wagons and other business enterprises. He was VP of Homer National Bank from its organization. He served as supervisor of Homer, superintendant of the poor from 1887-1890, village trustee, etc. He was a member of the board of education of Homer Academy. He was a member of the Congregational Church of Homer.
Vernon Stone's will contains the following information: "Vernon T. Stone of Homer gives to Glenwood Cemetery $150 in trust for care for his lot. To Mrs. Jennetta Cutway, niece of my wife Emily, of Tonawanda, Erie Co. NY $5 00. Remainder to wife Emily A. Stone for her life. After death of wife he gives to daughter Lottie M. Schermerhorn of Homer $5000 and remainder of his personal estate. If she is not living, the $5000 to go to adopted daughter. After deaths of wife and adopted daughter, gives to nephew Charles L. Stone of Homer $500 and residue of personal estate. To nephew Agustus H. Bennett and to nephew Eliot L. Stone of Homer and to niece May E. Van Hoesen, wife of Arthur Van Hoesen of Syracuse, NY. If Augustus Bennett not living, then to Lester P. Bennett and Frederick V. Bennett sons of Augustus. Wife Emily A. Stone and Augustus H. Bennett executors. After death of wife, adopted daugther, Dottie M. Schermerhorn in place of wife." 6 Jan 1899. Wit: S.S. Knox and Charles F. Brown residents of Cortland, NY. Codicil. Revokes bequest to Jennie Cutway. 3 Nov 1899. Wit: S.S. Knox and L.P. Hollenbeck of Cortland, NY.
m. 20 AUG 1847 Emily A. Elliott , b. 16 OCT 1823 ,, New York, d. 2 AUG 1903 Homer, Cortland Co., New York.
2 children: Charlotte M. "Lottie", Frederick B..

NotesWOLCOTT is described in the announcement of his wedding as "heir to a considerable fortune. He is a Polo enthusiast and acted as host to the Prince of Wales when the latter visited Chicago a year ago". In 1930, Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair were living at the Ritz Tower, in New York City and were listed in the Social Register.

(7) Henry Keep (Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 OCT 1820 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 4 MAY 1897 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesHENRY graduated from Union College in Schenectady, New York in 1839, and practiced law for several years. He was a partner with Philander Peck and Albert Keep in a dry goods business in Whitewater, Wiscosin. Im 1851 he opened a similar business in Chicago, called Peck, Keep & Co.

NotesCHARLES graduated from Harvard University in 1882 and the law school in 1885. He served as a Assistant Secretary of Treasury under President Theodore Roosevelt from 1903-1907.

NotesWALLACE graduated from Harvard University in 1884.
m. 5 DEC 1894 Kate F. Ransom , b. , d. 27 MAY 1960 .
1 children: Katharine.
(9) Katharine Keep (Wallace Irving Keep8, Charles Keep7, Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 APR 1897 , d. .
(8) Roger Wolcott Keep (Charles Keep7, Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 OCT 1865 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 5 JUN 1897 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York.
NotesROGER graduated from Harvard University in 1887. Ten years later after extensive travel, both here and abroad, he took his own life with a shot throught the heart.
(7) Albert Keep (Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 APR 1826 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 1908 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALBERT came from Fredonia to Whitewater with his brother, Henry, in 1847. He formed a parnership with Philander Keep to operate a retail business. In 1851 Peek & Keep entered the wholsale dry goods trade at Chicago. In 1856 Albert turned to real estate, and was hired to secure a right of way through Chicago for the Chicago & Nothwestern Railroad. He became a director of the railroad in 1865, and became President of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad in 1883.
m. 6 APR 1853 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Susan A. Williams , b. , d. 29 NOV 1859 .
(7) Albert Keep (Prudence Wolcott6, Parmenio Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 APR 1826 Homer, Cortland Co., New York, d. 1908 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALBERT came from Fredonia to Whitewater with his brother, Henry, in 1847. He formed a parnership with Philander Keep to operate a retail business. In 1851 Peek & Keep entered the wholsale dry goods trade at Chicago. In 1856 Albert turned to real estate, and was hired to secure a right of way through Chicago for the Chicago & Nothwestern Railroad. He became a director of the railroad in 1865, and became President of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad in 1883.

m. 30 MAY 1771 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Marvin Lord , b. 19 JUL 1748 Lyme, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 2 MAY 1801 Lyme, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
9 children: Roger Wolcott, Emelia, Sophas, Marvin, Mary, Marvin, Ursula, Betsey, Tryphena.
(6) Roger Wolcott Lord (Amelia Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 JAN 1778 Lyme, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesROGER came from New London, Connecticut to Carlisle, New York, where he purchased a farm. He opened an inn and tavern in 1804. He married a grandaughter of Gov. Roger Sherman. "But the loss of property and love of ardent spirits brought him down to poverty in a few years, and he became dependant upon his four sisters, who followed him in a short time and established themselves as milliners, the first in town.... hen the shop was dull they taught school and gave lessons in fancy work, and were active in church work.

John L. Lord, age 55, was at Schoharie in 1855
m. Sherman , b. , d. .

NotesBERTHA Dean of Auburn New York, joined the Wolcott Society in 1915. She attended the Syracuse reunion with a cousin. She rejoined in 1976 as member #1043, residing at Auburn, New York.

(6) Betsey Lord (Amelia Wolcott5, Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 AUG 1794 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .

(5) Martha Wolcott (Roger Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 APR 1753 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 MAY 1753 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(4) Roger Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1704 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 OCT 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived in South Windsor, his property adjoining that of his uncle, Henry. He was a Representative for Windsor at the General Assembly, a Major in the Connecticut militia, a member of the Council, and Judge of the Hartford County Court and the Superior Court of Connecticut. Roger was one of those appointed to revise the laws of the Connecticut Colony, and was one of three commissioners appointed by the Colony of Connecticut to meet at Albany in 1745 with representatives of other colonies, to discuss a plan for union. He was one of the subscribers to the Susquehanna Land Company in 1753.
m. 19 JUN 1759 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Eunice Colton , b. 22 FEB 1706 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 29 MAR 1778 Bolton, Worcester Co., Massachusetts.
(4) Elizabeth Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 APR 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 JUL 1775 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesELIZABETH received a pension from the British government for her husband's military service. It was paid in merchandise, which she sold from her home at Wintonbury, now Bloomfield. Her account books and scales used in this mercantile business for 1739 to 1741 were in the possession of her great-grandson. Oliver Dwight Filley of Bloomfield.
m. 27 AUG 1727 Roger Newberry , b. 4 JUN 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAY 1741 ,, Cuba.
7 children: Elizabeth, Hannah, Abigail, Roger, Sarah, Benjamin, Thomas.

NotesSIDNEY died from the effects of privations as a prisoner in Andersonville prison during the Civil War.

(8) Samuel Strong Hayden (Wealthy Haskell7, Elizabeth Bissell6, Elizabeth Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 OCT 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 APR 1863 Irish Bend, St. Mary Parish, Louisiana.
NotesSAMUEL joined the militia at age 18, rose to the rank of Major of the 1st Regiment at age 49. He secured the raising of a company from Windsor, Company C, 25th Regual Connecticut Volunteers, at which he was in command when repelling a rebel charge with the words on his lips "Dont' run borys" when he was killed.

m. 18 JAN 1770 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Russell , b. 23 JUL 1725 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1775 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Roger Newberry (Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.
m. 9 JAN 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hannah Allyn , b. ABT 1740 , d. 23 FEB 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Roger Newberry (Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.

(8) Henry Strong Newberry (Henry Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 NOV 1850 , d. .
m. 12 OCT 1876 Elizabeth Schuyler Britton , b. 20 JAN 1855 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
1 children: Elizabeth.
(9) Elizabeth Newberry (Henry Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 OCT 1881 , d. .
(7) John Strong Newberry (Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 DEC 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesJOHN graduated from Western Reserve College in 1846 and received his M.D. from the Cleveland Medical College in 1848. He was in Europe in 1849/1850 and commenced the practice of medicine in 1851. In May 1855 he was appointed by the U.S. War Department as Surgeon and Geologist of Williamson's Expedition for the exploration of Northern California and Oregon, which took the next six years. He was then appointed to the Ives Expedition to Southern California and New Mexico. In 1861 he was appointed Secretary of the Western Department, U.S. Sanitary Commission. John was appointed Professor of Geology and Paleontology in the School of Mines, Columbia College, New York City. In 1860 he was appointed Chief of the Ohio State Geological Survey; was President of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1867-1889. He was President of the Torrey Botanical Club, 1886-1889; was an original incorporator of the National Academy of Sciences, and was President of the American Association for the Advacement of Science.
m. 12 OCT 1848 Sarah Brownell Gaylord , b. 16 DEC 1823 Madison, Madison Co., New York, d. .
7 children: Cleveland Gaylord, Arthur St. John, Spencer Baird, Elizabeth Strong, Wolcott Ely, Robert Thorne, William Belknap.
(8) Cleveland Gaylord Newberry (John Strong Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 JAN 1851 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 10 FEB 1882 Corralitos,, Mexico.
NotesCleveland received his M.D. from Cleveland Medical College in 1875.

NotesArthur graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1872; received a B.A. from Harvard College in 1976 and was admitted to the Ohio bar in 1878.

(9) Winifred Eelis Newberry (Arthur St. John Newberry8, John Strong Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 SEP 1881 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) John Strong Newberry (Arthur St. John Newberry8, John Strong Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 APR 1883 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Mary Witt Newberry (Arthur St. John Newberry8, John Strong Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JUN 1885 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(8) Spencer Baird Newberry (John Strong Newberry7, Henry Newberry6, Roger Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 MAY 1857 , d. .
NotesSpencer received a M.E. from the School of Mines, Columbia College, New York City in 1878 and a Ph.D. in 1879. He studied at the University of Berlin, 1879-1880; Paris, 1880-1881; was assistant in chemistry, Cornell University, 1 November 1881 and Professor of chemistry and mineral in 1882. He was U.S. Commissioner to the Paris Exposition in 1889. His wifes father, was the President of Cornell University and the U.S. Minister to Germany. Source #70, Vol. II, page 532-533.

(8) Harriet E. Olcott (Frances Olcott7, Sarah Mather6, Sarah Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 NOV 1827 Windsor Locks, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 20 FEB 1862 .
(8) Asahel E. Olcott (Frances Olcott7, Sarah Mather6, Sarah Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 NOV 1831 Windsor Locks, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1886 .
(8) William Henry Olcott (Frances Olcott7, Sarah Mather6, Sarah Newberry5, Elizabeth Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 MAR 1834 , d. 22 MAY 1888 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
NotesWilliam graduated from Yale in 1859, studied medicine and surgery in Northampton and Pittsfield, Massachusetts, and with Dr. Valentine Mott, New York city. He settled in Brooklyn; was assistant surgeon for the 173rd New York Regiment last in the Civil War and had charge of hospitals at Baton Rouge, Louisiana. He served through the war and was breveted Lt. Col. for meritorious service.

NotesALEXANDER was killed by a cart wheel.
(4) Samuel Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JAN 1710 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 DEC 1717 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(4) Alexander Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 4 DEC 1732 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lydia Roswell Atwater , b. 18 OCT 1715 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 JAN 1776 Cromwell, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
3 children: Jeremiah, Alexander, Lydia.
(5) Jeremiah Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 NOV 1733 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAY 1792 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesJEREMIAH was a physician at Branford, Connecticut. He may have been the Jeremiah Woolcott who served during the Revolutionary War. In 1773 Sarah Wolcott of Branford obtained a divorce from him

4 children: William R, Frederick Ferdinand, Henry Augustus, George Edward.
(8) William R Street (Martha Davenport Wolcott Reynolds7, Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 JUL 1828 , d. .
m. Elizabeth T. Upson , b. , d. .
(8) Frederick Ferdinand Street (Martha Davenport Wolcott Reynolds7, Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JAN 1830 Cheshire, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1921 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK F. Street of Hartford was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-16. He and his wife entertained in their home at Hartford those attending the 1913 reunion at Hartford. In 1919 he reported that the apple trees planted by Henry Wolcott were still alive, but "only here and there a limb showing foliage and occasionally some fruit." He said that the Wolcott homestead was then owned by the Loomis School. In 1920 he made a donation of $100 to the fund to restore the Old State House at Hartford in the name of the Henry Wolcott family.

NotesHENRY changed his surname from Street.

(8) Wolcott Reynolds Harrison (Sarah Goodsell Reynolds7, Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 MAY 1822 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 16 JUL 1885 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesWOLCOTT travelled extensively up and down the East coast of the United States. He kept a journal of his travels from 1841 to 1844 which was published in a 306 page volume.

1 children: Pauline M..
(9) Pauline M. Harrison (Wolcott Reynolds Harrison8, Sarah Goodsell Reynolds7, Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 JAN 1849 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .

m. Margaret Belden , b. , d. .
1 children: Lovell "Birge".
(9) Lovell "Birge" Harrison (Appollos Wolcott Harrison8, Sarah Goodsell Reynolds7, Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 OCT 1854 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
NotesBIRGE was a artist. His line descend from Thomas Harrison, who was Major General to Oliver Cromwell, signed the death warrant of King Charles I of England, and conducted him to the scaffold; and whose son, Thomas, emigrated from England in 1640 and settle at Branford, Connecticut.

Birge was educated at the private academies of Philadelphia; went to Paris in 1875 and studied painting in the Ecole des beaus arts, under Alexandre Cabanel. He made trip around the world, painting in Australia, the South Seas, California and among the American Indians, 1889-1893. H was elected a member of the Society of American Artist, and received a silver medal at the Exposition Universal in 1889 and a unique medal from the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893.
(7) Thomas Goodsell Reynolds (Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 MAR 1798 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 26 SEP 1826 .
(7) William Augustus Reynolds (Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 APR 1800 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesWILLIAM was a merchant and broker at New Haven.
m. New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Jane Lynde , b. , d. .
(7) Beverly Reynolds (Martha Davenport Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 NOV 1806 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 5 NOV 1807 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
(6) Thomas Goodsell Wolcott (Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 AUG 1764 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 22 JAN 1847 New York City, New York.
NotesTHOMAS was expelled from Yale College in his Junior year for participating in a serious disorder and was not admitted to a degree until a year after his class had graduated. He received a BA from Yale College in 1783. He was a member of "Brothers in Unity", a Yale fraternity which maintained a library and reading room at Yale. . In 1790 he was at North Haven, Connecticut, with a family of 1 male over 16 and 3 females. He was teaching school at North Branford in 1792. In 1840 he was at New York City. He died in the Alms House at New York City.
m. 27 MAY 1789 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lucy Hoffman , b. 5 FEB 1769 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1830 .
6 children: Sarah Goodsell, Nancy Green, Eliza, Alexander, Martha Davenport, Lucretia.
(7) Sarah Goodsell Wolcott (Thomas Goodsell Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 MAR 1790 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1822 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesSARAH wrote poetry and played the guitar. Her sister, Eliza, wrote "The Two Sisters, Poems and Memories", published by Baldway & Stradway, New Haven, 1830, containing many of Sarah's poems. She and her husband moved to Southwick, Massachusetts after their marriage. After his death she returned to her parents' home with her son and had a school.

(9) Nellie Harrison (John Davenport Harrison8, Jeremiah W. Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1875 Springfield, Greene Co., Missouri, d. 3 FEB 1956 Kansas City, Jackson Co., Missouri.

m. Charlotte Lynde , b. 1813 ,, Connecticut, d. .
6 children: Hart Lynde "Lynde", Janet Shepherd, Henry N., Ella Louisa, Eleanore Florence, Arthur W..
(8) Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison (James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1837 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesLYNDE graduated from Yale Law School in 1860. He was a lawyer in New Haven, Connecticut starting in 1863. He was clerk of the Connecticut House of Representative and Senate in 1862, 1863 and 1864 and was elected as a Republican to the Connecticut state senate in 1865 and 1866. He served as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps, 27th Connecticut Regt., during the Civil War. From 1874 until 1877 he was the representative from Guilford and was Speaker of the lower house in 1877. He was a judge of the city court and then Judge of the New Haven County Court of Common Pleas. He delivered an oration at the 1889 Gettysburg Battlefield reunion.
m. 2 MAY 1867 ,, Connecticut, Sarah Plant , b. Of Branford,, Connecticut, d. MAR 1879 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
2 children: William Lynde "Willie", Paul.
(9) William Lynde "Willie" Harrison (Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison8, James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1868 ,, Connecticut, d. .
(9) Paul Harrison (Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison8, James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1871 ,, Connecticut, d. .
(8) Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison (James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1837 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesLYNDE graduated from Yale Law School in 1860. He was a lawyer in New Haven, Connecticut starting in 1863. He was clerk of the Connecticut House of Representative and Senate in 1862, 1863 and 1864 and was elected as a Republican to the Connecticut state senate in 1865 and 1866. He served as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps, 27th Connecticut Regt., during the Civil War. From 1874 until 1877 he was the representative from Guilford and was Speaker of the lower house in 1877. He was a judge of the city court and then Judge of the New Haven County Court of Common Pleas. He delivered an oration at the 1889 Gettysburg Battlefield reunion.
m. 30 SEP 1886 Harriet S. White , b. Of Waterbury,, Connecticut, d. .
(8) Janet Shepherd Harrison (James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 MAR 1840 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesJANET studied art with Louis Bail in New Haven and with her husband-to-be in Rome, Paris and Venice. She was elected an associate of the National Academy of Design in 1875 and in 1901 was one of three women on the list of associated national academicians. She became well known as a painter of portraits and regular exhibitor at the academy. "Baby Belle"; "Little Runaway"; "Bouguet for Mamma" are named as especially noteworthy.
m. 1865 Henry Augustus Loop , b. Of New York City, New York, d. .
(8) Henry N. Harrison (James Harrison7, Sarah Wolcott6, Jeremiah Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1848 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1880 .
NotesHENRY N. Harrison was a bookeeper at New Haven, Connecticut, in 1880.

NotesALEXANDER was killed in the French-Indian War while serving under his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott.

m. 6 DEC 1759 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Samuel Austin , b. 3 APR 1734 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 25 JAN 1790 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
3 children: Samuel, William, Lydia.
(6) Samuel Austin (Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 OCT 1760 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 4 DEC 1830 Worcester, Worcester Co., Massachusetts.
NotesSamuel graduated from Yale University in 1783, and was President of the University of Vermont.
m. 14 SEP 1788 Jerusha Hopkins , b. 1767 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .
(6) William Austin (Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 SEP 1762 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 2 OCT 1822 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesWILLIAM was a Deacon in his church.
m. 6 OCT 1784 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Mary Bellamy , b. 18 APR 1761 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 3 DEC 1841 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
10 children: William, Nathan, David, Lydia, Samuel, Samuel, Samuel, Nathan, Joseph, Mary.

(6) Lydia Austin (Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 DEC 1764 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 APR 1829 .
NotesLYDIA made a statement at Rockville on 13 Aug, 1842, stating she was born New Haven 9 Dec. 1764, daughter of Samuel Austin and of a daughter of Dr. Alexander Wolcott, that she was under the ministry of Dr. Jonathan Edwards until age 26 at the time of her marriage to Rev. David Hale of Lisbon. In 1804 due to her husband's health he was dismissed and they moved to Coventry. He died in 1822,
m. David Hale , b. 15 DEC 1761 Coventry, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. FEB 1822 ,, Connecticut.
2 children: Laura, David.
(7) Laura Hale (Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1789 , d. .

NotesDAVID was an author.
m. 18 JAN 1815 Canterbury, Windham Co., Connecticut, Laura Hale , b. 29 AUG 1789 , d. 25 JUL 1824 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Richard, David Austin.

(8) David Austin Hale (David Hale7, Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 SEP 1822 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 20 DEC 1892 Aurora, Cayuga Co., New York.
m. 3 SEP 1849 Athol, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, Mary Isabella Simonds , b. 22 NOV 1829 Athol, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 19 JUL 1913 Aurora, Cayuga Co., New York.

(9) William Nelson Hale (David Austin Hale8, David Hale7, Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1850 , d. 1855 .
(9) Charles Warren Hale (David Austin Hale8, David Hale7, Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Mary Agnes Hale (David Austin Hale8, David Hale7, Lydia Austin6, Lydia Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 SEP 1869 Innsbruck,, Austria, d. 14 JUN 1928 Palo Alto, Santa Clara Co., California.
(4) Alexander Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 17 MAR 1739 Mary Mansfield , b. 23 FEB 1707 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1741 .
(4) Alexander Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 3 APR 1745 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Mary Richards , b. 1724 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 23 OCT 1817 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
10 children: Esther, Simon, Esther, George, George, Christopher Drake, Mary, Alexander, Guy, Elizabeth.
(5) Esther Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 SEP 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 OCT 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Simon Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 APR 1809 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.
m. 23 JAN 1774 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Lucy Rogers , b. 1752 , d. 21 APR 1791 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
8 children: Lucretia, Alexander, Lucy, Mary, Lucy, Charlotte, Catherine, Elizabeth.
(6) Lucretia Wolcott (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JAN 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 21 MAR 1823 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
m. 28 OCT 1793 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Richard Law , b. 6 MAR 1763 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 19 OCT 1845 .
1 children: Mary Cecelia.
(7) Mary Cecelia Law (Lucretia Wolcott6, Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 FEB 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 8 APR 1876 .
m. 11 OCT 1832 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Coleby Chew , b. 17 NOV 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 26 NOV 1850 .
(6) Alexander Wolcott (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 NOV 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. at Sea.
NotesALEXANDER died at sea.
m. Joanna Paul , b. , d. .
1 children: Alexander Simon.
(7) Alexander Simon Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott6, Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1805 ,, New York, d. 10 NOV 1844 Stamford, Fairfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER was listed as an artist in New York City in 1841, and was said to have been known for his mechanical ingenuity. He was a pioneer in amateur Deguerreotype photography, working with John Johnson to create a daguerreotype camera in 1839. After the camera was patented in 1840, he traveled to Washington, D. C. and helped Stevenson open a gallery there, and in 1841 went to London to show the invention. The "New York Times" of 28 Jan 1883 stated, "Mr. A. S. Wolcott, who was for a long time in the business of daguerreotyping in this city, and afterwards opened a laboratory in London, really preceded Prof. Draper by several weeks in the application of Daguerre's discovery..., to whom may be ascribed the first image of the human face ever taken by sunlight." The question of whether Wolcott or Draper took the first photograph of a living person was hotly disputed. Alexander purchased property at Stamford, Connecticut, in 1842 and had a rolling mill there. His obituary in the Stamford Advocate reads: "Died in this village on Sunday last, of consumption, Mr. Alexander Simon Wolcott, aged 40 years." His will was probated inthe Stamford, Connecticut, court: "Wolcott, Alexander S., deceased, late of Stamford, Nov. 13 1844, his widow refused to qualify...." This record mentions Cynthia L. Wolcott, age 13, who had Humphrey Phelps of New York City appointed as her guardian. Humphrey Phelps was apparently the one who was a New York City publisher of prints and maps, 1832-53, author of "Pictorial View of the World" published New York City 1847 and "Phelps Travelers' Guides" of various cities which were published beginning in 1838.
m. 1832 Bridgeport, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, Mary Sanborn , b. 10 APR 1809 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire, d. 20 JUL 1895 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire.
1 children: Cynthia Louisa.
(8) Cynthia Louisa Wolcott (Alexander Simon Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1834 Bridgeport, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesCYNTHIA had a guardian, Humphrey Phelps of New York City, appointed for her at age 13 in New York City, having no father or guardian, but owning property at Stamford, Connecticut.

NotesWOLCOTT served in Co. K, 21st Connecticut Regt, during the Civil War.

(8) Charlotte E. Hull (Lucretia Law Hinsdale7, Catherine Wolcott6, Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .

(6) Elizabeth Wolcott (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JAN 1788 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
(5) Simon Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 APR 1809 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.
m. 8 NOV 1798 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Charlotte Woodbridge , b. 26 DEC 1761 , d. 1 DEC 1831 .
1 children: Frances Caroline.
(6) Frances Caroline Wolcott (Simon Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 FEB 1803 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. George Stillman Robbins , b. 25 MAY 1796 Sandisfield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 JAN 1886 .
(5) Esther Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 JUL 1749 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1841 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesESTHER was interested in genealogy, and collected information about the Wolcott family.

NotesGEORGE was a Representative for the town of Windsor at the General Assembly. In 1790, his family at Windsor consisted of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females. He moved to Saybrook, Connecticut, in 1804, where he was Surveyor of the Port.

(8) Henry Lay Bliss (Henry Bliss7, Mary Wolcott6, George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 FEB 1843 ,, New York, d. .
NotesHENRY enlisted in the Union Army during Civil War as a private and afterwards was made a Lieutenant and then Captain, retaining the latter as a title. On June 14, 1870 at Chicago, he was reported to be living in a boarding house and working as a painter.
m. 22 MAY 1873 Laura E. Lane , b. 19 MAY 1850 Wooster, Wayne Co., Ohio, d. .
3 children: William Lane, Henry W., Laura F..
(9) William Lane Bliss (Henry Lay Bliss8, Henry Bliss7, Mary Wolcott6, George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 FEB 1875 La Grange, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 8 MAR 1948 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesWilliam served with an Illinois volunteer regiment during the Spanish-American War under the leadership of the father of the famed General Douglas MacArthur. He then enlisted in the 11th Philippine Veteran Volunteer Calvalry and served in the Camarines of the Philippine archipelago. He received an honorable discharge. He entered the newspaper business and eventually worked for "The Chicago Tribune, The Chicago Inter-Ocean, The Kansas City Post, The Denver Post and The Denver Times". After many evenful years of reporting, he became labor editor for "The Chicago Herald and Examiner", and then edited various other labor newspapers. In 1937, he bacame assistant editor of the VOICE, a labor paper for cement, lime, gypsum and allied workers, a position held until 1947.

(6) William Frederick Wolcott (George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1788 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Agawam, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesWILLIAM was a farmer at West Springfield, Massachusetts, and a Justice of the Peace. In 1860 he was at Agawam, Massachusetts, with children Martha, Hellen, and Alexander.

NotesMARTHA and her sister, Helen, and brother, Alexander, lived together at Agawan, Massachusetts, in 1880, all unmarried.

NotesWILLIAM was a farmer at Agawan, age 38, when he elisted 2 Sept. 1862 as a private in I Co., 46th Massachusetts Inf. Regt.. He wasa farmer at Agawam, Massachusetts, in 1860, with Elizabeth M., Frederick C., and William B. Woolcott.
m. 26 APR 1848 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Elizabeth M. Cooper , b. 1827 ,, Massachusetts, d. .
3 children: Frederick C., William B., William Henry.

NotesHelen was an Army nurse.
(7) Alexander Bryant Wolcott (William Frederick Wolcott6, George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 AUG 1828 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1829 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
(7) Alexander Wolcott (William Frederick Wolcott6, George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 APR 1830 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. JAN 1904 Agawam, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesALEXANDER was a farmer at Agawam, Massachusetts, in 1880. His sisters, Martha and Helen, lived with him.
(6) Elizabeth Wolcott (George Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 NOV 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(5) Christopher Drake Wolcott (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.
m. 1 AUG 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Lucy Parsons , b. 3 AUG 1762 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1804 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
6 children: Laura, Elizabeth, Christopher Columbus, Laura, Elizabeth, Philip.
(6) Laura Wolcott (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 MAY 1783 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 AUG 1789 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Elizabeth Wolcott (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 JAN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 MAY 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Christopher Columbus Wolcott (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1787 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 18 DEC 1853 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER lived at Wolcottville, Connecticut, where he was a Justice of the Peace and Representative to the Connecticut State Legislature. In 1833 he moved to Steubenville, Ohio, where he engaged in woolen manufacturing. He was a visitor at the Steubenville Female Seminary where his daughter, Caroline, was a student, in 1836-7. The 1837 business directory for Beaver Co., Pennsylvania, has at Fallston: "C. C. Wolcott has a large factory for the manufacturing of Jeans upon a very extensive scale with splendid machinery, unsurpassed for excellency and beauty by any in any part of the country." He operated the Fallston factory until 1850 or later.
m. 18 NOV 1818 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Susan Blinn , b. 14 AUG 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 10 APR 1859 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
7 children: Christopher Parsons, Samuel Merwin, Henry Philip "Harry", Frederick Halsey, Susan Maria, Caroline Matilda, Laura Elizabeth.
(7) Christopher Parsons Wolcott (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 DEC 1820 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1863 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER attended Kenyon College in 1839, and graduated from Jefferson College at Washington, Pennsylvania, in 1840 at the age of 20. He read law in the office of Tappan & Stanton. Tappan became U. S. Senator from Ohio, and Edwin Stanton became Secretary of War. Christopher was admitted to the Bar in 1843, and established a law practice at Akron in 1846. He built a large home on West Market St. in Akron, which was destroyed by fire in 1933. He was appointed Attorney-General for the State of Ohio in 1856 and served until 1861. His most famous case was the Wellington Fugitive Slave case. He journied to Virginia to ask Gov. Wise to spare the life of the abolitionist, John Brown, whose home was at Kent, Portage Co., Ohio. He became Judge Advocate General in 1861. In May of 1862 he was appointed Assistant Secretary of War, under his brother-in-law, Edwin Stanton, Secretary of War. He held this position at the time of his death. His brother-in-law often visited his widowed sister at Gambier to rest from his greuling schedule, He was so unobtrusive that the neighbors usually did not know he was there. When his two nephews, Darwin and Merwin, were in College after the war, Stanton spoke affectionately of his college days at Kenyon College from which he received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree..
m. 18 APR 1844 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, Pamphila Stanton , b. 20 FEB 1827 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 8 FEB 1899 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
5 children: Christopher Darwin, Christopher Columbus, Samuel Merwin, William Merwin, Darwin Stanton.
(8) Christopher Darwin Wolcott (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 SEP 1846 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. INFANT .
(8) Christopher Columbus Wolcott (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 SEP 1847 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1899 Vallejo, Solano Co., California.
NotesCHRISTOPHER was a member of the Founders and Patriots of America. In 1897 he was Deputy Governor of the organization. Born September 25, 1846, died April 5, 1902. Columbus C. Wolcott purchased 160 acres of land at Humbolt Co., California in 1884. Christopher C. Wolcott registered to vote at Vallejo, California, in 1890.
m. 8 FEB 1872 Elizabeth McCrae , b. ,, Virginia, d. .
2 children: Christopher Stanton, Cornella.

Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 1872 Sarah Harding "Sallie" Crothers , b. 20 AUG 1848 , d. 5 JAN 1873 .
(8) William Merwin Wolcott (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 DEC 1849 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. ABT 1890 .
NotesWILLIAM attended college. He apparently died shortly after his second marriage when his wife is listed as a widow.

1900 Denver CO:
Caroline D Wolcott 43, b. PA Oct 1856, bakery
Robert D Wolcott 12, b. CO Feb 1888
Helen D S Wolcott 7, b. Co Sept 1892

1908 Denver CO
Mrs. Caroline D. Wolcott
Miss Helen S. Wolcott, student
Robert D.Wolcott, meter reader

1910 Los Angeles CA
Carolyn Wolcott 54 b. PA own income
Helen Wolcott 17 b. CO legal stenographer
Annie S Dornberg 31 roomer ,garment fitter




Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 16 APR 1881 Caroline Delange , b. 4 OCT 1856 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
2 children: Robert Delange, Helen Delange Stanton.
(9) Robert Delange Wolcott (William Merwin Wolcott8, Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 FEB 1888 Denver, Arapahoe Co., Colorado, d. 16 DEC 1947 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
NotesROBERT lived with his uncle, Frank E. Delange 52, machinist, at Denver, Colorado, in 1910, with both parents born Pennsylvania. Frank was at Pittsburg in 1880, and at Denver in 1900. His daughter, Donna, said that her mother told her that a friend of Robert's mother worked as a maid in a wealthy family who refused to allow their pregnant daughter to marry the father of her child. The baby was taken in and raised by Caroline.

1918 Draft Registration
Robert D Wolcott 29, b. 15 Feb 1888 Denver CO, lives Los Angeles, Imperial Irigation District, single, served in California Artillery 7 yrs., medium height, slender, blue eyes, light brown hair.
(9) Helen Delange Stanton Wolcott (William Merwin Wolcott8, Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 SEP 1893 ,, Colorado, d. .
NotesHELEN was a stenographer at Los Angeles in 1910. She became an acress in early silent films, 1914-1916. In 1919 she filed for a passport to travel to France with the Overseas Theatre League, giving her name as Helen Stanton Wolcott and her father born at Sewickley, Iowa, current location unknown.

Helen Stanton Wolcott
Birth Date: 20 Sep 1893
Birth Place: Denver, Colorado
Age: 25
Passport Issue Date: 11 Apr 1919 for YMCA entertainment work, Overdeas Theatre League.
Passport Includes a Photo: Yes
Residence: New York City, New York, actress
Father Name: Merwin Wolcott
Father's Birth Location: Sewickley, Iowa
(8) Darwin Stanton Wolcott (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JUL 1851 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 FEB 1927 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesDARWIN attended Kenyon College, and was was at College, Ohio, in 1870. He was employed by the United States Coast Survey as an emgineer for 5 or 6 years, and then worked for the Patent Office in Washington D. C.. He moved to Pittsburg in 1883 and in partnership with George H. Christy, established a law office. He was an attorney at Pittsburg in the 1890s and assisted Reginald Fessening in registering patents on his inventions for radio broadcasting. He helped Fessening find financial backers for setting up the National Electric Signaling Co. and was one of the principal shareholders in the company. The company sent the first two-way wireless communication across the Atlantic and produced the first radio broadcast program in 1906. In 1910 he established his own practice. He settled at Sedgewickley, where he was a member of the Episcopal Church.

1910 Sewickley PA:

Darwin S Wolcott Jr 32. b. Dist of Columbia, office mgr., steel works

Robert W Wolcott 17, b. PA
Evelyn M Wolcott 15, b. PA
Kate Stepanczk 19, servant
