m. SEP 1892 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Harriet Wright "Hattie" Baldwin , b. 4 MAR 1867 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 12 JAN 1951 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
5 children: Arthur Baldwin, Francis Bryan, Donald Treat, Robert Lemuel, Louis Porter.
(9) Arthur Baldwin Wolcott (Bryan Treat Wolcott8, Lemuel Porter Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 APR 1894 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 OCT 1982 Navarre, Stark Co., Ohio.
NotesARTHUR graduated from the agriculture school at Ohio State University. Following his father's death in 1923, he went home to farm the family farm until he sold it about 1960.
(9) Francis Bryan Wolcott (Bryan Treat Wolcott8, Lemuel Porter Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 MAY 1895 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 16 JUL 1973 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFRANCIS' obituary appeare in the Akron Beacon Journal: "At the age of 54 he walked from Tallmadge Circle to Akron during the record 1950 snowstorm to open the doors of the Akron National Bank. That was the kind of dedication that marked the 47 year banking career of Francis B. Wolcott, retired executive vice president of the bank. Mr. Wolcott died early today at his home 22 Northwest av. after a one-year illness. He was 78. Banking was the lifetime love of Wolcott who joined the National City Bank as a statement clerk in 1916. He retired in 1963. Wolcott was the fifth generation of a family which helped settle Tallmadge, but he showed no liking for farming. Instead he got a sales job with B. F. Goodrich in Akron and after six months joined the National City bank. Over the years he served as a vice president for five Akron banking institutions including the National City, First Central Trust, Bank of Akron and Akron Dime. He worked in almost every phase of the business. Wolcott preferred banking to working on the family farm which was founded by his great-great-grandfather in 1817. He took time off in World War I to serve with the 77th Division in a field artillery unit. In 1920 he lived at Akron, where he joined the Wolcott Society. At National City he was successively a teller, bookkeeper, assistant casier and a vice president. His friend J. Penfield Seiberling, former president of Seiberling Rubber once said Wolcott knows more about banking than anyone in Akron. Wolcott helped shape Akron banking development as he watched the city grow from a farm machinery center into the worlds rubber capital. He was with First Central when the stock market crashed in 1929 and remembered the 1933 bank holiday when President Roosevelt closed the nations banks. Wolcott stayed with First Central nine years while the State liquidated the troubled banks assets. We never lost faith in the country and its ability to bounce back, Wolcott said then. When it was all over First Central paid off its obligations 100 cents on the dollar. In 1942 Wolcott went with the Bank of Akron as a vice president. He later was named its first executive vice president and kept that title when Dime Bank was merged with the Bank of Akron in 1960. He once said he devoted most of his time to reading banking publications and had no time for fiction and other light reading. After living in Cuyahoga Falls 25 years, Wolcott returned to his native Tallmadge in 1949 to remodel the original Tallmadge Congregational Church parsonage near the circle, one of the few remaining old homes in the city. In 1940 the Wolcotts repurchased the farm belonging to an original family settler Guy Wolcott on N. Monroe Rd. in Tallmadge. The place was adjacent to the family farm where Wolcott was born and raised. He enjoyed being a gentleman farmer until the buildings were destroyed by fire in 1953. In 1954 he was chief coordinator of financing when a new church parish house was built. It is now the Tallmadge Municipal Building. Wolcott was church treasurer for many years and was active in the celebration of Tallmadges sesquicentennial in 1957. He was a graduate of Tallmadge High School; the Board of the Tallmadge Historical Society; Tallmadge Lions Club. Congregational Church, past president of the Tallmadge Alumni Association and was treasurer of the Tallmadge Business & Industrial Commission. His wife Florence died in May, 1972, shortly after they celebrated their 55th wedding anniversary." He was probably the Francis B. Wolcott who joined the Wolcott Society in 1920 as member #40.
(9) Donald Treat Wolcott (Bryan Treat Wolcott8, Lemuel Porter Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 JUN 1897 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 MAR 1976 Chesterland, Geauga Co., Ohio.
NotesDONALD was in the wholesale grocery business at Tallmadge, Ohio. He was there in 1930, with Ethel G., Helen D., Brice G. Wolcott.
(9) Robert Lemuel Wolcott (Bryan Treat Wolcott8, Lemuel Porter Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 JUL 1898 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 13 DEC 1991 Kent, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesROBERT was at Talmadge Township, Ohio, in 1930, with Emma E., Robert F., and Matilyn Wolcott. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1977 as member #1080, residing at Kent, Ohio.

Obituary: "Kent - Robert L. Wolcott, 93, of Munroe Falls Rd., died Friday at Robinson Memorial Hospital. He was born July 3, 1898 in Tallmadge to Bryan and Harriet (Baldwin) Wolcott. He was a former employee of the Summit Wholesale Grocery in Akron, then he was a farmer in Randolph from 1942 - 1975. He was a descendant of the early settlers of Tallmadge and a life member of Tallmadge Congregational Church. He was a past member of the Randolph Farm Bureau Council, Randolph Hayseed Club and the Tallmadge AARP. He is survied by his sons, Robert F. of Beaumont, Texas, and Richard A. of Manhattan Beach, Calif.; daughters, Marilyn D. Kilgore of Tallmadge and Margery L. Balthis of Kent; 17 grandchildren and 24 great- grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his wife, Emma E. (Atwater) in 1973 and by his four brothers.... Burial at Hillside Cemetery in Randolph."
(9) Louis Porter Wolcott (Bryan Treat Wolcott8, Lemuel Porter Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 MAY 1903 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 4 SEP 1977 Bonita Springs, Le Co., Florida.
NotesLOUIS was in a real estate agent and owned a real estate firm in Akron, Ohio.
(7) Elizur V. Wolcott (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 JUL 1833 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 20 DEC 1873 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesELIZUR was a student at the Western Reserve College in 1850, and graduated from Yale in 1854. He became a tutor at Western Reserve College in 1856. In 1857 he entered Andover Theological Seminary. Due to failing health he left the seminary before completing his studies. He bought the Pierce farm, and live there until his death. In 1870 he was at Tallmadge, Ohio, with Clara P., and Byron and his mother, Annie Wolcott.
m. 29 NOV 1860 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Fannie L. Pierce , b. 1834 Woodbury, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 23 SEP 1906 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
4 children: Clara Pierce, Kate Eloise, Emily Porter, Josephine Minor.
(8) Clara Pierce Wolcott (Elizur V. Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1861 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 6 NOV 1944 Ormond Beach, Volusia Co., Florida.
NotesCLARA attended design school at Cleveland and worked for a furniture manufacturer before moving to New York City to attend the Metropolitan Museum of Art School. By 1888 she was a designer and glass mosiac worker for the Tiffany Studios in New York City. In 1898 she became head of the Glass Mosaic Department which supervised women who created some of Tiffany's best known glass objects. She won an award for a dragonfly lampshade design at the 1900 Paris Arts Exhibition. An exhibition focused around her work and papers was put on by the New York Historical Society Feb. - May 2007.
m. 28 NOV 1889 New York City, New York, Francis S. Driscoll , b. , d. 21 FEB 1892 .
(8) Clara Pierce Wolcott (Elizur V. Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1861 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 6 NOV 1944 Ormond Beach, Volusia Co., Florida.
NotesCLARA attended design school at Cleveland and worked for a furniture manufacturer before moving to New York City to attend the Metropolitan Museum of Art School. By 1888 she was a designer and glass mosiac worker for the Tiffany Studios in New York City. In 1898 she became head of the Glass Mosaic Department which supervised women who created some of Tiffany's best known glass objects. She won an award for a dragonfly lampshade design at the 1900 Paris Arts Exhibition. An exhibition focused around her work and papers was put on by the New York Historical Society Feb. - May 2007.
m. 1 SEP 1909 Montclaire, Essex Co., New Jersey, Edward A. Booth , b. , d. .
(8) Kate Eloise Wolcott (Elizur V. Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 DEC 1863 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 FEB 1903 .
(8) Emily Porter Wolcott (Elizur V. Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 OCT 1866 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 DEC 1953 .
NotesEMILY's letter have been published in a book by Elizabeth A. Yeargin, entitled "The Pierce and Wolcott Letters". Emily never married. In 1880 she lived with Rev. Jonathan Upton, brother-in-law of her aunt. She studied at Mt. Holyoke and taught school at Baltimore, Maryland, and Akron, Ohio. She then attended Michigan State University at Ann Arbor, Michigan, and taught school in New York City for most of the rest of her life.
(8) Josephine Minor Wolcott (Elizur V. Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 OCT 1871 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 22 APR 1896 .
(7) Eleanor Wolcott (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 JUL 1833 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 14 JUL 1834 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
(7) Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 FEB 1837 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 8 MAY 1896 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
NotesFRANKLIN went to Nebraska in 1856. He took up 160 acres of land in Center Precinct, where he engaged in real estate and loaning money for 7 years. He returned to Ohio in 1862, and married. He purchased 220 acres of land near Weeping Water in 1864. In the fall of 1864 he moved West, shipping some sheep and cattle to Ottumwa, Iowa, where the railroad then ended. He drove the livestock overland, while his new wife continued by stage coach to the Missouri River. They crossed the river to Patsmouth on a flatboat. Then continue on to Nebraska, and lived in the second floor of the log cabin of Philander Beardsley, in Cass Co., a mile west of the present town of Weeping Water. They built a small log cabin, and a short time later built a frame house in front of it. He was elected to the Nebraska House of Representatives in 1870. Frank M. Wolcott was at Weeping Water in 1870, with wife Henrietta and daughters Lucy R. and Creda A. Wolcott. In 1880 Franklin became the county agent for the B & M Railroad Land Department Company in Cass and Otoe counties, showing the company's land grant lands to newly arrived pioneers and acting as real estate agent. In 1881 he was appointed notary public. Frank was instrumental in building the first church in Weeping Water. It later became the Weeping Water Academy, of which his daughter, Lucy, was in the second graduating class, in 1889. He died of a stroke while resting on a creek bank. His son, Lloyd, thought his father's middle name was Marshall, rather than Maginnis.
m. 10 MAY 1864 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Henrietta M. Brooks , b. 14 AUG 1845 New Rochelle, Westchester Co., New York, d. 16 FEB 1925 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
3 children: Lucy Rowena, Creda Annis, Lloyd Porter.
(8) Lucy Rowena Wolcott (Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 DEC 1868 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 7 MAY 1898 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
m. 28 SEP 1892 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, Isaac William Teegarden , b. 10 MAR 1866 , Columbiana Co., Ohio, d. 25 SEP 1943 Long Beach, Los Angeles Co., California.
2 children: Jeanette, Lucy Wolcott.
(9) Jeanette Teegarden (Lucy Rowena Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 AUG 1895 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. .
(9) Lucy Wolcott Teegarden (Lucy Rowena Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAY 1898 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. ABT 1928 .
NotesLUCY died age 29 years, 4 mo., 29 days.
(8) Creda Annis Wolcott (Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 APR 1870 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 2 SEP 1902 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
NotesCREDA never married. She lived with her mother and gave piano lessons, driving her horses to neighboring small towns. She also did china painting. She died of a heart attack at her brothers' wedding.
(8) Lloyd Porter Wolcott (Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 MAR 1879 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 4 JUL 1952 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska.
NotesLLOYD was cashier of the First National Bank, retiring in 1925. During World War II he was a watchman at the Glen L. Martin Bomber Plant near Omaha. He was very active in the Masonic lodge. He was Wolcott Society vice-president for Nebraska in 1909.

1918 Draft Registration:
Lloyd Porter Wolcott, 39
County: Cass NB
Birth Date: 8 Mar 1879
banking, First National Bank, Weeping Water NB
wife Olive H. Wolcott, Weeping Water
medium height and build, blue eyes, light hair.
m. 2 SEP 1903 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, Olive Hitchman , b. 1 SEP 1880 Mount Pleasant, Westmoreland Co., Pennsylvania, d. 1967 .
5 children: Franklin Marshall "Frank", Elizabeth Henrietta "Betty", Robert Hitchman, Doris, Warren James.
(9) Franklin Marshall "Frank" Wolcott (Lloyd Porter Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JUN 1908 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 10 OCT 1995 Indianapolis, Marion Co., Indiana.
NotesFRANKLIN graduated from the University of Nebraska in 1931. During World War II he was an inspector in a war plant in New Jersey. In 1947 he went to work for the Bureau of Reclamation, and worked most of the time in Huron, South Dakota.
(9) Elizabeth Henrietta "Betty" Wolcott (Lloyd Porter Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUL 1911 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 1971 .
(9) Robert Hitchman Wolcott (Lloyd Porter Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 FEB 1913 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 1974 .
NotesROBERT served in the South Pacific during World War II, then graduated from the University of Nebraska in Engineering and was employeed by the Nebraska State Highway Department.
(9) Doris Wolcott (Lloyd Porter Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 SEP 1918 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. .
NotesDORIS worked at the Glenn L. Martin Bomber Plant in Omaha during World War II.
(9) Warren James Wolcott (Lloyd Porter Wolcott8, Franklin Maginnis "Frank" Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 JAN 1921 Weeping Water, Cass Co., Nebraska, d. 21 SEP 1951 .
NotesWARREN, known as Jim, was a U.S. Army Glider pilot during World War II and served in Italy and Europe. He was a very successful salesman for Devoe and Raeynolds Paint Company headquartered in Sioux City, Iowa. While returning home one night, his car overturned into a rain swollen river and he was drowned.

Military Gravestone: Warren James Wolcott, enlisted 29 June 1942, discharged 24 Sep 1946, 2nd LT. NB, 349th Troop Carrier, Glider Pilot 1026, USAAF, bur Oakwood Cemetery, Weeping Water NB
(7) Ellen Coe Wolcott (Guy Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 OCT 1844 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 5 APR 1871 .
NotesEllen was a graduate of Lake Erie Seminary.
m. 8 JUN 1870 Lyman Walker Peet , b. 14 JAN 1838 Cornwall, Addison Co., Vermont, d. 4 JAN 1917 Cornwall, Addison Co., Vermont.
(6) James Wolcott (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 NOV 1789 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1873 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES supervised the construction of a woolen mill on the Waterbury River for his father in 1813. In 1818 he moved to Delaware, Ohio, where he and Joseph S. Hughes constructed a woolen mill at Delaware, Ohio, which he managed fot two years. Here he joined the Episcopal church. He then moved to St. Louis, Missouri, where he married, and then settled at Fort Wayne, Indiana. He purchased 300 acres of land in Allen Co., Indiana in 1826 at Ft. Wayne. He and his wife and all their household goods were put in a boat and paddled down the Maumee River from Fort Wayne to Waynesfield, Ohio. In 1827 he purchased 300 acres of government land in Waynesfield Township for $1.25 an acre, and 377 acres in Lucas Co. He build a log house in what was then a wilderness and sold land to other settlers. In 1834-6 he built a two story frame house on the north bank of the river at Maumee in which he and his wife lived and died. He operated the Central House, Maumee's first "hotel" before establishing himself as a merchant. By 1837, his business, receiving and forwarding merchandise to Ft. Wayne and points west, was one of the largest in the area. He paid personal property taxes in Waynesfield Township in 1838. In 1838 he was elected to the first Maumee City Council, where he served as president. He also built wharves and shipyards along the river near his home. James commissioned construction of two steamboats, the "General Harrison", with a 150 ft. keel, launched in 1840, and the "James Wolcott". They operated between Maumee and Buffalo, New York, via Lake Erie. James was the first president of Maumee City Council in 1838. The following year he was elected Judge of the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas. In 1843 he was Mayor of Maumee. He was a founder of the Ohio Whig political party and a supporter of William Henry Harrison and Henry Clay. In 1860 he was at Maumee, with Fred K. and James Wolcott. James, William W., Eliza J., Zoe W., Byron, and James M. Wolcott were at Maumee in 1870. After his death, his home was occupied by his daughter Mary, and was willed to the Episcopal church about 1960. It is now a museum.
m. 8 MAR 1821 , St. Charles Co., Missouri, Mary Ann "Polly", "Ahmaquahzahquah" Wells , b. 10 MAY 1800 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, d. 19 FEB 1843 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
7 children: William Wells, Robert Fulton, Mary Ann, Henry Clay, Frederick Calhoun "Fred", James Monroe "Tip", Emily B..
(7) William Wells Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 DEC 1821 Louisville, Jefferson Co., Kentucky, d. 30 APR 1905 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesWILLIAM came to Maumee, Ohio, in 1826 with his parents. As a young man, he intended to study law, but the death of his mother changed that plan. In 1840 he went to the Great Lakes where be became captain of some of the finest ships of those days. One of the boats he captained was the "General Harrison", built and owned by his father. He lived at Toledo OH from 1847 to 1850, and then moved back to Maumee, Ohio, where he was a general contractor of public works and a farmer. In 1860 he was at Maumee with Eliza, Effa, and Byron Wolcott. In 1880 he and his wife were living at Toledo with their son, Byron. His obituary describes him as the "second eldest son of Judge James Wolcott"
m. 11 FEB 1848 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, Eliza Jane Border , b. 1825 ,, England, d. 1898 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
3 children: Effie E., Zoe Wells, Byron William.
(8) Effie E. Wolcott (William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1849 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. .
m. William Douglas Randall , b. 1841 , d. JUL 1917 Liberty Center, Henry Co., Ohio.
1 children: Eva Wolcott.
(9) Eva Wolcott Randall (Effie E. Wolcott8, William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
NotesEVA was in the Perrysburg, Ohio, hospital in 1914, due to a serious illness.
(8) Zoe Wells Wolcott (William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JUL 1851 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 6 FEB 1923 ,, Ohio.
NotesZOE and her husband attended the 1912 Wolcott Society reunion at Detroit residing at Maumee, Ohio.
m. Edward E. Church , b. 4 JUL 1850 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 21 MAR 1921 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
2 children: Carrie, Grace.
(9) Carrie Church (Zoe Wells Wolcott8, William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1877 ,, Ohio, d. .
(9) Grace Church (Zoe Wells Wolcott8, William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. JUL 1879 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 1909 .
(8) Byron William Wolcott (William Wells Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1852 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
Notes1910 Maumee OH:
Name: Byron Wolcott
Birthplace: Ohio
Relationship to Head of Household: Self
Residence: Maumee Ward 3, Lucas, Ohio
Marital Status: Single
Father's Birthplace: Kentucky
Mother's Birthplace: England
(7) Robert Fulton Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1824 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, d. 1836 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesROBERT drowned in the Maumee River.
(7) Mary Ann Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 JUN 1827 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 30 APR 1891 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesMARY lived in her father's home after his death.
m. 1848 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, Smith Gilbert , b. 29 OCT 1815 Newtown, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 30 MAR 1879 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
3 children: Frederica Eliza "Freddie", Albert Wolcott, Smith Wells.
(8) Frederica Eliza "Freddie" Gilbert (Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 APR 1850 Fort Wayne, Allen Co., Indiana, d. 17 JUL 1934 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICA was born and died in the house James Wolcott built at Maumee. She and her daughter lived there, and her funeral was held there. She was buried with military honors by the American Legion. She was a member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church and of the Relief Corps of the G. A. R. She was a member of the Wolcott Society 1912-15, and attended the 1912 and 1914 reunions.
m. 22 DEC 1875 William Curtis Hull , b. 8 AUG 1852 , d. 2 APR 1903 .
1 children: Rilla E..
(9) Rilla E. Hull (Frederica Eliza "Freddie" Gilbert8, Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 FEB 1880 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 1957 .
NotesRILLA was the last resident of the James Wolcott house in Maumee City, Ohio. She willed the house to the Episcopal Church and requested that it be preserved as a museum for local history. They sold it to the city of Maumee for $15,000 in 1960. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1937 as member #211, residing at Maumee, Ohio.
(8) Albert Wolcott Gilbert (Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1852 ,, Ohio, d. 1926 .
m. Mary Elizabeth Power , b. , d. .
2 children: William, Albert Wolcott.
(9) William Gilbert (Albert Wolcott Gilbert8, Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Albert Wolcott Gilbert (Albert Wolcott Gilbert8, Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
NotesALBERT lived at Toledo, Ohio, in 1934.
(8) Smith Wells Gilbert (Mary Ann Wolcott7, James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1854 ,, Ohio, d. 1925 .
(7) Henry Clay Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 OCT 1830 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 7 APR 1882 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesHENRY had black hair and dark eyes, reflecting his mother's Indian bloodline. He was living at Wayne Co., Michigan, when he enlisted in Co. E, 16th Michigan Inf. Regt., serving for 2 years and fighting at the Battle of Manassas. He then returned to Ohio. In Jan. 1864, he enlisted in Co. E, 3rd Ohio Cav. Regt. Part of this service was a a Brigade teamster, delivering supplies. He was mustered out at Nashville on 14 Aug. 1865. His life after the war was said to have been " difficult". In 1880 he was single and living alone at Maumee, age 52, with no occupation.
m. Annie , b. 7 JUL 1846 , d. 16 JUN 1925 .
(7) Frederick Calhoun "Fred" Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 NOV 1834 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 24 JUL 1864 Atlanta, Fulton Co., Georgia.
NotesFREDERICK served in the 47th Ohio Inf. Regt., and was killed at the Battle of Atlanta. His name is also given as Frederick Allyn Wolcott.
(7) James Monroe "Tip" Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 DEC 1839 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 24 NOV 1917 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES served in the 130th Ohio Inf. Regt. in the Union Army during the Civil War. He was a dentist by profession, and served as Justice of the Peace. He filed a number of legal suits claiming property in the city of Fort Wayne based on old Indian treaties. In 1887 he was Waynesfield Township clerk and justice of the peace. He was appointed Mayor of Maumee in 1885, and elected to that office in 1887. He was also Secretary of the Maumee Board of Education in 1887. James was a Mason, a Democrat, and an Episcopalian. He spoke at the 1912 Wolcott Society reunion, and read an account of his family which was printed in the society's annual report..
m. Emma Randall , b. , d. .
(7) Emily B. Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. INFANT .
(6) James Wolcott (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 NOV 1789 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1873 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES supervised the construction of a woolen mill on the Waterbury River for his father in 1813. In 1818 he moved to Delaware, Ohio, where he and Joseph S. Hughes constructed a woolen mill at Delaware, Ohio, which he managed fot two years. Here he joined the Episcopal church. He then moved to St. Louis, Missouri, where he married, and then settled at Fort Wayne, Indiana. He purchased 300 acres of land in Allen Co., Indiana in 1826 at Ft. Wayne. He and his wife and all their household goods were put in a boat and paddled down the Maumee River from Fort Wayne to Waynesfield, Ohio. In 1827 he purchased 300 acres of government land in Waynesfield Township for $1.25 an acre, and 377 acres in Lucas Co. He build a log house in what was then a wilderness and sold land to other settlers. In 1834-6 he built a two story frame house on the north bank of the river at Maumee in which he and his wife lived and died. He operated the Central House, Maumee's first "hotel" before establishing himself as a merchant. By 1837, his business, receiving and forwarding merchandise to Ft. Wayne and points west, was one of the largest in the area. He paid personal property taxes in Waynesfield Township in 1838. In 1838 he was elected to the first Maumee City Council, where he served as president. He also built wharves and shipyards along the river near his home. James commissioned construction of two steamboats, the "General Harrison", with a 150 ft. keel, launched in 1840, and the "James Wolcott". They operated between Maumee and Buffalo, New York, via Lake Erie. James was the first president of Maumee City Council in 1838. The following year he was elected Judge of the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas. In 1843 he was Mayor of Maumee. He was a founder of the Ohio Whig political party and a supporter of William Henry Harrison and Henry Clay. In 1860 he was at Maumee, with Fred K. and James Wolcott. James, William W., Eliza J., Zoe W., Byron, and James M. Wolcott were at Maumee in 1870. After his death, his home was occupied by his daughter Mary, and was willed to the Episcopal church about 1960. It is now a museum.
m. 21 NOV 1844 Caroline B. , b. 1815 ,, New Hampshire, d. .
1 children: Joseph Luke.
(7) Joseph Luke Wolcott (James Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1845 Maumee, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesJOSEPH served as a musician in Co. B, 67th Ohio Inf. Regt., during the Civil War. In 1865 he was a lieutenant in the Loyal Legion of the United States. Joseph L. Wolcott of Toledo, Ohio, was an officer of the Paltrier Oil Company in 1897.
(6) Elizur "Eli" Wolcott (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JUL 1792 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. Enfield, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesELIZUR is said to have lived at Thompsonville. He was probably the Elizur Wolcott, age 50, born in Connecticut, who was living at a hotel in Enfield, Connecticut in 1850.

1850 Enfield, Harftford Co. CT: Elizur Wolcott 50y, b. CT, lodger at Harris family hotel.

1860 Eli Wolcott was a machinist living at Enfield, Connecticut, in 1860. Living with him was Sophia Moulton 57.
m. 1817 ,, Connecticut, Esther Lewis , b. , d. .
(6) Frederick Wolcott (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 JAN 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 24 JUL 1895 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICK or another Frederick Woolcott owned 277 acres at Ashtabula, Ohio, in 1833, which he rented to Eli Sanford.
He was a farmer at Stow, Ohio, in 1850.
Frederick Wolcott M 52y
Lucy Wolcott F 18y
Frederick Wolcott M 16y
Mary Wolcott F 14y
Hobart Wolcott M 12y
Keily Peirce F 22y
Robert Walker M 23y
m. 27 DEC 1821 , Portage Co., Ohio, Eliza Ann Gaylord , b. 1801 Middletown, Butler Co., Ohio, d. 11 JUL 1825 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio.
2 children: Eliza Ann, Oliver.
(7) Eliza Ann Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
m. Elijah Judson Dibble , b. , d. .
1 children: Nancy.

NotesFREDERICK or another Frederick Woolcott owned 277 acres at Ashtabula, Ohio, in 1833, which he rented to Eli Sanford.
He was a farmer at Stow, Ohio, in 1850.

(7) Lucy Ann Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1830 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesLUCY A. Wolcott of Monroe Falls, Ohio, was a student at Steubenville Female Seminary in 1845.
m. 14 JAN 1864 , Summit Co., Ohio, John A. Knolton , b. 1824 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont, d. .
1 children: Frank W..
(8) Frank W. Knolton (Lucy Ann Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1867 ,, Ohio, d. .
(7) Frederick Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1834 Stow, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 23 MAY 1903 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesFREDERICK was at Stow, Ohio, in 1870 with Catherine and Marchant Wolcott. He and his wife went from Ohio to Kansas by wagon train with a family named Hoit.. While crossing the Mississippi River they were attacked by Indians and several wagons were nearly lost. In Kansas home they built a sod house, enduring locusts, Indians, droughts and "The Great Prairie Fire". In 1880 Frederick was a farmer at Trego Co., Kansas. They later returned to Ohio.
m. 3 JAN 1866 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, Katherine Finley , b. South Bend, St. Joseph Co., Indiana, d. 5 NOV 1915 Troy, Bradford Co., Pennsylvania.
1 children: Marchant Finley,
(8) Marchant Finley Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 OCT 1866 Munroe Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 7 DEC 1913 Troy, Bradford Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesMARCHANT was foreman in a brass factory at Franklin, New York, in 1913 when he purchased a farm at Armenia, New York, where he moved with his wife, mother, and four daughters. He attended the 4th Wolcott reunions held at Silver Lake, Ohio, in 1908.
m. Cora Winkes , b. ABT 1870 , d. .
2 children: , Coral Lee.
(9) Wolcott (Marchant Finley Wolcott8, Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 FEB 1893 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Coral Lee Wolcott (Marchant Finley Wolcott8, Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1895 , d. 23 NOV 1918 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(8) Marchant Finley Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 OCT 1866 Munroe Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 7 DEC 1913 Troy, Bradford Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesMARCHANT was foreman in a brass factory at Franklin, New York, in 1913 when he purchased a farm at Armenia, New York, where he moved with his wife, mother, and four daughters. He attended the 4th Wolcott reunions held at Silver Lake, Ohio, in 1908.
m. 14 SEP 1898 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, Myrtle Luella Poulson , b. 28 MAY 1878 Holmesville, Holmes Co., Ohio, d. .
4 children: Katharyn Poulson, Mildred Ann, Martha Finley, Nancy.
(9) Katharyn Poulson Wolcott (Marchant Finley Wolcott8, Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 AUG 1899 Chrystal Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1 MAR 1976 .
NotesKATHARYN attended Columbia University. She was a poet. Her poetry was published in the book, "Wind Across the Threshold", and in many national magazines. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1934 as member #191, residing at Weehawken, New Jersey. and was poet for the Wolcott Society for over 25 years. She wrote in 1935 that she remembered "attending the first Wolcott reunion held at Silver Lake, Ohio, as a child. I have in fact a picture taken that day of all the children present." This would actually have been the 4th reunion, held at Cuyahoga Falls. During World War II she was supervisor of the Red Cross program at Weehawken, New Jersey, with over 4,000 volunteer workers.
(9) Mildred Ann Wolcott (Marchant Finley Wolcott8, Frederick Wolcott7, Frederick Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 NOV 1900 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesMILDRED joined the Wolcott Society in 1956 as member #581, residing at Mahopac, New York, and rejoined in 1969 as member #814 residing at Black Mountain, North Carolina..

NotesCECELIA "was one of the early members when the local Ohio chapter was the only chapter in existance, about 1900, and the meetings were held in little Ohio towns such as Hudson and Silver Lake, Ohio." She lived at Hudson, Ohio.

(7) Ellen Arabella Hitchcock (Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 FEB 1831 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 27 MAY 1832 .
(7) Elizur Hitchcock (Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 AUG 1832 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesThe following sketch appears in History of Summit County, With an Outline Sketch of Ohio, edited by William Henry Perrin (Chicago: Baskin & Battey, 1881), p. 716:
"Dr. Elizur Hitchcock, physician, Akron; is a native of Summit County. He was born on his fathers farm in Tallmadge, Aug. 15, 1832, and is the fourth of seven children born to Lucius W. and Eleanor (Wolcott) Hitchcock. His parents were natives of Connecticut, his father coming on foot in 1822, to Tallmadge, where he bought a farm, married and raised his family. In 1873, he lost his wife, and left the farm, coming to Akron, where he now resides. Dr. Hitchcock remained at home until the spring of 1850, working on the farm and gaining such education as the schools of the neighborhood afforded. At 18, he entered the Western Reserve College at Hudson, where he studied two years, and then entered the Junior Class in Yale College, graduating there in 1854. During the next four years, he taught select schools in Tallmadge and Gustavus, dividing the time between them. In 1857, he began reading medicine with Dr. Dudley Allen, at Kinsman, Ohio, and in 1860, graduated at the Medical Department of the Western Reserve College, at Cleveland, having taken a course previously at Ann Arbor, Mich. He began his practice at Mecca, but in the following spring located at Orwell, where he remained two years. He then went into the army as Surgeon of the 7th O.V.I., and resigned after serving about sixth months. In the fall of 1863, he located in West Williamsfield, Ohio, where he remained until 1869, when he sold out his business and attended the Bellevue Hospital. In 1870, he came to Akron and has since practiced his profession here. He is a member and President of the Summit County Medical Society, and also a member of the Union Medical Association of Northeastern Ohio. On Nov. 24, 1861, he married Miss Hattie Reed, a native of Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, by whom he had one child, Gertrude R. His wife died in May, 1864. In November, 1864, he married Miss Lucretia Kellogg, a native of West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, by whom he has two children -- Halbert K. and Lucius W."
m. 24 NOV 1861 Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Hattie Reed , b. Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, d. 20 MAY 1864 West Williamsfield, Ashtabula Co., Ohio.
1 children: Gertrude Reed.
(8) Gertrude Reed Hitchcock (Elizur Hitchcock7, Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 NOV 1862 , d. .
m. 24 DEC 1883 Daniel Dickle , b. , d. .
(7) Elizur Hitchcock (Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 AUG 1832 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesThe following sketch appears in History of Summit County, With an Outline Sketch of Ohio, edited by William Henry Perrin (Chicago: Baskin & Battey, 1881), p. 716:
"Dr. Elizur Hitchcock, physician, Akron; is a native of Summit County. He was born on his fathers farm in Tallmadge, Aug. 15, 1832, and is the fourth of seven children born to Lucius W. and Eleanor (Wolcott) Hitchcock. His parents were natives of Connecticut, his father coming on foot in 1822, to Tallmadge, where he bought a farm, married and raised his family. In 1873, he lost his wife, and left the farm, coming to Akron, where he now resides. Dr. Hitchcock remained at home until the spring of 1850, working on the farm and gaining such education as the schools of the neighborhood afforded. At 18, he entered the Western Reserve College at Hudson, where he studied two years, and then entered the Junior Class in Yale College, graduating there in 1854. During the next four years, he taught select schools in Tallmadge and Gustavus, dividing the time between them. In 1857, he began reading medicine with Dr. Dudley Allen, at Kinsman, Ohio, and in 1860, graduated at the Medical Department of the Western Reserve College, at Cleveland, having taken a course previously at Ann Arbor, Mich. He began his practice at Mecca, but in the following spring located at Orwell, where he remained two years. He then went into the army as Surgeon of the 7th O.V.I., and resigned after serving about sixth months. In the fall of 1863, he located in West Williamsfield, Ohio, where he remained until 1869, when he sold out his business and attended the Bellevue Hospital. In 1870, he came to Akron and has since practiced his profession here. He is a member and President of the Summit County Medical Society, and also a member of the Union Medical Association of Northeastern Ohio. On Nov. 24, 1861, he married Miss Hattie Reed, a native of Mecca, Trumbull Co., Ohio, by whom he had one child, Gertrude R. His wife died in May, 1864. In November, 1864, he married Miss Lucretia Kellogg, a native of West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, by whom he has two children -- Halbert K. and Lucius W."
m. 30 NOV 1864 Lucretia Kellogg , b. West Andover, Ashtabula Co., Ohio, d. .
2 children: Herbert Kellogg, Lucius Wolcott.

(8) Eva Pearl Hitchcock (Herbert Pascal Hitchcock7, Eleanor Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 AUG 1876 , d. .
(6) George Wolcott (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUL 1806 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 31 MAR 1857 Wolcottville, LaGrange Co., Indiana.
NotesGEORGE's father died when he was 15, leaving him in charge of the family farm at Tallmadge Ohio. In 1828, he went to Wadsworth, Ohio, where he purchased 100 acres of land at four dollars per acre, and began clearing it and building a log cabin. He bought half interest in a sawmill in 1832, and engaged in the manufacture of fanning mills. George moved to La Grange Co., Indiana, in 1837, and built a log cabin on the Elkhart River. He homesteaded 160 acres in LaGrange Co. jointly with Smith C. Sherman in 1838. Here he built a sawmill and gristmill, adding a store and a frame barn in 1839. The town was called Wolcott's Mills, but in 1848 the name was changed to Wolcottville, named after George. In 1845 he built a larger gristmill, bringing the machinery by wagon from Ann Arbor, Michigan, a distance of one hundred and sixty-five miles. In 1847 he built a larger store, putting into it a full stock of goods and conducting seven different branches of business; milling, sawing, coopering, blacksmithing, mercantile,and potash production. George also had a large farm. He requested the National Educational Society to send a teacher as governess for his family. The next year he built a school building that he named the Wolcottville Young Ladies Seminary. Later young men were admitted as well. Soon after this he built a boarding house with rooms for the students. The money used in these enterprises was from his own resources. The 1850 census has him as a miller at Johnson Township, LaGrange Co., Indiana, age 43, with Margaret 46, Abby A. 19, Esther R. 16, Elton 14, Marshall 12, and Amelia 8.
m. 6 AUG 1828 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Margaret Hine , b. 12 NOV 1803 North Milford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 2 FEB 1892 Wolcottville, LaGrange Co., Indiana.
7 children: Anna Louisa "Ann", Abigail Amanda, Julia Almira, Esther Rowena, Elton Romeo, Marshall Franklin, Amelia.
(7) Anna Louisa "Ann" Wolcott (George Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1829 Wadsworth, Medina Co., Ohio, d. 25 JAN 1919 Kalamazoo, Kalamazoo Co., Michigan.

NotesELTON was of Wolcottsville, Indiana, at the time of his marriage. He lived at Wolcottvile in 1864. He had land for 32 lots and 4 streets annexed to the town of Wolcottville in 1872. In 1880 he was a farmer at Sheridan, Iowa.

NotesALFRED was a member of the Wolcott Society 1914-15, residing at Omaha, Nebraska, but was not on the 1916 roster. He was a clerk in Portland, Oregon, in 1919, and was living in Portland in 1944.

NotesFRANK" left Wolcottville, Indiana, more than 50 years ago. and after great irrigation difficulties developed the Hemet Valley, famous for its scenery, beauty and fruits. At one time the family suffered a $200,000 loss through failure of the water supply." Survivors were his widow and a brother, Alfred Perry Wolcott. (1944 Wolcott Society Annual Report) Two infants listed here and buried in Riverside Co. are probably his children.

NotesROGER graduated from Yale College in 1911, and received his law degree from Yale in 1913. He practiced law ar Hartford and was an alderman at Hartford from 1917 to 1919. He moved to Windsor, Connecticut, where he practiced law and became a judge.

(5) Sarah Strong (Hepzibah Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1761 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(4) Josiah Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 FEB 1719 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 29 JUN 1802 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesJOSIAH served in Capt. E. Grant's Co. during King George's War. He apparently never married, although he is listed at East Windsor in 1790 with a household of 1 male over 16 and 2 females. He left an estate valued at 8,034L.
(4) Erastus Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 FEB 1721 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 MAY 1722 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(4) Epaphras Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 FEB 1721 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 APR 1733 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(4) Erastus Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 SEP 1722 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 SEP 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS was a Representative to the General Assembly for South Windsor for many terms, and was Speaker of the Assembly. He was a Justice of the Peace, Judge of Probate, and Chief Judge of the County Court. Erastus was sent to Boston in 1775, to observe the British troops. He commanded a Regiment of Connecticut militia in 1776, which helped raise the siege of Boston. After the British left, he took his troops to New London where he supervised the erection of fortifications and garrisoned Fort Trumbull and Fort Griswold. In 1777 Erastus was in charge of the troops guarding the Hudson River. He led the 1st Connecticut Brigade in the expedition to Peekskill, New York, and then to Danbury, Connecticut. Erastus, leader of the agrarian faction in the state, was chosen a delegate to the Continental Congress, but did not accept. He was a member of the Court Martial selected by Washington for the trial of Major Andre. After the war, he was a Judge of the Connecticut Supreme Court. Yale College gave him an honorary degree. In 1790 he was at East Windsor with family consisting of 3 males over 16 and 1 female. Erastus' will, dated 14 Dec. 1792, left a silver tankard to his son, Erastus, 500L each to his daughters, Flavia and Jerusha, and the residue to be divided between his sons, Erastus, Arodi, and Albert. He was said to been of large frame, with light gray eyes and light hair, reserved in conversation, with a reputation for sagacity. He was affectionately known as "Old Long Head". Erastus and his wife, Jerusha, were 2nd cousins.
m. 10 FEB 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Jerusha Wolcott , b. 18 JAN 1719 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 JUN 1789 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
7 children: Erastus, Flavia, Erastus, Flavia, Jerusha, Arodi, Albert.
(5) Erastus Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 DEC 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 AUG 1751 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Flavia Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAY 1750 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 AUG 1751 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Erastus Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 JUL 1752 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JAN 1797 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS was a Captain in the Connecticut Line, and commanded a regiment at Boston. He was taken prisoner by the British and suffered a long confinement. He lived in his father's house at Windsor, where he was a Justice of the Peace, a Representative to the General Assembly, and Judge of Probate. In 1790 he was at East Windsor with a family consisting of 1 male over 16, 2 males under 16, and 1 female. His estate was valued at $39,918. A land warrant was issued in 1799 to his wife, Chloe, guardian of his minor children, Erastus, Chloe, Edward, Julia, and Helen Wolcott, based on his military service. He was tall and thin, with light complexion, and light flaxen hair. Erastus and his wife were second cousins.
m. 27 DEC 1783 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Chloe Bissell , b. 30 AUG 1758 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1802 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
5 children: Erastus, Chloe, Edward, Juliana, Helen.
(6) Erastus Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 OCT 1784 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 FEB 1812 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Chloe Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 APR 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Rochester, Monroe Co., New York.
(6) Edward Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 OCT 1788 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 NOV 1832 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesEDWARD was at Hartford Co., Connecticut, in 1810, as head of family consisting of 2 males age 16-25 (Erastus and Edward), 1 female 26-44, and 3 females age 16-25 (Chloe, Julianna, and Helen). He was captain of a company in Col. Shepard's Regt. in the War of 1812. His grave stone gives his rank as Captain.
(6) Juliana Wolcott (Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 APR 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 NOV 1832 .
m. 13 MAY 1823 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elihu Wolcott , b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
3 children: Helen Maria, Julia Ann, Ellen Louise "Ella".
(7) Helen Maria Wolcott (Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1824 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 13 MAY 1831 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

NotesJULIA was a student at the Jacksonville Female Academy, graduating in 1845.

NotesHERBERT graduated from Illinois College in 1892, and from Hahnemann Medical College in Philadelphia in 1895. He had a druggist business in Jacksonville for a few yearsm and then returned to Philadelphia to study diseases of the nose and throat.
(8) Helen Hooker Carter (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 OCT 1870 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 11 JUN 1871 .
(7) Ellen Louise "Ella" Wolcott (Juliana Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 JUN 1828 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 15 APR 1912 Elmira, Chemung Co., New York.
NotesELLEN had a dermatalogical illness and spent much time undergoing various cures. After the death of her father she had financial problems. She worked for the Sanitary Comission as a nurse during the Civil War, where she was a correspondent of Dorthea Dix. After the war she was a librarian at Elmira, New York. In 1880 she was living alone at Elmira. Her letters and papers are in the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, at the University of Connecticut Library. Ellen L. Wolcott of Elmira, New York, is reported deceased in the 1912 Society report, and is described as "a loyal member of the society from its beginning."
m. McVaugh , b. , d. .
1 children: Archie.

NotesARCHIE was killed.

NotesHELEN attended Mrs. Royce's School for Girls at Hartford, as did her cousin, Ursula Wolcott.

NotesELON was a chemist, hydrodynamic engineer, and founder of the Hooker Electrochemical Co., founded in 1909. He was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York in 1920.

NotesFREDERICK took over his father's farm. He served as Corporal, Sgt., 2nd Lt., and Capt. of the 2nd Co., 1st Cav. Regt. He was appointed Major in the 1st Cav. Regt. in 1832.

(8) Henry Tudor Bissell (Edward Bissell7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 AUG 1834 Lockport, Niagara Co., New York, d. 9 SEP 1863 Louisville, Jefferson Co., Kentucky.
NotesHENRY enlisted 22 August 1862 in the 111th Ohio Volunteer Regiment and was Adjustant of the regiment and participated in Gen. Buell's campaign in pursult of Bragg's army. He died of extra fatigue and exposure in The Sisters' Hospital. He was educated at Brown University in Rhode Island and studied law in Cincinnati, Ohio. Source #70, Vol. 2, page 97.

m. 26 NOV 1840 Julia Watson , b. , d. .
(6) Naomi Wolcott (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 OCT 1777 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1831 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
m. 23 OCT 1804 , Ontario Co., New York, James Wadsworth , b. 20 APR 1768 Durham, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JUN 1844 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
5 children: Harriet, James Samson, William Wolcott, Cornelia, Elizabeth.
(7) Harriet Wadsworth (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 SEP 1805 , d. 1834 .
m. Martin Brimmer , b. , d. .
1 children: Martin.
(8) Martin Brimmer (Harriet Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
NotesMARTIN graduated fron Harvard University in 1849.
(7) James Samson Wadsworth (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 OCT 1807 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 6 MAY 1864 Wilderness, Spotsylvania Co., Virginia.
NotesJAMES dropped out of Harvard, studied law with Daniel Webster, and was admitted to the bar in 1833. He married a "celebrated beauty" and took her to Europe for their honeymoon. Fascinated by the way the English gentry lived, he returned to Geneseo and built a palatial house called "Hartford House". He purchased 24,000 acres of government land in Ohio in 1836. He had a home in New York City, and maintained a racing stable and an impressive wine cellar. He entertained lavishly, his guests including many prominent government officials and European nobility. His house had nine servant rooms and other servants came in for the day. He divorced his first wife and remarried. In 1855, James took his family to France and England for two years. He was a leader in various agricultural movements, and was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of New York. He was an outspoken opponent of slavery. James volunteered for the Union Army in 1861, and fought at the Battle of Bull Run and at Gettysburg. He was briefly Military Governor of Washington, D.C., and was nominated for Governor of New York in 1862. James commanded the Union troops at the Battle of The Wilderness in 1864, and died during the battle, reportedly after saying: "Steady boys. Come ahead. There isn't danger enough to harm a mouse." In 1868 he had an estate of 7,237 acres at Geneseo. The wil of James S. Wadsworth of Livingston, New York, dated 1856. recorded at Fulton Co., Ohio, states that he owned about 24,000 acres of land in Northwest Ohio, purchased fron the government in 1836. It mentions his children, Charles F. Wadsworth, Craig W. Wadsworth, James Wadsworth Jr., Cornelia, Nancy, and Elizabeth; nephew, Martin Brimmer; son-in-law, Montgomery Ritchie of Ritchey & Fitzhugh of New York City. His wife, Mary C. W. Wadsworth, is to have the home she was given in her fathers will dated 1837, and the home and library in New York City. He mentions various pieces of land formerly belonging to William A. Wadsworth, Livingston Wadsworth, and Herbert Wadsworth, infant children of William W. Wadsworth, and their mother, Emeline Wadsworth, and Charles James Murry, infant child of Elizabeth Wadsworth Murry.
m. 11 MAY 1834 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, Mary Craig Wharton , b. ABT 1811 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
6 children: Charles Frederick, Cornelia, Craig Wharton "Tic", Nancy Craig, James Wolcott, Elizabeth,
(8) Charles Frederick Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1835 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
m. Jessie Burden , b. , d. .
1 children: Mary Wharton.
(9) Mary Wharton Wadsworth (Charles Frederick Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Cornelia Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 APR 1837 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 22 SEP 1921 London,, England.
NotesCORNELIA met her second husband while touring England with her first husband. After his death she took her two sons to Paris where the eldest died a few years later. After her second marriage she lived in Ireland. She and her husband toured the American West in 1874, and she kept a diary of the experience which was published in 1918. In 1877 they purchased land in Donley Co., Texas, which became the J&A Ranch. It covered 336,000 acres, and grew to 500,000 acres in 1917. They kept 100,000 head of cattle on the ranch. Cornelia ran the ranch after her husband's death.
m. 1857 Montgomery Ritchie , b. Of Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 1864 Geneseo, Ontario Co., New York.
2 children: Arthur Montgomery, James Wadsworth "Jack".
(9) Arthur Montgomery Ritchie (Cornelia Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. ABT 1866 Paris, Seine, France.
(9) James Wadsworth "Jack" Ritchie (Cornelia Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1861 Geneseo, Ontario Co., New York, d. 1924 ,, England.
NotesJAMES graduated from Cambridge University in 1931. He worked for a while on his mother's ranch in Texas. He then enlisted for service in the Boer War in 1889 and became a Major. After the war he settled in England. He had a large art collection and was a pilot and photographer.
(8) Cornelia Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 APR 1837 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 22 SEP 1921 London,, England.
NotesCORNELIA met her second husband while touring England with her first husband. After his death she took her two sons to Paris where the eldest died a few years later. After her second marriage she lived in Ireland. She and her husband toured the American West in 1874, and she kept a diary of the experience which was published in 1918. In 1877 they purchased land in Donley Co., Texas, which became the J&A Ranch. It covered 336,000 acres, and grew to 500,000 acres in 1917. They kept 100,000 head of cattle on the ranch. Cornelia ran the ranch after her husband's death.
m. 1869 John G. Adair , b. 1823 ,, Ireland, d. 1885 ,, Texas.
(8) Craig Wharton "Tic" Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1841 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1 JAN 1872 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesCRAIG was mustered in as a Lieutenant in the Union Army in September 1861, and served as an aide to Gen. John F. Reynolds. After Reynold's death in 1863, he joined the staff of Gen. John Burford. He was brevetted Major, Lt. Colonel, and was made Colonel 13 March 1864. He resigned his comission 16 July 1864. In 1868 he was living at Geneseo.
m. 31 MAR 1869 Evelyn Willing Peters , b. 1845 , d. 1885 .
2 children: Craig Wharton, James Samuel "Jim Sam".
(9) Craig Wharton Wadsworth (Craig Wharton "Tic" Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1872 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1960 .
(9) James Samuel "Jim Sam" Wadsworth (Craig Wharton "Tic" Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 FEB 1870 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 3 JUL 1930 Buffalo, Erie Co., New York.
NotesJAMES graduated from Harvard University. In 1916 he enlisted as a Private and went to the Mexican border. He was comissioned a Lieutenant at Spartanburg, South Carolina, and served as a Captain in the Hq. Trp., 27th Div. overseas during World War I. He led a colorful life, backed a musical comedy, owned a stable of racing horses, divorced his wife and remarried, fought in the war, and lost most of his money. He was Master of the Genesee Valley Hunt.
(8) Nancy Craig Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
m. 25 OCT 1866 M. Edward Rogers , b. , d. .
2 children: James Wadsworth, Harriet Ruggles.
(9) James Wadsworth Rogers (Nancy Craig Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(9) Harriet Ruggles Rogers (Nancy Craig Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) James Wolcott Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 OCT 1846 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 24 DEC 1926 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJAMES was preparing to enter Yale College when word came of his father's death in battle. He immediately enlisted in the Army, and was appointed a Captain on the staff of Maj. Gen. G.K. Warren, commanding the 5th Army Corps of the Potomac. He was brevetted a Major for gallantry at Five Forks, 1 April 1865. After the war he managed the family estates at Geneseo, New York and built a large house called "Hartford House. He loved baseball, and financed teams on which his son, Jimmy, played. He also was a fan of harness racing. James was active in Republican politics. He was elected to the New York State Assembly, 1878-1879; State Comptroller, 1880-1881. In 1881 he was elected to fill an unexpired term in the U.S. House of Representatives, Eldridge G. Lapham, and the next year was elected for a new term from the 27th district in the 47th and 48th Congress. He served in the 52nd - 58th congress, 1891-1905 from the 13th district and served as chairman of the Committee on Agriculture. In 1898, James was given an Honorary MA degree by Yale University. He was then appointed to the State Racing Commission, and in 1915 was a member of the State Constitutional Convention. He was for many years President of the Geneseo National Bank and of the Genesee River National Bank.
m. Maria Louisa "Eloise" Travers , b. ABT 1843 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 6 MAY 1931 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
2 children: James Wolcott, Harriet.
(9) James Wolcott Wadsworth (James Wolcott Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 AUG 1877 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 21 JUN 1952 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJAMES worked summers as a laborer on his father's farm, and at one time managed his aunt Cornelia's ranch. He attended St. Mark's School and graduated from Yale University. He left school to enlist as a Private in the Spanish American War, and later visited the Phillipines as a civilian. He inherited "Hartford House" from his father. He was a member of the New York State Assembly from Livingston County from 1904 to 1910, and was elected Speaker from 1906 to 1910. He was elected U.S. Senator for New York from 1914 to 1926, and was Chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee. James was a leader in the anti-suffrage movement, and president of the company that published an anti-suffrage newspaper. He and was a member of Congress for eight terms from the 39th District of New York, beginning in 1934 until 1949. James was the Honorary President of the National Defense League. He was United States Ambassador to the United Nations from 1960 to 1961.
(9) Harriet Wadsworth (James Wolcott Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 OCT 1881 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
NotesHARRIET was the author of "Around the World in 80 years on a Sidesaddle", published in 1966, and "Thoughts in the Night" published in 1967, and others.
(8) Elizabeth Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1849 , d. .
m. Arthur Post , b. , d. .
1 children: Helen Agnes.
(9) Helen Agnes Post (Elizabeth Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. 1 SEP 1962 .
(8) Elizabeth Wadsworth (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1849 , d. .
m. 28 FEB 1889 Arthur Hugh Barrymore , b. , d. 21 SEP 1844 .
1 children: Dorothy Elizabeth.
(9) Dorothy Elizabeth Barrymore (Elizabeth Wadsworth8, James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(7) William Wolcott Wadsworth (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1806 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
NotesWILLIAM remained a bachelor.
m. 5 JAN 1846 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Emeline Austin , b. 27 NOV 1808 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
3 children: William Austin, Livingston, Herbert.
(8) William Austin Wadsworth (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1847 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
NotesWILLIAM lived alone until mid-life, in "The Homestead", which he inherited from his mother. He introduced fox hunting into the Genessee Valley in 1876. The Genessee Valley Hunt is the third oldest in the country. He served in the Rough Riders during the Spanish American War, and in the 101st Cav. Bde. in France during World War I.
m. Elizabeth Perkins , b. Of Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
1 children: William Perkins.
(9) William Perkins Wadsworth (William Austin Wadsworth8, William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1906 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1982 .
NotesWILLIAM lived in "The Homestead" after the death of his mother. He was Master of the Genessee Valley Hunt from 1932 to 1975.
(8) Livingston Wadsworth (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1849 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1855 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
(8) Herbert Wadsworth (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1851 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
m. Blow , b. , d. .
(7) Cornelia Wadsworth (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1810 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
(7) Elizabeth Wadsworth (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUL 1815 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 8 DEC 1851 Cairo,, Egypt.
NotesELIZABETH was considered beautiful and talented, and was courted by many men. She met her future husband when he visited America in 1834. Her father refused to consent to this marriage, but after his death she visited England and married Charles there in Westminster Abbey. She died following complications caused by the birth of her son.
m. 12 DEC 1850 London,, England, Charles Augustus Murray , b. 22 NOV 1806 ,, Scotland, d. 3 JUN 1895 .
1 children: Charles James.
(8) Charles James Murray (Elizabeth Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1851 , d. 25 SEP 1929 .
NotesCHARLES was educated at Eton. He visited his mother's family in 1880. He purchased the Lochcarron estate, including Courthill House, in 1882. He lost part of his fortune during World War I, and then came to live primarily at Courthill House. He served as a Member of Parliament.
m. 9 AUG 1875 Anne Frenchesca Wihelmina Finch , b. , d. 16 JAN 1933 .
3 children: Sybil Louise, Alasdair, .
(9) Sybil Louise Murray (Charles James Murray8, Elizabeth Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JAN 1876 , d. .
(9) Alasdair Murray (Charles James Murray8, Elizabeth Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. 1900 .
NotesALASDAIR died of wounds received in battle during the Boer War.
(9) Murray (Charles James Murray8, Elizabeth Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1881 , d. 1885 .
(6) Samuel Wolcott (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 DEC 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 FEB 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Elihu Wolcott (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 27 NOV 1806 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Rachel McClure , b. 29 OCT 1783 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1822 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
7 children: Elizabeth Ann, Elihu, Hannah McClure, Samuel, Arthur, Elizur, Frances Jane.
(7) Elizabeth Ann Wolcott (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 DEC 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Carlton H. Perry , b. 1802 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
2 children: Howard Wolcott, Katharine Wolcott "Kate".
(8) Howard Wolcott Perry (Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Katharine Wolcott "Kate" Perry (Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1820 ,, Illinois, d. NOV 1924 Capri, Isola Di Capri, Italy.
NotesKATHERINE resided on the Isle of Capri, Italy, with her cousin, Sarah Morrison Wolcott. When her cousin died in 1918, she returned to America. Her escort, sent from America to accompany her home was held for two days, having the same name as a noted spy operating in France. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1916.
(7) Elihu Wolcott (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1808 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(7) Hannah McClure Wolcott (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JUN 1811 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 AUG 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Kirby , b. 2 JUL 1805 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 20 DEC 1851 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
7 children: Edward Payson, William Arthur, Frances Caroline, Katherine Wolcott, Helen McClure, Henry Burgess, Elizabeth Pomeroy "Bessie".
(8) Edward Payson Kirby (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 OCT 1833 Blackstone's Grove, Will Co., Illinois, d. 25 FEB 1917 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesEDWARD graduated from Illinois College in 1854 and taught at the West Jacksonville School, where he became Principal. He read law and was admitted to the Illinois bar in 1862, after which he opened a practace at Jacksonville. He received his LLD degree in 1880. He was a lawyer and a Morgan County Judge at Jacksonville, Illinois, and a trustee of Illinois College. He had no children in 1880. He was a member of the Illinois State Historical Society, and joined the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1896 as a descendant of Gen. Erastus Wolcott.
m. 28 OCT 1862 Julia Smith Duncan , b. , d. 5 JUL 1896 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Edward Payson Kirby (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 OCT 1833 Blackstone's Grove, Will Co., Illinois, d. 25 FEB 1917 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesEDWARD graduated from Illinois College in 1854 and taught at the West Jacksonville School, where he became Principal. He read law and was admitted to the Illinois bar in 1862, after which he opened a practace at Jacksonville. He received his LLD degree in 1880. He was a lawyer and a Morgan County Judge at Jacksonville, Illinois, and a trustee of Illinois College. He had no children in 1880. He was a member of the Illinois State Historical Society, and joined the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1896 as a descendant of Gen. Erastus Wolcott.
m. 1898 ,, Illinois, Lucinda Gallaher , b. , d. .
(8) William Arthur Kirby (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 AUG 1837 Mendon, Adams Co., Illinois, d. ABT 1922 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesWILLIAM was a Captain in the Civil War. He was a soap maker at Jacksonville, Illinois, in 1880, age 43, with Arabella 38, Clement 11, Harry 7, and Marian 3. He was a member of the Wolcott Society 1916-20, residing at Jacksonville, Illinois.
m. 10 SEP 1867 Arabella Clement , b. 23 MAR 1842 Port Mills,, Vermont, d. 31 DEC 1910 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
4 children: Clement Rufus, Henry Wolcott, Marian Dorothy, William Joshua.
(9) Clement Rufus Kirby (William Arthur Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 JUL 1868 South Pass,, Illinois, d. .
NotesCLEMENT was a Captain in the Ordnance Department at Brownsville, Texas, in 1919.
(9) Henry Wolcott Kirby (William Arthur Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1872 South Pass,, Illinois, d. .
NotesHENRY was at Jacksonville, Illinois, in 1880. He was a dentist at Sebring, Florida, in 1923.
(9) Marian Dorothy Kirby (William Arthur Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1876 South Pass,, Illinois, d. .
NotesMARION was DAR member #10996.
(9) William Joshua Kirby (William Arthur Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 JUL 1883 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .

m. 1 AUG 1861 James McLaughlin , b. 25 OCT 1829 , d. 17 AUG 1870 .
5 children: William Kirby, Bessie, Harry James, Frank Wolcott, Helen Margaret.
(9) William Kirby McLaughlin (Frances Caroline Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JAN 1862 Red Bluff, Tehama Co., California, d. .
(9) Bessie McLaughlin (Frances Caroline Kirby8, Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 JAN 1864 Red Bluff, Tehama Co., California, d. .
