(9) Alfred Whitney Griswold (Harold Ely Griswold8, William Noyes Griswold7, William Frederick Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 OCT 1906 Morristown, Morris Co., New Jersey, d. 19 APR 1963 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesALFRED received his B.A. from Yale in 1929 and Ph.D. in 1933. He was instructor in History in 1933, Research Assistant in International Relations in 1935; Assistant Professor of Government and International Relations in 1938; Associate Professor in 1942; and Director, United States Army Specialized Training Program, Foreign area and Language Studies; and Director, United States Army Civil Affairs Training School. He was an Alumni Trustee, The Hotchkiss School in 1943 and Professor of History at Yale in 1947. In 1948 he published "Farming and Democracy" and in 1950 was elected President of Yale University. He received Honorary Degrees from Harvard University, Princeton University, Trinity College, Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Brown University, Columbia University, the University of Pennsylvania, Wesleyan University, Johns Hopkins University, Williams College and the University of Bridgeport.

(6) Robert Harper Griswold (Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1806 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 1882 .

m. Helen Maria Powers , b. 1820 , d. 1899 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
4 children: Louise Augusta, Helen Adele "Adele", Robert Harper, Florence.
(7) Louise Augusta Griswold (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1841 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 12 APR 1896 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesLOUISE was the organist for the First Congregational Church at Old Lyme for 40 years.
(7) Helen Adele "Adele" Griswold (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 MAR 1844 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 FEB 1913 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesHELEN and her sister, Florence, lived in the family home after their mother's death, taking in borders and selling plants and vegetables from their garden to make ends meet. In 1899 the artist, Henry Ward Ranger, came to board with them, and he encouraged other artists to stay there and to form an artist's colony at Old Lyme. Shortly after the colony was formed, Adele got tuberculosis and went to live in a sanitarium at Hartford, after which Florence ran the boarding house.
(7) Robert Harper Griswold (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1847 , d. 21 SEP 1864 .
NotesROBERT died of dyptheheria at age 16.
(Medical):ROBERT died of Dyptheria at age 16.
(7) Florence Griswold (Robert Harper Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 DEC 1850 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 6 DEC 1937 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesFLORENCE ran the family home as a boarding house for artists and an art gallery after her sister moved to a sanitarium. In 1921 the Lyme Art Association opened a gallery next to her home on land she gave them for this purpose. She was considered a patron of the American Impressionist movement. She became the first manager of the gallery, receiving a percentage of the sales. In 1936 a conservator was appointed for her and her property sold, but she retained life tenancy. The home is now th "Florence Griswold Museum.

(8) Sarah Spencer Lane (William Griswold Lane7, Frances Ann Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 MAR 1853 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 19 JAN 1935 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(8) Wolcott Griswold Lane (William Griswold Lane7, Frances Ann Griswold6, Roger Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JAN 1866 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 11 NOV 1956 .
NotesWOLCOTT graduated from Yale University with a degree in law in 1888. He was a lawyer and argued before the New York Surogate Court. He was one of the Executors of the will of William Augustus Spencer who died in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, as well as executor for Williams brother, Lorrilard Spencer. His transcripts of the papers of Roger Griswold are in the Connecticut Historical Society.

(4) Oliver Wolcott (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1726 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 DEC 1797 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesOLIVER WOLCOTT, born 20 Nov. 1726 Windsor, Connecticut; died 1 Dec. 1797 Litchfield, Connecticut, buried East Cemetery, Litchfield. Oliver graduated first in his class from Yale in 1747. In the same year he was commissioned a Captain by Gov. Clinton of New York and raised a company of men which he lead in defense of the northern frontiers against the French and the Indians. After the peace of Aix-la-Chapelle his unit was disbanded and he returned to Connecticut and studied medicine under his brother, Alexander. Oliver moved from Goshen, Connecticut, to Litchfield about 1750. In that year his father was elected Governor of Connecticut. From 1751 to 1771 he was Sheriff of Litchfield County. In 1753 he built a large house at Litchfield, on land given him by his father. This home is the oldest house at Litchfield, and was lately occupied by his descendant, Mrs. Alice Wolcott Sherman. Washington and Lafayette visited the home, and Washington stayed here on his visit to Litchfield in 1780. He married Laura Collins 21 January 1755, by whom he had five children, one dying in infancy. One son, Oliver Wolcott. Jr., was a Governor of Connecticut. Oliver was elected a Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1764 and served until 1770. He was an Assistant to the Governor from 1771 to 1786. He was also a Judge of Probate from 1772 to 1795, and chief Judge of the Court of Common Pleas from 1774 to 1786. He rose through the ranks of the Connecticut militia, from Captain to Major-General. In 1775, he was appointed one of the Commissioners of Indian Affairs, charged with inducing the Indians to remain neutral during the struggle with Great Britain. He was appointed as a representative of Connecticut to the Continental Congress in 1776, taking his seat there in January, 1776. Becoming ill in June, during the discussion of the Declaration of Independence, he returned to Connecticut. He led fourteen units of the Connecticut militia to the defense of New York. On 9 July, 1776, a group of patriots tore down the lead statue of George III on Bowling Green in New York City. Oliver had it taken by cart to his home at Litchfield. His family and neighbors melted the lead in the Wolcott's apple orchard, molding 42,000 bullets for Washington's army. He returned to Philadelphia where he signed his name to the Declaration of Independence on 4 September 1776. Oliver spent the summer of 1777 recruiting troops from Connecticut, and with the rank of Major General, he commanded the Connecticut militia at the Battle of Saratoga, where British General Burgoyne was defeated. He rejoined the Continental Congress at York, Pennsylvania, and went with it when it moved to Baltimore in the winter of 1777-8. He signed the Articles of Confederation as representative for Connecticut on 15 Nov, 1777. In 1779 he commanded a division of militia defending the Connecticut coast. In 1780, he was one of the three commissioners appointed to arrange for supplies for the French troops at Newport, Rhode Island. He served with the militia until 1780, and, except for 1799, he represented Connecticut in the Continental Congress until 1784. In 1784 and 1785 he was one of the Commissioners for Indian Affairs charged with establishing terms of peace with the Iroquois. He helped negotiate the "Purchase of 1784", which legally cleared all Indians from the land northwest of the Allegheny River. Oliver, and his sons, Oliver and Frederick, were given land grants at Elmore, New Hampshire, for his service in the wars. He was also given land near Wolcott, New Hampshire, named for him because of his support for making New Hampshire a state. He was a member of the Susquehanna Company, a group of Connecticut investors who sold land in the Wyoming Valley to settlers. This land was claimed by both Connecticut and Pennsylvania. At a meeting of the Susquehanna Company in 1785, he is said to have presented a draft of a constitution for a new state in that area, to be called "Westmoreland". He was involved in negotiations for resolving the "Wyoming Controversy". The resuts of this negotiation was that the Wyoming Valley belonged to Pennsylvania. He was also involved in negotiating a land dispute between Vermont and New York. Oliver was a slave owner. In 1786 he freed a slave named Caesar, giving him the surname, Jamus. In 1790, his family at Litchfield consisted of 3 males over 16, 1 female, and 6 slaves. From 1786 to 1796 Oliver was Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut. He was an ardent Federalist. He was granted an honorary LLD degree by Yale University. In 1796 he was a Presidential Elector and voted for John Adams. Upon the death of Governor Huntington, he became Governor of Connecticut, holding office until he died the following year. The town of Farmingbury, Connecticut, changed it's name to Wolcott when Oliver cast the tie-breaking vote in 1796, to allow it to seperate from the town of Waterbury, of which it had been a part. Oliver was described as tall, erect, and dignified, with a dark complexion. Two portraits of him, painted by Ralph Earle, have survived. One was presented to the State Senate of Connecticut by his grandson, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. It is now in the Connecticut State Library. The other is owned by the Connecticut Historical Society. Oliver's letters and papers are deposited with the Connecticut Historical Society. His statue was one of those placed on the Connecticut State House, added in 1916 by a vote of various Connecticut patriotic societies.
m. 21 JAN 1755 Laura Collins , b. 1 JAN 1732 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1794 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
5 children: Oliver, Oliver, Laura, Mariann, Frederick,
(5) Oliver Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 AUG 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 SEP 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(5) Oliver Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 JAN 1760 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JUN 1833 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended Nathaniel Beckwith's grammar school, and in 1773 enrolled at Yale College. He served with the Litchfield militia in 1777 when they fought to keep the British from capturing the colonist's supplies at Danbury. He graduated from Yale in 1778, at the age of 18, and served as an military aide to his father in 1779. He studied law at Litchfield, and was admitted to the bar in 1781. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. Oliver began practicing law in Hartford, and became a clerk in the state Treasury office, and was a member of the pay-table committee from 1782 to 1788, Connecticut State Comptroller of Public Accounts 1788-9, Auditor 1789-91, Comptroller of the U.S. Treasury 1791-5, and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury 1795-1800, succeeding Alexander Hamilton in the Cabinets of Presidents Washington and Adams. He resigned due to slander from his Republican opponents, being accused of starting a fire in the Treasury office to conceal peculations. Oliver was appointed by President Adams as a Judge of the Circuit Court in 1801, and served until 1802. He then established a mercantile business in New York City, where he was President of the Merchants' Bank of the City of New York from 1803 to 1804. He was living in Ward 2, New York City, in 1810, with a family of 1 male born before 1765 (Oliver), 1 male born 1765-85 (servant ?), 2 males born 1800-10 (Oliver, John), 2 females born 1775-85 (servants ?), and 2 females born 1785-95 (Laura, Elizabeth). These may have included his Negro servants, Julia b. 1780, Peggy Zillah born 1786, Chloe born 1788, and Chloe born 1791. He was one of the founders, and President of the Bank of North America from 1812 to 1814. Oliver and his brother, Frederick, established a large woolen mill on the Naugatuck River in Torrington Township in 1813, and the village of Orleans there was changed to Wolcottville in their honor. This became the city of Torrington in 1881. In 1815 Oliver was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Connecticut on the Democratic ticket. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1817, and was President of the Connecticut Constitutional Convention in 1818. He served as Governor until 1827. He was an ardent Federalist, an intimated friend and advisor of Washington, Adams and Hamilton, and for some time was the last surviving member of Washington's Cabinet. Oliver was associated with Julius Demming and Benjamin Tallmadge in the Litchfield China Trading Company. One of their ships, "The Trident", sailed between America and China for 14 years. Oliver was Grand Master of the Masonic Lodge of Connecticut from 1818 to 1820. He was awarded honorary LLD degrees from Yale, Princeton, and Brown Universities. Oliver purchased a large home at Litchfield near his father's house where his brother, Frederick, lived. He planted 13 sycamore trees along South St. at Litchfield, commemorating the 13 colonies. All but one of these were killed by disease, so Oliver and his brother planted elm trees to replace them. After retiring from public service, Oliver lived with his son, John, in New York City. His will left "to my beloved and only surviving son, Doctor John Stoughton Wolcott, who resides with me and is the protector of my declining years," all his books and papers and household effects and his home and property at Litchfield; $100 to his son-in-law William Gracie; and the remainder to be divided between his children, John and Laura. He requested that John provide for the support and education of his grandson, Oliver WolcottIV. In 1844 his sole surviving heirs were Mrs. Laura Gibbs of New York City, and a grandson, Oliver Wolcott of Litchfield, Connecticut.

"28 Jan. 1796, Philadelphia: letter from Wm. V. Murray to George McHenry on his nomination as Secretary of War: ... as to the Salary, it will maintain you in that easy style of elegant but quiet accomodation which I think you love at all events it does Wolcott & Pickering. The first lives in Fourth South, at the corner of Spruce, in a
neat house of two rooms, one small, on a floor and must I think live within his means. He is a very worthy man & quite equal to his duty; his wife one of the mildest & most amiable women in town an excellent manager, kind but economical.

Oliver's portrait was presented to the Connecticut State Senate by his son, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. A facimile of it was put on the 2 cent Revenue Stamp in 1945. His letters and papers were deposited with the Conneticut Historical Society.

A painting of Oliver dated 1806 said to have been painted in 1806 for the Hon. Josiah Quincy and bequeathed by him to Oliver Wolcott Gibbs (1822-1908); or alternatively, it was given by the subject to his daughter, Mrs. George Gibbs III (Laura Wolcott), who gave it to her son, Oliver Wolcott Gibbs. Oliver Wolcott Gibbs' niece, Laura Henriette d'Oremieulx, later Mrs. J. West Roosevelt, New York, great-granddaughter of the subject; her gift in 1933 to her son, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, New York (died July 15, 1953); owned by 1966, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, Jr., Birmingham, Alabama (on permanent loan to Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham, in 1997, still owned by O.W. Roosevelt, Jr.. A copy of this portrait is owned by George Gibbs, New York. See also the copy by G.L. Nelson owned by New-York Historical Society, New York. This copy by Nelson is owned by First National City Bank of New York (Citibank). A copy is at the United States Treasury Department.
m. 1 JUN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth Stoughton , b. 27 OCT 1767 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 SEP 1805 New York City, New York.
7 children: John Stoughton, Oliver, Laura, Elizabeth Stoughton, Oliver Stoughton, John Stoughton, Henry.
(6) John Stoughton Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 AUG 1787 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 4 FEB 1789 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(6) Oliver Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAY 1790 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 17 JUL 1791 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(6) Laura Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 APR 1794 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 10 DEC 1870 New York City, New York.
NotesLAURA was strong and fortright, according to her grandson. She was an ardent abolitionist, and helped hide runaway slaves in New York City. Later in life she became an amateur artist.
m. 27 DEC 1810 New York City, New York, George Gibbs , b. 7 JAN 1776 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, d. 6 AUG 1833 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
7 children: George, Mary, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza", Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott", Alfred, Laura Wolcott, Francis Sarason.
(7) George Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 JUL 1815 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 19 APR 1873 New Haven, Oswego Co., New York.
NotesGEORGE attended the Round Hill School of Northampton, and graduated from Harvard College in 1838. In his early 20s he travelled extensively in Europe, making scetches of towns in Germany and Switzerland. This sketch book was in the possession of his descendant, Robert Nowell Williams Jr.. He was a lawyer, antiquarian, and Librarian of the New York Historical Society. In 1846 he published "Memoirs of the Administration of Washington and John Adams, Edited from the Papers of Oliver Wolcott, Secretary of the Treasury". George marched overland from St. Louis to Oregon in 1854. He was appointed Collector of the Port of Astoria, Oregon, in 1854, and served on the Boundary Commission. He was appointed to the boundary survey team in 1857. In 1860 he returned East and was employed by the Smithsonian Institution editing documents about Indian culture. He was the author of several works on Indian languages published by the Smithsonian. He moved to New Haven, Connecticut in 1871. He gave the chest owned by Henry Wolcott, the immigrant, to the Connecticut Historical Society. He married his first cousin.
m. 11 APR 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, Mary Kane Gibbs , b. 19 JAN 1827 , d. 18 DEC 1876 .
(7) Mary Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1818 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 2 JUN 1820 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
(7) Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JUL 1819 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 25 AUG 1906 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
m. 2 APR 1844 New York City, New York, Lucius Tuckerman , b. 19 MAR 1818 Chelsea, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1890 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
9 children: Lucius Carey, Alfred, Walter Cary, Laura Wolcott, Rupert, Emily, Bayard, Paul, Lucy.
(8) Lucius Carey Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 AUG 1846 , d. 23 SEP 1849 .
(8) Alfred Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JAN 1848 , d. 24 MAY 1925 .

(9) Wolcott Tuckerman (Walter Cary Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 APR 1880 , d. 15 FEB 1973 King, San Bernardino Co., California.
NotesWOLCOTT lived at Ipswich, Massachusetts from 1903 to 1913, and then moved to a ranch at Carpinteria, California.
(9) Walter Rupert Tuckerman (Walter Cary Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 DEC 1882 , d. 15 JAN 1961 .
(8) Laura Wolcott Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 AUG 1850 ,, New York, d. 9 FEB 1914 .
m. 9 APR 1891 Washington, District of Columbia, James Lowndes , b. , d. .
(8) Rupert Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 DEC 1851 , d. 23 NOV 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
(8) Emily Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 NOV 1853 ,, New York, d. .
(8) Bayard Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JUL 1855 New York City, New York, d. ABT 1920 .
NotesBAYARD graduated from Harvard in 1878; studied in Europe, and wrote on literary and historical subjects for periodicals. In 1880 he is described as an iron merchant, living with his parents at New York City. In 1898 he became lecturer on English Literature at Princeton University, a position he still held in 1903. He was the author of: "History of England Prose Fiction" (1882); "Life of General Lafayette with a Critical Estimate of his Character and Public Acts" (1889); and edited with an introduction, "Diary of Philip Hone" (1889); "Peter Stuyvesant" (1893); "William Jay and the Abolition of Slavery" (1893) and "Life of General Philip Schuyler" (1903). He was on the New York City Social Register.
m. 26 SEP 1882 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, Anna Osgood Smith , b. 20 FEB 1862 New York City, New York, d. .
4 children: Elisabeth Wolcott, May Appleton, Bayard, Joan Cotton.
(9) Elisabeth Wolcott Tuckerman (Bayard Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JUL 1882 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(9) May Appleton Tuckerman (Bayard Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 NOV 1886 ,, New York, d. .
(9) Bayard Tuckerman (Bayard Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 APR 1889 Morristown, Morris Co., New Jersey, d. MAR 1968 .
NotesBAYARD was a horse breeder and racetrack executive.
(9) Joan Cotton Tuckerman (Bayard Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 APR 1891 , d. .
(8) Paul Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 NOV 1856 ,, New York, d. .
NotesPAUL is described as an iron merchantat New York City in 1880. He built a large home at Tuxedo Park, New York, and was one of the original trustees of the Tuxedo Park Library.
m. 3 MAR 1886 Susan Minturn , b. 3 MAR 1865 , d. .
1 children: Dorothy.
(9) Dorothy Tuckerman (Paul Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 NOV 1889 Tuxedo Park, Orange Co., New York, d. 10 MAR 1969 .
NotesDOROTHY was one of the leading interior decorators of her time. She founded the Architectural Clearing House in 1925. The business was later renamed Dorothy Draper & Co. he decorated hotels, apartment houses, restaurants and the private homes of the wealthy. She had three children.
(8) Lucy Tuckerman (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 FEB 1858 Staten Island, Richmond Co., New York, d. 12 MAY 1904 .
m. 16 NOV 1882 Arthur George Sedgwick , b. 6 OCT 1844 New York City, New York, d. 14 JUL 1915 Pittsfield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Grace Ashburner, Susan Ridley.
(9) Grace Ashburner Sedgwick (Lucy Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 OCT 1883 , d. 23 JUN 1961 .
(9) Susan Ridley Sedgwick (Lucy Tuckerman8, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 SEP 1886 New York City, New York, d. .
(7) Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott" Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 FEB 1822 New York City, New York, d. 9 DEC 1908 .
NotesOLIVER dropped his first name at an early age, and called himself "Wolcott Gibbs". He entered Columbia College in 1837 and graduated in 1841. He then attended the College of Physicians and Surgeons there, qualifying as a medical doctor in 1845. He studied chemistry at the University of Berlin in the laboratories of Rose and Rammelsberg, and subsequently spent five months with Liebig in Giessen, returning to America in 1848. In that year he became professor of Chemistry at the Free Academy, which later became the University of the City of New York. In 1863 he became Rumsford Professor of Science at Harvard University which he held until his retirement in 1887. During the Civil War he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Sanitary Comission. In 1873 he was granted a LLD degree, and was appointed comissioner to the Vienna Exhibition. he was an honorary member of the German Chemical Society and the London Chemical Society, and one of the original members of the National Academy of Scienc. He is credited for introducing research into university requirements. In organic and analytical chemistry he discovered many new substances and developed new methods. His study of complex ammonia bases, double compounds, acids of metal, and metals of the platinum group, contributed markedly to the science of chemistry.
m. 1853 Josephine Mauran , b. , d. 16 FEB 1887 .
(7) Alfred Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 APR 1823 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 26 DEC 1868 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesALFRED graduated from the West Point Military Academy in 1846, and served in the Mexican War. As a Captain in the Civil War, he was taken prisoner by the Confederates and exchanged 27 August 1862. He was commissioned Colonel of the 130th New York Regiment of Volunteers on 6 September 1862. He reorganized his regiment as the 1st New York Dragoons in August 1863. He was appointed Brigadier General 19 Oct. 1864, and commanded a Brigade under Gen. Sheridan until 1865. He was present at the surrender of Gen. Lee. He mustered out of the army as a Major General 1 February 1866. He was then made a Major in the 7th U.S. Cavalry on 28 July 1866, serving under Gen. George Custer.
m. 27 DEC 1856 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, Peggy Forshee Blair , b. JAN 1825 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, d. 25 JUL 1908 .
2 children: Alfred Wolcott, John Blair "Blair".
(8) Alfred Wolcott Gibbs (Alfred Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 OCT 1856 Fort Filmore,, New Mexico, d. 19 MAY 1922 Wayne, Delaware Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesALFRED attended Rutgers College 1873-1874, and Stevens Institute of Technology 1874-1878, and entered railroad employment in 1879. He was a master mechanic and was Chief Mechanical Engineer on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

1 children: Marianne Skelton.

m. 26 FEB 1884 James West Roosevelt , b. 2 JUL 1858 , d. 10 APR 1896 .
5 children: Lewis West, Lorraine D'Oremieulx, Harold West, Oliver Wolcott, Nicholas.
(9) Lewis West Roosevelt (Laura Henriette Oremieulx8, Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 AUG 1885 , d. 12 JUN 1892 .
(9) Lorraine D'Oremieulx Roosevelt (Laura Henriette Oremieulx8, Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 JAN 1887 New York City, New York, d. 1965 .
(9) Harold West Roosevelt (Laura Henriette Oremieulx8, Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1888 , d. 9 APR 1892 .
(9) Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt (Laura Henriette Oremieulx8, Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 NOV 1890 New York City,, New York, d. 15 JUL 1953 New York City,, New York.
NotesOLIVER was a first cousin once removed of President Theodore Roosevelt. He graduated from Harvaard in 1912 and served in World Wat I. He was manager of a branch of the Farmers Loan & Trust Co. of New York, located in France, during World War I. He lived at Woodmere, Long Island, New York.

"The wedding of Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt of this city, a son of Mrs. J. West Roosevelt and the late Dr. J. West Roosevelt, who was a cousin of the late President Roosevelt, and Mrs. Verdery Akin McMichael, a daughter of Mrs. John W. Akin of Atlanta, Ga., and the late Judge Akin, was solemnized quietly at 12 o'clock yesterday noon..

1930 Hewlett NY
Oliver W Roosevelt 41, b. NY, stock broker
Verdery E Roosevelt 42, b. GA
J West Roosevelt 12, b. France
Oliver W Roosevelt 3, b. NY
Gardiner Blake 21, chauffeur


1940 Hempstead NY:
Oliver W Roosevelt 49
Verdery Roosevelt 51
Oliver Roosevelt 13
Malloy Terrall 30

Injuries Kill Oliver Roosevelt NEW YORK--VP--Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, 60, a distant cousin of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, cited last night of injuries suffered In an accidental five-story fall from his Manhattan apartment. Roosevelt's wife told police he slipped and fell through an open low-silled bedroom window Tuesday night. Roosevelt was an Investment banker.
(9) Nicholas Roosevelt (Laura Henriette Oremieulx8, Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 JUN 1893 New York City, New York, d. FEB 1982 .
NotesNICHOLAS was U. S. Minister to Hungary. Roger Dodd Wolcott reported: "Nicholas Roosevelt told me in Washington that he and his wife had most of the Wolcott furniture and silver."

Nicholas Roosevelt was an American diplomat and journalist. A member of the Roosevelt family and first-cousin once removed of U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt, he was born in New York City to James West Roosevelt, a brother of Hilborne Roosevelt, and Laura Henrietta d'Oremieulx. Brought up in Oyster Bay, New York, he graduated from Harvard University in 1914. He was an attach at the American Embassy in Paris, secretary to the American mission to Spain in 1916 and 17, vice-governor of the Philippine Islands in 1930, and U.S. minister to Hungary from 1930 to 1933. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and a writer for its journal Foreign Affairs, and a foreign correspondent and editorial writer for the New York Times and New York Herald Tribune from 1921 to 1946. A prolific author, his autobiography, A Front Row Seat (1953), offers a critical view of Franklin D. Roosevelt, a distant cousin, and an inside view of the New York Times. [6] Theodore Roosevelt (1967) drew on Nicholas Roosevelt's unique childhood recollections, his father having been a close friend of Theodore. He was married to Tirzah Gates, the daughter of Senator Egbert Gates. Her sister, Dorothy Gates, was the first wife of eminent astrophysicist Fritz Zwicky. He remained lifelong friends with Fritz Zwicky. He lived in Big Sur, California in later life.
(8) Leon F. Oremieulx (Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(7) Francis Sarason Gibbs (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JUN 1831 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 27 DEC 1882 New York City, New York.
NotesFRANCIS spent two years in Shanghai, China, as a resident agent for "Wolcott, Bates & Co.", a trading company. He returned to America and was in the grain exporting business in New York City. His firm failed when an English firm, which held the shipments on consignment, failed.
m. 6 JUN 1860 Eliza Gay Hosmer , b. 27 OCT 1836 New York City, New York, d. 24 NOV 1883 .
4 children: George, Annie Margaretta, Laura Wolcott, Lucius Tuckerman,
(8) George Gibbs (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 APR 1861 New York City, New York, d. 19 MAY 1940 .
NotesGEORGE was author of "The Gibbs Family of Rhode Island".
(8) Annie Margaretta Gibbs (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 DEC 1862 New York City, New York, d. 5 MAR 1922 .
(8) Laura Wolcott Gibbs (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1865 New York City, New York, d. 1 MAY 1951 Milwaukee, Milwaukee Co., Wisconsin.
NotesLAURA spent much time in Milwaukee with her children. Later she moved to New York to live with her brother, George. Her grandson, Robert Nowell Miller, Jr., has a silver service presented to her on her 25th wedding anniversary.

(8) Lucius Tuckerman Gibbs (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 FEB 1869 New York City, New York, d. JAN 1909 .
NotesLUCIUS was a drama critic for the New Yorker magazine.
m. 7 APR 1901 Angelica Singleton Duer , b. 1878 , d. .
2 children: Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott", Angelica Singleton.
(9) Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott" Gibbs (Lucius Tuckerman Gibbs8, Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 MAR 1902 New York City, New York, d. 16 AUG 1958 Fire Island, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesOLIVER, under the name Wolcott Gibbs, began his literary career as a copy reader for the New Yorker magazine in 1926. He worked a newspaper reporter, and in 1940 became a theatre critic. He was the author of numerous stories and articles published in leading magazines, especially the New Yorker. He was the author of a 1950 Broadway hit, "Season in the Sun".

m. Unknown , b. , d. .
(6) Elizabeth Stoughton Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 OCT 1795 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 2 JUL 1813 New York City, New York.
NotesELIZABETH died in the Gracie mansion of a hemmorhage on her wedding night.
m. 2 JUL 1813 New York City, New York, William Gracie , b. 28 NOV 1787 New York City, New York, d. .
(6) Oliver Stoughton Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 JAN 1800 ,, New York, d. 23 MAY 1832 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended the U. S. Military Academy at West Point, and then was attached as Midshipman to the "Chesapeake". After he left the Navy he settled in Litchfield, Connecticut, and then moved to New Jersey. Later, his father lived with him in New York City. An 1833 court case, DuBois v. Hepburn, says that Oliver S. Wolcott, lessee of the plaintiff of land in Lycoming County, was born in Connecticut, but was domiciled in the state of Pennsylvania on 25 Sept. 1830. A painting of him by an unknown artist is in the Frederick Co., Maryland Historical Society.
m. 9 NOV 1820 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Jane Lowe Conard , b. 17 SEP 1803 , d. 1845 .
3 children: Oliver, Oliver, Elizabeth Stoughton.
(7) Oliver Wolcott (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 NOV 1821 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 MAR 1823 .
(7) Oliver Wolcott (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1823 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 22 MAY 1856 San Francisco, San Francisco Co., California.
NotesOLIVER received his MD at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York City. He lived in Argentina and died unmarried.
(7) Elizabeth Stoughton Wolcott (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 JUL 1825 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 15 AUG 1825 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(6) John Stoughton Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 DEC 1802 New York City, New York, d. 22 NOV 1843 New York City, New York.
NotesJohn S. Wolcott of CT was admitted to West Point 1 Sept. 1818, age 15 yrs 8 mo.

John practiced medicine at Litchfield, and later in New York City, where his father lived with him. Paintings of his father and grandfather Wolcott were presented by him to the Connecticut Senate in 1834. In 1925, miniature portraits of him and of his father, and a Latin text book inscribed with his name were presented to Peter Clark Wolcott for the Wolcott Society by Mrs. Olive K. Walden. Her aunt had been engaged to John.

April 8, 1844, Alexandria Gazette (Virginia): DIED: In Litchfield, Conn. Dr. JOHN STOUGHTON WALCOTT. His death was occasioned by the effects of arsenic and morphine, applied to the cavities of two hollow teeth, for the purpose of destroying the sensitiveness of their nerves.
(6) Henry Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 SEP 1805 ,, New York, d. 25 SEP 1805 ,, New York.
(5) Laura Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1761 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 23 JAN 1814 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 6 OCT 1785 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Moseley , b. ABT 1758 , d. .
1 children: Charles.
(6) Charles Moseley (Laura Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 JUN 1786 , d. 29 MAR 1815 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Mariann Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 FEB 1765 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAR 1805 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesMariann's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Litchfield, Connecticut, Museum.
m. 13 OCT 1789 ,, Connecticut, Chauncey Goodrich , b. 20 OCT 1759 Durham Township, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 18 AUG 1815 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Frederick Wolcott (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 NOV 1767 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 28 MAY 1837 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK graduated from Yale College in 1786, delivering the the salutatorian oration in Latin. He was Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas in 1793, and clerk of the Superior Court at Litchfield in 1798. In 1796 he was appointed Judge of Probate. He inherited his parents home on South Street at Litchfield in 1797. His black servant, Hebe Williams died at Litchfield in 1803. Frederick was elected as Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1808, and in 1810 was elected to the State Senate, an office that he held until 1823. He was a partner with his brother, Oliver, in the development of the woolen mills at a place that became known as Wolcottville. He and his brother imported cattle from England and sheep from Spain, and worked to improve American breeds of cattle and sheep. During the Revolutionary War he provided public service in Connecticut. He and his wife sold 200 acres of land at Norwalk, Ohio in 1822, part of the estate of her first husband, Amos Cook.
m. 12 OCT 1800 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth "Betsey" Huntington , b. 8 NOV 1774 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1812 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
6 children: Mariann Goodrich, Hannah Huntington, Joshua Huntington, Elizabeth Huntington, Frederick Henry "Fred", Laura Maria.
(6) Mariann Goodrich Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1801 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 26 APR 1864 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
m. 22 MAY 1827 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Asa Whitehead , b. 26 MAY 1795 Livingston, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 2 JUN 1860 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
1 children: Frederick Wolcott.
(7) Frederick Wolcott Whitehead (Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 OCT 1846 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
NotesFREDERICK was a railroad clerk at Newark, New Jersey, in 1880, with Ada, Huntington, Aaron P., and Normee (?) Whitehead.
m. 13 AUG 1867 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Ada Italia Locker , b. 5 OCT 1849 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
7 children: Frederick Wolcott, Asa, Ada Birdette, Archer Wolcott, Huntington Wolcott, Aaron Pennington, Genevieve Elise.
(8) Frederick Wolcott Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAY 1868 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 24 JAN 1869 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Asa Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1869 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 15 AUG 1870 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Ada Birdette Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JAN 1872 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 26 AUG 1872 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Archer Wolcott Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JUN 1873 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 26 NOV 1873 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Huntington Wolcott Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JAN 1875 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.

(8) Genevieve Elise Whitehead (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 MAY 1878 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 1952 Volusia,, Florida.
NotesGENEVIEVE was DAR member #148548.
m. Rial Newland Denison , b. 1885 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York, d. .
1 children: Ruth Wolcott.
(9) Ruth Wolcott Denison (Genevieve Elise Whitehead8, Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1905 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York, d. .
(6) Hannah Huntington Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 JAN 1803 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 26 FEB 1838 Manayunk, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
m. 21 APR 1834 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Frederick Freeman , b. 1 DEC 1799 Sandwich, Barnstable Co., Massachusetts, d. 12 SEP 1883 Sandwich, Barnstable Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Huntington Wolcott, Hannah Huntington.
(7) Huntington Wolcott Freeman (Hannah Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 FEB 1835 New York City, New York, d. .
m. Clara Alexander , b. , d. .
(7) Hannah Huntington Freeman (Hannah Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 DEC 1837 Manayunk, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 30 JUN 1838 .
(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
m. 12 NOV 1844 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Cornelia Frothingham , b. 11 DEC 1824 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 1 JUN 1850 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Huntington Frothingham, Roger.
(7) Huntington Frothingham Wolcott (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 FEB 1846 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1865 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHUNTINGTON was comissioned 23 Oct. 1864 as a 2nd Lt. in I Co., 2nd Regiment, Massachusetts Cavalry, during the Civil War. He served as an aide to his relative, Gen. Alfred Gibbs. At the end of the war, he participated in a Grand Review at Washington D. C., and two days later took ill with "camp fever". He returned to his father's home, where he died a week later from typhoid.
(7) Roger Wolcott (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 JUL 1847 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 DEC 1900 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated from Harvard in 1870 and delivered the Class Oration. He received his LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1874, and was a lawyer at Boston. He was a Member of the Boston Common City Council, 1877-79; the House of Representatives, 1882-84; Lieutenant-Governor of Massachusetts, 1892-95; became Governor upon the death of Governor Greenhalge in 1896 and was elected Governor, 1897-1898. He was the first President of the Republican Club of Massachusetts in 1891, a member of the Massachusetts Historical Society, Society of the Cincinnati and Loyal Legion and Society of Colonial Wars. He was overseer of Harvard University, 1885-1895, and Director and Trustee in many business and charitable organizations. In 1891 he established funds at Harvard in memory of Hunting Frothington Wolcott to benefit the Peabody Museum, and in memory of Joshua Huntington Wolcott to benefit the Harvard Library. A large bronze statue of him by Daniel Chester French graces the main lobby of the Massachusetts State House in Boston.

1910 Milton MA:
Edith P Wolcott F 57y
William P Wolcott M 30y
Cornelia F Wolcott F 25y
Oliver Wolcott M 19y
Dehlia A Ryan F 27y
Margaret M Queeney F 64y
Margaret M Walsh F 28y
Catharine Kenney F 27y
Ellen Carbac F 43y
John G Madden M 36y
William Brennan M 19y
Robert Crellin M 23y

Find A Grave memorial No. 10634892.
m. 2 SEP 1874 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Edith Prescott , b. 20 APR 1853 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 JUN 1934 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
6 children: Huntington Frothingham, Roger, William Prescott "Prescott", Samuel Huntington, Cornelia Frothingham, Oliver.
(8) Huntington Frothingham Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1875 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 19 FEB 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Roger Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUL 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1965 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated cum laude from Harvard College in 1899. He served in the Spanish-American War and was a Major in the Infantry Officers Reserve Corps, in charge of the draft for Massachusetts, during World War I. He was a member of the Harvard Board of Overseers. He was also a members of the Advisory Board of Massachusetts General Hospital. His wife, Claire, seperated from him in 1923, saying "he had allowed their palatial home to become so dillapidated and run down" that she was unable to stay there. She left Milton, Connecticut, returned to Boston.

Find A Grave memorial No. 78346099.

3 children: Roger, Clarissa Endicott, John Endicott.

(8) Roger Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUL 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1965 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated cum laude from Harvard College in 1899. He served in the Spanish-American War and was a Major in the Infantry Officers Reserve Corps, in charge of the draft for Massachusetts, during World War I. He was a member of the Harvard Board of Overseers. He was also a members of the Advisory Board of Massachusetts General Hospital. His wife, Claire, seperated from him in 1923, saying "he had allowed their palatial home to become so dillapidated and run down" that she was unable to stay there. She left Milton, Connecticut, returned to Boston.

Find A Grave memorial No. 78346099.
m. 21 JUN 1928 Baltimore, Baltimore Co., Maryland, Barbara Hinkley , b. 6 FEB 1889 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 MAR 1958 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
1 children: Susan.
(9) Susan Wolcott (Roger Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1929 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(8) William Prescott "Prescott" Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 MAY 1880 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 JUN 1947 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesWILLIAM served as the American Red Cross representative at Base Hospital 18 in France during World War I. He was a member of the Wolcott Society living at Readville, Massachusetts, in 1914. He was a later a farmer at Milton, Massachusetts, and a noted sportsman and dog-show judge.

(8) Samuel Huntington Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 NOV 1881 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 DEC 1964 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesSAMUEL was a member of the Executive Committee for Massachusetts of the American Protective League, and Captain in the First Cavalry Troop,Massachusetts State Guard, in 1919.

1918 Draft Registration:
Samuel Huntington Wolcott 36, b. 9 Nov 1881, Milton, Norfolk, Massachusetts, banker, Brown Bros. and Co., wife Hannah S. Wolcott, Milton, tall, medium build, brown eyes, black hair.

In 1930 he was at Milton, Massachusetts, with Hannah, Edith P., and Samuel, Robert S Wolcott.

3 children: Edith Prescott, Samuel Huntington, Robert Stevenson.
(9) Edith Prescott Wolcott (Samuel Huntington Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 SEP 1908 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(9) Samuel Huntington Wolcott (Samuel Huntington Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 AUG 1910 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 7 NOV 2000 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesSAMUEL attended Harvard University, where he lettered in three sports. He was a founding partner of Loring, Wolcott & Coolidge, a financial firm. He was probably the Samuel Wolcott who deposited the Wolcott family papers with the Massachusetts Historical Society in 1989.
(9) Robert Stevenson Wolcott (Samuel Huntington Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 FEB 1914 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 6 AUG 1984 .
NotesROBERT S. Wolcott served in World War II and was captured by the Germans.
(8) Cornelia Frothingham Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 FEB 1885 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 JAN 1956 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
m. 18 APR 1911 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Samuel Smith Drury , b. 18 OCT 1878 Bristol, Bristol Co., Rhode Island, d. 21 FEB 1938 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
3 children: Samuel Smith, Roger Wolcott, Edith Prescott.
(9) Samuel Smith Drury (Cornelia Frothingham Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 DEC 1911 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 7 OCT 1972 Nahant, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
NotesSAMUEL graduated from Harvard University in 1935, and was Captain of the Harvard crew team.
(9) Roger Wolcott Drury (Cornelia Frothingham Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 MAR 1914 Jamaica Plain, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 31 OCT 1996 Sheffield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated from Harvard in 1936. He was a reporter for the New York Herald Tribine 1936-7, worked in the Advertising Department of Macmillan Company 1937-9, did alternative service as a military service objector 1939-46, and was a dairy farmer at Sheffield, Massachusetts, 1946-60. He was author of "The Finch's Fabulous Furnace", published in 1971, and other works.
(9) Edith Prescott Drury (Cornelia Frothingham Wolcott8, Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 DEC 1916 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 6 SEP 1987 Pasadena, Los Angeles Co., California.
(8) Oliver Wolcott (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 APR 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 11 MAR 1967 South Hamilton, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
Notes OLIVER graduated from Harvard in 1913 and received his LLB in 1915. He was a Capt. in the U.S. Army Cavalry and served with the 28th Div. in France. In 1925, he was a Lt. Col. in the National Guard. He was legal counsel for the Old Colony Trust Co.
m. 2 DEC 1922 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, Sybil Appleton , b. 28 DEC 1899 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 DEC 1973 Beverly, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
3 children: Helen, Augusta Peabody, Oliver.

NotesOLIVER lived at Hamilton, Massachusetts in 2004. He was Marketing Manager of Honeywell, Inc. at Waltham, Massachusetts, in 2007. He joined the Wolcott Society as member 1734.
(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.

m. 12 MAY 1875 Caroline Rosa Bayard , b. , d. .
2 children: Adeline Mckean, Alexander.
(9) Adeline Mckean Henry (Alexander Henry8, Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 MAY 1878 , d. .
(9) Alexander Henry (Alexander Henry8, Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 AUG 1885 , d. .
(8) Charles Wolcott Henry (Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 APR 1852 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 23 NOV 1903 .
NotesCHARLES took over his father's lumber business, Henry, Bayard & Co., in 1872, and was active in the business until his death. He was a member of the Philadelphia Common Council in the 1870s and 1880s, served on the Fairmont Park Commission, and was a Trustee of the Chesnut Hill Academy. His uncle, Alexander Henry, was Mayor of Philadelphia 1858-1862. The Charles W. Henry Elementary School in Philadelphia was named for him.
m. 18 NOV 1885 Sarah Bonnell "Sallie" Houston , b. 1860 , d. 1938 .
3 children: Thomas Charlton, Gertrude Houston, Elizabeth Wolcott.

NotesFREDERICK studied at the Sheffield Scientific School at Yale University, graduating in 1852. He joined Norwood & Co. in New York City, and in 1855 went to work for New Jersey Railroad. He became General Superintendant of the United New Jersey Railroads, Pennsylvania Co..
m. 12 OCT 1859 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Nannie Jane Nye , b. 5 AUG 1835 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 10 MAR 1905 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.

(8) Philip Nye Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 SEP 1860 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 13 MAR 1911 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesPHILIP graduated from Princeton University in 1880, and Columbia Law School. He worked for the Newark Power & Light Co..
m. 5 NOV 1884 Margaret Atlee , b. , d. 12 SEP 1934 .
6 children: Nannie Nye, Edith Atlee, Frederick Wolcott, Margaret Atlee, Philip Nye, Schuyler Brinckerhoff.

(9) Frederick Wolcott Jackson (Philip Nye Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 FEB 1888 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 13 DEC 1934 Wolcott, Wayne Co. New York.
(9) Margaret Atlee Jackson (Philip Nye Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 NOV 1890 , d. .
(9) Philip Nye Jackson (Philip Nye Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 MAY 1898 , d. .
(9) Schuyler Brinckerhoff Jackson (Philip Nye Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 AUG 1900 , d. 4 JUL 1968 Wabasso, Indian River Co., Florida.
NotesSCHUYLER was a writer, critic, and poetry editor for Times magazine. He and his wife Laura, were co-authors of "Rational Meaning", published after his death. They settled at New Hope, Pennsylvania in 1941. In 1943 they moved to Wabasso, Florida, where he had a fruit shipping business. His papers are at Cornell University,
(8) John Brinckerhoff Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 AUG 1862 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
NotesJOHN attended the Naval Academy 1879-83. He served in the Navy, resigning in 1886. He studied law at New York University and was admitted to the bar in 1889. He joined the diplomatic corps in 1890 and in 1903 was appointed minister to Greece, Roumania, Serbia, Bulgaria and Montenegro. In 1907 he was transferred to Persia, and in 1909 to Cuba, and then to the Balkans.
m. 25 APR 1886 Florence A. Baird , b. , d. .
1 children: Florence.
(9) Florence Jackson (John Brinckerhoff Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 MAR 1887 , d. 10 APR 1887 .
(8) William Fessenden Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 NOV 1864 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
NotesWILLIAM graduated from Princeton University in 1885 and became a banker.
(8) Frederick Wolcott Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 JUN 1867 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 2 SEP 1932 Lakeville, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK graduated from Princeton University in 1887 and received a docturate from Columbia University in 1888 and graduated from Priceton Theological Seminary in 1891. He was a Presbyterian minister, and a member of the Board of Managers of the Americam Bible Society. He was a missionary to China 1892-94, representing the Society. He studied medicine at Bellvue Hospital 1894-95. He was pastor of the Scotch Presbyterian Church at Jersey City 1896-1900. He then did missionary work in North Carolin and studied in Germany. In 1906 he became an English professor at the German Theological Seminary at Bloomfield, New Jersey. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1930 as member #149, residing at Glen Ridge, New Jersey.
m. 27 JUN 1894 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, Louise Gindrat Arnold , b. 23 OCT 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, d. 17 FEB 1928 Glenn Ridge, Essex Co., New Jersey.
4 children: Elizabeth Screven, Frederick Huntington Wolcott, Louise Arnold, Nannie Nye.
(9) Elizabeth Screven Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 SEP 1895 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Frederick Huntington Wolcott Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 SEP 1897 , d. 8 OCT 1925 .
NotesFREDERICK attended the Naval Academy at Annapolis and patroled the coast in the summer of 1918.
(9) Louise Arnold Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAY 1902 Glenn Ridge, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 4 OCT 1944 New York City, New York.
(9) Nannie Nye Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 SEP 1904 , d. 9 FEB 1923 .
(8) Charles Huntington Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1869 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 5 JUN 1911 Denver, Arapahoe Co., Colorado.
NotesCHARLES graduated from Princeton in 1890 and Columbia Law School in 1893, He was at Attorney at Newark until 1903, when he joined the Benefit Life Insurance Co.. He moved to Greeley, Colorado, in 1908 where he died of a heart attack.
(8) Elizabeth Wolcott Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JAN 1872 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .

NotesNEILSON graduated from Princeton in 1924.

NotesOLIVER graduated from Princeton University in 1898 and became a realator.

3 children: Frances Adele, Lorraine Wolcott, Martha Nye.

(9) Martha Nye Jackson (Oliver Wolcott Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 AUG 1910 , d. .
(8) Martha Nye Jackson (Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 NOV 1878 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 7 MAR 1951 .
m. 12 OCT 1906 Lewis Stewart , b. , d. 3 MAR 1908 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
1 children: Francesca Lewis.
(9) Francesca Lewis Stewart (Martha Nye Jackson8, Frederick Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 DEC 1907 , d. 5 JUN 1980 Godalming,, England.
(7) Joseph Cooke Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 AUG 1835 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 22 MAY 1913 New York City, New York.
NotesJOSEPH graduated from Yale College in 1857. He received a LLB degree from Harvard University in 1860 and was admitted to practice law in New York City in 1860. He was commissioned Lt. Col. of the 6th New Jersey Volunteers in December 1862 for his gallant action at Fredericksburg, Virginia, December 11-15, 1862. He was brevetted Brigadier General, March 13, 1865. He was appointed U.S. Assistant District Attorney for the Southern District of New York by President Grant in 1870. After the war he was an attorney in New York City. He visited Tolland, Somerset, in 1903 and 1907, and joined the Wolcott Society in 1913 residing at New York City. In 1912 he privately published a 93 page book, "European and American Family of Wolcott". Some things said in that book were erronius.
m. 12 OCT 1864 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Katharine Perkins Day , b. 24 FEB 1837 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 NOV 1914 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
4 children: Joseph Cooke, John Day, Katharine Seymour, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott.
(8) Joseph Cooke Jackson (Joseph Cooke Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 AUG 1865 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAR 1946 Orange, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesJOSEPH graduated from Yale University in 1887.
m. 14 JUN 1900 Orange, Essex Co., New Jersey, Mabel Goodsell , b. 29 APR 1872 , d. 11 APR 1955 Orange, Essex Co., New Jersey.
1 children: Joseph Hamilton Goodsell.
(9) Joseph Hamilton Goodsell Jackson (Joseph Cooke Jackson8, Joseph Cooke Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JUN 1901 East Orange, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
(8) John Day Jackson (Joseph Cooke Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 SEP 1868 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 MAR 1961 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesJOHN graduated from Yale University in 1890 and was a journalist. He was owner and publisher of the New Haven Register.
m. 28 JUL 1909 Elgin, Kane Co., Illinois, Rose Marie Herrick , b. 25 MAR 1888 Dundee, Kane Co., Illinois, d. 9 FEB 1977 Hamden, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
8 children: Richard Seymour, John Herrick, Henry Wolcott, Lionel Stewart, Rose Day "Posy", Katharine, Harriet, William Brinckerhoff "Billy".

NotesROSE was a vice-chairwoman of the American Red Cross 1960-1966, and a representative of the League of Red Cross Societies to the United Nations for 25 years.

NotesWilliam was killed over China in World War II.

(7) John Peter Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 FEB 1837 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 17 DEC 1880 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesJOHN graduated from Princeton College in 1856 and received a LLB degree from Harvard in 1858. He was an attorney at Newark, New Jersey. He was a member of the Newark City Council 1866-70, and was Speaker of the New Jersey Legislature 1862-63.
m. 1868 Clara Catlin Gregory , b. , d. 1936 .
5 children: Eliza Gregory, Laura Wolcott, Eliot Gregory, John Peter, Huntington Wolcott.

NotesJOHN graduated from the Naval Academy and served in the Navy during the Spanish American War.
(8) Huntington Wolcott Jackson (John Peter Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 APR 1880 , d. .
NotesHUNTINGTON graduated from Princeton University.
m. 18 FEB 1909 Shelby Converse , b. , d. .
(7) Hannah Wolcott Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 APR 1839 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 24 AUG 1904 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(7) Huntington Wolcott Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JAN 1841 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 3 JAN 1901 ,, Illinois.
NotesHUNTINGTON entered the College of New Jersey in 1859, but left at the end of his junior year to join the army. In 1863 he was brevetted Lt. Colonel. He was badly wounded at Kenesaw Mountain. He graduated from Harvard Law school in 1865, and was admitted to the Bar in 1868. He practiced law in Newark and Chicago, and in 1888 he was president of the Chicago Bar Assn. He apparently never married. A bronze tablet to his memory was placed in the Marshall Field store in Chicago.
(7) Charles Henry Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 MAY 1843 , d. 14 FEB 1844 .
(7) Henry Griswold Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 MAR 1845 , d. 28 MAR 1846 .
(7) Schuyler Brinckerhoff Jackson (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 JUN 1849 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 28 JUL 1915 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
NotesSCHUYLER graduated from Yale College in 1871, and from Columbia Law School in 1873. In 1879 he was an alderman at Newark 1879-80 and a member of the New Jersey legislature 1878-79. He became Speaker of the General Assembly of New Jersey in 1879. He was a member of the Wolcott Society 1914-15, residing at Newark, New Jersey.
m. 27 FEB 1889 Angela Forbes , b. , d. .
(6) Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 AUG 1808 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 APR 1883 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
NotesFREDERICK was a merchant in New York City. In 1860 he was living at Newtown, Queens, with Sarah E., Elizabeth H., Alice, Frederick, and Gardner H. He was much interested in family history, and hired H. G. Somerby to research the Wolcott family in England. It was largely through his interest and using his papers that Samuel Wolcott compiled the "Wolcott Memorial", the first published genealogy of the family. The book was privately distributed in 1886. Frederick owned the Oliver Wolcott house at Litchfield.
m. 12 JUN 1838 ,, New York, Abby Woolsey Howland , b. 11 NOV 1817 New York City, New York, d. 14 JUN 1852 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
6 children: Elizabeth Huntington, Alice, Frederick Henry, Gardiner Howland, Oliver Huntington, Abby Howland.
(7) Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott (Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1840 Nyack, Rockland Co., New York, d. .

1 children: Huntington Wolcott.

NotesGARDINER was a merchant, and travelled to Europe in 1880.
(7) Oliver Huntington Wolcott (Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 OCT 1850 New York City, New York, d. 15 MAY 1852 New York City, New York.
(7) Abby Howland Wolcott (Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1852 , d. 22 JUN 1852 .
(6) Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 AUG 1808 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 APR 1883 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
NotesFREDERICK was a merchant in New York City. In 1860 he was living at Newtown, Queens, with Sarah E., Elizabeth H., Alice, Frederick, and Gardner H. He was much interested in family history, and hired H. G. Somerby to research the Wolcott family in England. It was largely through his interest and using his papers that Samuel Wolcott compiled the "Wolcott Memorial", the first published genealogy of the family. The book was privately distributed in 1886. Frederick owned the Oliver Wolcott house at Litchfield.
m. 18 JAN 1855 Plattsburgh, Clinton Co., New York, Sarah Elizabeth Merchant , b. 22 OCT 1822 Plattsburgh, Clinton Co., New York, d. 1907 .
3 children: Charles Merchant, Abby Howland, Alice.
(7) Charles Merchant Wolcott (Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 NOV 1855 New York City, New York, d. 3 APR 1858 .
(7) Abby Howland Wolcott (Frederick Henry "Fred" Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1863 New York City, New York, d. .

NotesALICE never married. She owned and lived in the Oliver Wolcott house at Litchfield. In 1922 she sold it to her niece, Alice Sherman.
(6) Laura Maria Wolcott (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 AUG 1811 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 7 FEB 1892 .
NotesLAURA went to live with her maternal grandparents at Norwich, Connecticut, shortly after her father remarried. She lived with them for nine years. In 1825 she was sent to Sarah Pierce's school for girls at Litchfield. In 1880, Laura was at Newburgh, New York, with daughters, Laura M., Frances W., Mary W., and Cornelia W. Wolcott

(9) Katherine McGiffert (Gertrude Huntington Boyce8, Katherine Almedea Rankin7, Laura Maria Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .

NotesARTHUR attended Lane Seminary. He was President of the Chicago Theological Seminary. He wrote a biography of Robert and Laura Wolcott Rankin.
